The team has won 25 out of 30 matches so far, setting a record. The next league game is the derby against Manchester City. United has won 50 out of a possible 54 points in their last 18 Premier League games and aims to surpass Chelsea's record 95-point haul from 2005. Ferguson will make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea, among others. Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck, and Tom Cleverley were not started in the previous game. The team had a tough second half against Sunderland but won due to determined defending and courage.

Google paid £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011, as required by law. Google's UK sales are primarily routed through Ireland, leading to criticism for tax minimization. Google's chairman, Mr. Schmidt, has advocated for corporate taxes to be levied in the country where economic activity and risks are conducted, rather than where products are consumed. He has also called for international tax reform and a debate on the issue. Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, has suggested a new committee to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms, with the aim of preventing companies from hiding their tax affairs behind confidentiality rules. European Union leaders have agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an "automatic information exchange between tax authorities."

The passage discusses the efforts by NHS Improvement to reduce the agency bill, which currently stands at £3.6bn. The regulator aims to bring this down by £1bn by the end of the current financial year. A cap on agency staff pay was introduced in October and has already saved £600m. The cap limits the pay for staff, including doctors, nurses, and administration staff, to no more than 55% above normal shift rates, with senior managers being the only exception. The goal is to reduce the overall cost of agency staff and decrease the NHS's reliance on them. However, the NHS is currently 10% behind its target for reducing the agency bill, and it is unclear if spending on other parts of the pay bill has increased to compensate. NHS Improvement plans to publish league tables of trusts' performance on agency spending later this year, and will also collect information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust due to suspicions of excessive earnings. The passage also mentions examples of hospitals being quoted double the rates for doctors, with one surgeon being quoted £130 an hour when the cap is meant to

The Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of Ireland's economic prosperity, now stands as a reminder of the economic crash. Local trader Matt O'Brien, who runs a family-owned men's clothing shop, has noticed an increase in business over the past year, despite a 30% decrease during the economic downturn. However, he believes more could be done to boost local business, such as eliminating street parking charges.

The main opposition party, Fianna Fáil, criticizes the current government's handling of the midlands region, particularly the half-a-billion euro investment in water meters. They argue that this money should instead be used for broadband improvement. Local TD Robert Troy accuses the government of negligence, stating that the Industrial Development Authority (IDA) has not brought any potential clients to Longford in over four years.

However, the government points to the proposed Center Parcs tourism development in Ballymahon, which could employ about 1,000 people when it opens in 2019. Despite needing planning permission, the local Fine Gael TD, James Bannon, is confident about

The passage describes a cricket competition, the Indian Premier League (IPL), which takes place in a single stadium and finishes on May 29th. Eight teams are participating, with each team playing against every other team twice. The top four teams after these matches will qualify for the play-offs. The competition can be followed via BBC Sport.

Leading run-scorers in the tournament are Warner (294), Kohli (267), and De Villiers (249). The players with the most sixes are Warner (12), De Villiers (12), and Kohli (8). The highest individual score is 108, achieved by De Kock, while Warner and Gambhir both scored 90*.

Four current or former England players are participating: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), and Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants).

The fixtures and results for the tournament are provided, with matches taking place from April 25th to May 29th.

The passage discusses an increase in plastic carrier bag usage in England since 2013, as reported by the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs. It highlights the environmental issues caused by these bags, such as ending up in landfills and rivers. The summary also mentions that starting from October 2021, people in England will be required to pay 5p for plastic bags to encourage reuse. The success of similar charges in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland in reducing bag usage is also noted, with the hope that the English charge will similarly lessen the amount of bags being discarded, thereby helping the environment.

The passage describes a day of severe weather conditions in Wales, particularly strong winds, which led to several disruptions. These disruptions included a part of a school roof being ripped off, power cuts affecting hundreds of homes, train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and the cancellation of six Irish Ferries sailings between Holyhead and Dublin. Arriva Trains Wales also warned of potential delays due to the winds. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham due to the high winds. Restrictions on major bridges were lifted into Friday evening, but a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend has caused at least one festive event, Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip, to be postponed.

Michael B. Jordan, who played the Human Torch in last year's Fantastic Four reboot, is "super excited" to work on an unspecified role in an upcoming film. He will be reuniting with his Creed director, Ryan Coogler, and is looking forward to working with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Nyong'o won a best supporting actress Oscar for 12 Years a Slave in 2014, and Boseman is currently playing Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. The release date for the new film is February 2018, but the specific details about Jordan's role are not provided in the passage.

The passage describes a restoration project for the east wing of Alexandra Palace, which includes the renovation of a theatre founded in 1875 and BBC studios. The theatre, which has been unused for decades, will be used for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The project aims to transform Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination. The Heritage Lottery Fund (HLF) is contributing £18.8m towards the project, while Haringey Council is contributing £6.8m. The entire east wing will be refurbished at a cost of £26.6m, with the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust committing to raising the final £1m by summer 2017. The theatre still retains much of its original decor and stage machinery, and was originally designed to showcase opera, musicals, plays, and early cinema screenings.

The passage is about a former Manchester City player, aged 30, named Milner. He has represented England in 61 senior matches, starting from 2009, and was part of the squad for two World Cups and two European Championships. However, he only played for 3 minutes during Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, which he earned from 2004. He scored his only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers. Milner has announced his decision to step away from the England team, wishing success for the team, staff, and supporters in the future.

Marcy Smith and her family, including her son David, were awakened by a house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador. The house was completely destroyed, and their pets did not survive. The fire was started by rubbish burned in the wood stove, an action Mrs. Smith had done before without incident. The fire alarm did not go off. The family escaped with only their pyjamas, but the community has provided them with clothing, shoes, and a bike for David. Mrs. Smith credits David for their survival, as he was the only one awake and alerted the family to the fire. She is proud of her son for his quick actions.

The energy drinks giant is considering a £200m offer for West Ham United, a Premier League football club. Sullivan and Gold bought a majority stake in West Ham in 2010 for £105m and currently own over 85% of the club. There have been previous takeover links from Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan mentioned last year that a minority shareholding could be sold to clear debts, but they intend for the ownership to be passed on to their children.

The passage describes an awards ceremony, not the Oscars, held in Los Angeles. The fan-voted awards included categories like best kiss, best shirtless performance, and best movie. The Fault in Our Stars won best movie, and its star Shailene Woodley won best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Other winners included Bradley Cooper for best male performance, Channing Tatum for best comedic performance, Meryl Streep for best villain, and Kevin Hart for the comedic genius award. Robert Downey Jr won the Generation Award, and clips from upcoming summer releases like Pitch Perfect 2, Judd Apatow's Trainwreck, and Marvel's Avengers: Age of Ultron were shown.

In the provided passage, it is stated that Cameron Smith, a 21-year-old football player who has scored five goals this season while on loan from Dundee United to United, previously made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 and scored four times in 89 appearances for the Pittodrie side. Jack Ross, the boss of St Mirren, a Championship bottom side, has expressed his excitement about Smith joining their team, referring to him as a "really good player" and a "good, mature boy" who will provide another option in the attacking area. The passage concludes with the information that St Mirren will host Falkirk on Saturday.

The passage discusses a plan by Northumberland County Council to address pothole issues in the county. They aim to fill approximately 145 potholes daily for the next four months, using their Jetpatcher machines. Additionally, extra staff will be deployed to repair damaged drainage systems and clear debris from gutters, likely in response to heavy rain.

The passage describes an incident that occurred on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland in December 2016. Six workers, employed by Wood Group under a contract with EnQuest, were exposed to low levels of Naturally Occurring Radioactive Material (NORM) while removing pipework. The workers were not wearing proper Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) at the time. EnQuest and Wood Group have since taken additional precautionary steps to prevent further exposure. The workers are undergoing ongoing blood tests due to cancer fears. Rigging supervisor Steve Innes claims EnQuest failed in its duty of care and has struggled to find work since raising concerns. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) was made aware of the incident but no investigation was carried out as it was not reportable under the current RIDDOR system and no staff raised the issue with HSE separately. The Unite union believes the workers have been treated poorly and calls for openness and transparency about safety incidents to create a safer working environment offshore.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 (£420,000) from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The dealer was later found guilty of trafficking antiquities and selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the bronze sculpture. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. The decision to return the sculpture was made after discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Indian government body looking after its antiquities, the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). The ASI submitted an official request for the return of the sculpture in May. The ACM is taking legal action to seek compensation for the apparent fraud. The museum also bought 29 other objects from the art dealer, although none of the others are thought to be listed as stolen. The ASI was reportedly allowed to view them.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake occurred in Garfagnana, Italy, 35km north of Lucca, at a depth of 15.5km. The quake was felt in cities such as Milan, Florence, and Milan, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or significant damage. The area is prone to earthquakes, with a previous incident in May 2021 causing over 20 deaths. The quake struck at 15:48 GMT and was followed by several aftershocks. Power supplies were cut, phone lines were down, and schools were evacuated in the Garfagnana area as a precaution. The earthquake was described as "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow" by Alessandro Amato of the National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology (INGV). Italy is still recovering from the aftermath of the 2009 earthquake in L'Aquila, where six scientists and an ex-official were convicted of multiple manslaughter for providing false reassurances about the danger of the tremors before the deadly quake.

A 62-year-old man named Austin Grant from Sheffield, South Yorkshire, has successfully grown avocados in his garden. Despite initial doubts about the climate suitability, he has finally seen some results. The avocados are still attached to the plant and are not yet ripe enough to eat. Austin was overjoyed upon seeing the fruits.

The passage discusses the delay of the release of Grand Theft Auto V from 27 January to 24 March due to testing and polishing needs. Rockstar assures that this delay is in the best interest of the game and fans. The company also announced that online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release. Screenshots of the PC version have been released, promising improved visuals with 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and support for up to triple monitor configurations. While waiting for the game, PC users can ensure their systems meet the minimum requirements. GTA V holds the record for the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, generating $1bn in revenue in just three days upon its initial release in 2013.

The passage describes the 76-year-old artist, Malcolm Simpson, winning the John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)" at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. The painting depicts a leper squint, a hole in medieval churches for the undesirable to observe services. Simpson has been a shortlisted artist for the prize on multiple occasions and said winning was "very nice indeed." Judge Ansel Krut praised the painting as "quite extraordinary" and a "tone poem." The painting is about 7ft in height and Simpson entered it into the competition because of its size and familiarity. He plans to use the prize money of £25,000 on art supplies such as canvas, stretches, and paints. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig. Sir Peter Blake, now the prize's patron, won the junior title in 1961.

Two pro-government newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, in Istanbul, Turkey, were attacked simultaneously in the early hours of Thursday. The attacks involved gunfire, resulting in damaged windows and numerous spent bullet casings at both scenes. No casualties were reported. The police are currently investigating and have cordoned off the areas around the buildings. Neither attack has been claimed by any group as of yet. This incident follows a similar attack on the daily Hurriyet's offices last September, where pro-government protesters accused the paper of misquoting President Erdogan.

A 24-year-old footballer, who was previously under contract with the Stags, has agreed to join Marcus Bignot's team, the Mariners, on a free transfer starting from 1 January. He spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances. This will be Bignot's first signing for the Mariners, and he previously played for Burton.

The passage discusses two main topics: Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger's comments on England manager candidate, Gareth Southgate, and Wenger's plans for Arsenal defender Hector Bellerin.

1. Arsene Wenger, whose contract with Arsenal runs until the summer, has been linked with the England manager position. Current England manager Gareth Southgate, who took over from Sam Allardyce in September, is seeking a permanent position after overseeing England's 2-0 win against Malta and a 0-0 draw with Slovenia. Wenger praised Southgate's experience and competency, stating that he should prove his worth through his decisions. Southgate has upcoming World Cup qualifiers against Scotland and a friendly against Spain to impress the Football Association.

2. Regarding Arsenal, Wenger announced that 21-year-old defender Hector Bellerin will be offered a new contract. Despite interest from Barcelona and Manchester City, Wenger expressed his desire for Bellerin to stay at Arsenal long-term. Additionally, Wenger mentioned that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss "one

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. The incident is being jointly investigated by Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive. The company is cooperating fully with the investigation.

The Transport Minister, Humza Yousaf, announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a long-standing dispute over seafarers' pay. The issue concerned workers on two freight boats being paid less than £4 an hour. The charter change will transfer contracted services back to operator Serco Northlink from next month, as Seatruck, the current operator, argued that the national minimum wage was not applicable to the crew, many of whom are non-UK residents. Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap and backdate it, but Seatruck declined. The new arrangements, subject to some financial and regulatory details, will ensure all crew members are paid at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink has been operating three ferries and two cargo boats to the Northern Isles on a heavily subsidized route since 2012.

Ken Dickie, aged 64, passed away in a hospital six days after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. The incident occurred following an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother, which involved Jamie Mitchell, aged 35. Mr Mitchell had admitted intervening in the argument and was found guilty by a jury at Winchester Crown Court. The trial revealed that Mr Mitchell and Mr Dickie had been in a relationship for several years and were going through a difficult phase at the time. On 7 May, Mr Mitchell visited his mother at the park and, after getting drunk in the holiday park bar, there was a confrontation between him and Mr Dickie outside. Mr Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault in relation to the fight. Additionally, he and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, aged 57, admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the events to the police. The pair will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a British songwriter, died last week at the age of 66 after a brief battle with cancer. He is best known for his work with Michael Jackson, writing hits such as Off The Wall, Rock With You, and Baby Be Mine. Temperton also wrote for Jackson's album Thriller, including the title track and The Lady in My Life. His songs were also popular with other artists like Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin, and The Brothers Johnson. Temperton was nicknamed The Invisible Man due to his low profile and traced his songwriting ability back to his father's influence. He won a Grammy Award in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986. His family has requested privacy at this time.

A team of archaeologists, including Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott from Swansea University, have discovered ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in the western Brazilian Amazon. These discoveries include over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs" that were hidden for centuries by bamboo-dominated rainforest. The function of these sites is still unclear, but they are unlikely to be villages and may have been used sporadically as ritual gathering places, similar to the Maya pyramids or Stonehenge. Dr Loader's research suggests these geoglyphs were built amidst taller vegetation, unlike the Maya pyramids, and raises questions about their purpose. The research also indicates that the Amazonian forests were not pristine ecosystems, but had been influenced by humans for over 6,000 years, with a variety of plant species spread across the region. This suggests that people may have transformed their environment by concentrating on economically valuable trees, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products. Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, won his match against world number 29 Querrey in straight sets (6-4, 6-4) in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of a tournament. Kyrgios recently won the Japan Open and is approaching the top 10 in the world rankings. However, he was quieter than usual during the match, attributing his lack of vocalism to feeling tired and having a difficult time. Kyrgios mentioned that his success in Japan and the travel involved in playing at the Qi Zhong Stadium, an hour from Shanghai city center, had taken a toll on him, as he had a poor sleep the night before and the ride to the courts was not ideal. Kyrgios had previously been fined $1,500 for a foul-mouthed outburst at the Shanghai Masters last year, where he described the tournament as a "circus."

The passage discusses the call from scientists, charities, and organizations for the Welsh government to expand the HPV vaccination program to protect against head and neck cancers, in addition to the current protection against cervical cancer. The HPV vaccine is currently given to girls aged 12 and 13 in Wales, but the Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision. The increase in head and neck cancer cases, particularly among younger men who are non-smokers, is a concern. In 2008, a vaccination program was rolled out in schools in Wales, and 85% of girls have been vaccinated. The Welsh government has stated that they will consider the implications of any proposed changes to the HPV vaccination program after receiving recommendations from the committee.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old student at West Calder High School, was battling a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. He documented his life and treatment on a Facebook page called Jak's Journey, which attracted over 28,000 Likes. Jak's story and his positive attitude touched many people. He attended a school prom held in his honor on Saturday but had to leave due to feeling unwell. He was greeted at the event by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson. Jak's family collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity at the prom.

Jak was visited by various sports teams and the cast of the musical Wicked during his stays at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children in Edinburgh and Yorkhill Hospital in Glasgow. He also enjoyed experiences like visiting the Kelpies, having a romantic meal with his girlfriend, and going to a party in his honor.

Unfortunately, on January 23, Jak was informed by doctors that his cancer had spread throughout his body, and they decided not to pursue any

In a dull game with few chances, Egypt scored a late goal against Uganda, securing a 1-0 victory. The goal was scored by Abdallah El Said, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda had an earlier goal disallowed for offside. Egypt's win means they will play Ghana for the top spot in Group D on Wednesday, while Uganda are eliminated from the tournament, having not qualified since 1978. Ghana had already secured their place in the quarter-finals with a 1-0 victory over Mali earlier in the day. The game was played on a deteriorating pitch, with both goalkeepers making key saves. Uganda failed to register a shot on target, despite creating chances in the second half. Egypt appeared to be heading for a goalless draw, but Salah provided the decisive moment late in the game. Uganda will face Mali in their final group game on Wednesday, with Mali needing a win and a large margin of victory for Ghana to qualify.

The passage discusses a plan by Lancashire County Council to develop land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College, which are currently unused. The decision was made following a study by Network Rail. The council, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, plans to establish two direct trains to Liverpool per hour from Skelmersdale, a town that was designated a new town in 1961 and currently lacks its own railway station. The preferred location has good highway access and connectivity to the town and surrounding area. The council has initiated the process of acquiring the relevant land for this project.

The passage describes the discovery of plants in an elaborate grow house during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene. The core pieces of information are the discovery of plants in a grow house, the location of the warehouse (near Ashbourne), and the arrest of a man.

A 28-year-old woman of Kurdish origin was found with serious injuries, having been dragged by the neck through several streets in Hamelin, Lower Saxony. She underwent an emergency operation and was flown to a specialist clinic. The suspect, a 38-year-old man also of Kurdish origin from nearby Bad Muender, has handed himself in to authorities. The motive for the attack is currently unclear, and police are investigating, calling for witnesses to come forward.

The passage discusses a study conducted by the Cass Business School and universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, which found that while women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, they are less likely to receive one. The study, based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, found no evidence to support the theory that women are reticent about asking for more money. The study also found no evidence that women are reluctant to ask for a salary increase due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from a perceived female stereotype. The study took into account various factors such as the size of the employer, industry, whether the workers were parents, and their qualifications. The study's findings suggest that there is some element of discrimination against women in the workplace, and the researchers found that women and men under 40 ask for and receive pay rises at the same rate, indicating a potential change in negotiating behavior.

The passage discusses the issue of limited burial space in Oxford, England. Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years but has not found a suitable one due to various reasons such as size, ground conditions, high water table, or covenants restricting the use of the sites. The two remaining cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021 respectively. After these are full, the council plans to only offer options like reopening family plots, using a few reserved plots, and interment of ashes. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, offers an augmented reality experience through an app. This feature allows visitors to access online information from signs, posters, videos, and band interviews on their phones and tablets. Notable acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The festival organizers aim to provide this new feature to enhance the festival experience for attendees, while also allowing people worldwide to interact with the festival and experience its atmosphere. The app's content will be updated leading up to and during the event.

The passage describes the death of a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds, who won the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage" and was treated by veterinary staff before being pronounced dead. Despite being a rare incident, the British Horseracing Authority is determined to understand the causes and prevent such incidents in the future. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, but not on the day of his death. He was a well-known horse, having won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and was considered the "horse of a lifetime" by his trainer. The passage also mentions that Many Clouds had received treatment for a tendency to overheat in the past, but it does not conclusively link this condition to his death, as he was the victim of a rare pulmonary haemorrhage.

A 15-year-old girl met a man named David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Ayrton, now known as Davina, is currently on trial for allegedly raping the girl while two others were asleep in the garage. The victim clearly recalled the events, having only consumed half a can of Foster's. Davina, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer, has been remanded into custody at a male prison in Winchester due to concerns about her safety and potential to skip court. The trial took place at Portsmouth Crown Court, where Davina discussed her sexuality and denied making any physical changes to her body or taking medication. In 2014, Davina disclosed the attack to a worker at a care home where she lived in Fordingbridge, Hampshire.

The Serbs, specifically Novak Djokovic and an unspecified team, lost a doubles match 6-4 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This loss occurred a day after Djokovic was defeated in the singles by Juan Martin del Potro. Previously, Djokovic, who is the world number one, suffered a surprise third-round defeat in the Wimbledon singles by American Sam Querrey. However, he did win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics. The passage encourages readers to subscribe to the BBC Sport newsletter for more sports news, features, and videos.

The passage describes an upcoming event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, where over 20 competitors are expected to participate. These competitors are carvers from various countries, including Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US. The unique rule of the competition is that only chainsaws can be used for carving logs into animal and human shapes, and any other carving tools are prohibited. The defending champion, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will return to compete for the Claymore Trophy, the prize for the first-place winner.

The passage discusses the injury status and return plans of rugby player, Dan Biggar (referred to as Webb in the text). He has been out due to a serious foot injury sustained in a World Cup warm-up match with Italy in September. Webb is currently in a pre-season stage of recovery and aims to be fit for the Six Nations tournament starting in February. He expects to return around the beginning of February, but has asked his physios to expedite his recovery by a couple of weeks. The Six Nations tournament begins with Wales playing Ireland in Dublin on 7 February. Webb has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down offers from other clubs to stay with his home region. He made his debut with Ospreys in 2007.

The passage describes an incident involving drug smuggling from Canada to the US, specifically from Washington to San Francisco. Two men, Jeffrey Laviolette and Nathan Hall, were initially encountered by US border agents carrying backpacks containing approximately 58lbs (26kg) of MDMA (ecstasy). One of the men, whose identity is not specified, dropped his backpack, fired a weapon at the agents, and fled. Laviolette was immediately arrested. Hall was later arrested by the Abbotsford Police Department in British Columbia.

A Bellingham, Washington woman, Kali Henifin, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were also involved in the plot. They were accused of planning to pick up the two men at the border and transport the drugs to San Francisco. Lambert allegedly agreed to this for a payment of $11,000. Henifin told agents they had left the area after hearing a report of a shooting on a police radio.

All three defendants in US custody are facing charges of conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution. The wooded area near the border crossing is known for drug and firearm smuggling, and such cases are

The NSPCC's Childline service reported a significant increase in the number of children seeking help, with over 4,500 children counseled in the past year compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. The majority of these children experienced online abuse, with some as young as seven being tormented and scared to go to school. Online trolls were identified as the main cause of misery and humiliation for thousands of children. Dame Esther Rantzen, the president of Childline, urged adults, parents, and teachers to intervene to protect children, as bullying does not stop on its own and can have severe impacts on young people's lives. The report is being released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, which is coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance. The group is working with parents, schools, and other organizations to combat the problem. One young person shared their experience of cyber-bullying, expressing feelings of upset and helplessness. Advice given by young people on dealing with bullying includes asking for help.

The passage describes a series of events related to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. After a UN Security Council resolution, calling for an end to settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem, the US abstained from vetoing it, which Israel found infuriating. Israel's Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, claimed that the White House had helped draft the resolution and "pushed hard" for its passage, a claim denied by the US state department. The resolution states that settlements have no legal validity and constitute a violation under international law. Israel rejected the resolution, particularly the condemnation of building in East Jerusalem. In response, Israel postponed a planned vote on authorising new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot, at the request of the prime minister's office, to avoid further straining relations with the US. This postponement occurred ahead of a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry on his vision for ending the Israel-Palestinian conflict. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas sees the resolution as paving the way for a Middle East peace conference in France on 15 January.

The passage describes various events and celebrations marking Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday. The Queen, accompanied by other members of the royal family, visited Windsor and participated in several events, including meeting staff at a Royal Mail delivery office, opening a new bandstand, and viewing an exhibition. The royal family also posed for a picture that was released as a set of stamps to commemorate the Queen's birthday.

In addition, the passage discusses a BBC interview with Prince William, in which he paid tribute to the Queen, calling her a "guiding example" of what a good monarch should be. He also addressed recent criticisms about his commitment to royal duty, stating that he takes his responsibilities seriously but is trying to find his own way in his role as a future heir.

Finally, the passage mentions that the Queen will have two birthday celebrations, one on her actual birthday and another on a Saturday in June, and that there has been some criticism about the amount of coverage given to the Queen's birthday by the BBC.

In the EFL Cup match, West Ham United, a Premier League team, defeated League Two side Cheltenham Town 2-0. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored for West Ham before half-time, with assists from Sam Byram and a goal-less performance from Adrian in goal. Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a car collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday. Werner expressed remorse for the accident but could not offer an explanation for it.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British jihadist from Southall, west London, is facing a possible life imprisonment for his activities in Syria. In Syria, he was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State, and was involved in producing propaganda videos and appeals for donations. However, some of the group's material online showed gruesome scenes of death, including a picture of Khawaja holding a bag containing a head. Khawaja returned to the UK in June 2015, but was arrested upon arrival and is currently facing prosecution at the Old Bailey. He has admitted four offences, and an additional charge of soliciting to murder was made against him, although it will lie on file. Kayden Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, contributing to their eighth-place finish in the table. In the passage, it is reported that bottles, possibly from a container lost from the MV Blue Ocean, have been washing up on Poldhu Cove and other nearby coves in Cornwall. The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the transfer of Neymar to Barcelona. Despite paying £48.6m for the Santos striker, it has been alleged that the actual cost of Neymar was significantly higher due to additional fees, including signing-on fees, agents fees, and wages. Barcelona's president, Sandro Rosell, resigned following accusations of misappropriating money and is currently under investigation.

In response, Barcelona made an additional tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to cover potential interpretations of the contracts related to Neymar's signing. Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver from Nottingham, was killed in a car accident caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, who was driving the wrong way on a motorway. Luciw's family, including his mother Andrea Shelton and brother Simon, are advocating for regular driving tests for older drivers, citing Luciw's untimely death as a result of an older driver's poor driving. Age UK supports the idea of older people being able to drive for as long as possible, but also emphasizes the importance of safety. Luciw's family and a colleague who survived the accident believe that regular medical examinations and driving tests should be implemented for older drivers. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must renew their licenses every three years and report any medical conditions that could affect their driving, but there are no mandatory medical or driving tests. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) has no plans to restrict licensing based on age, stating that older drivers are not more likely to cause serious accidents than others. The incident is being further discussed on BBC One East Midlands' Inside Out program.

The passage discusses the safety concerns surrounding transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse in women. Two members of the initial review group resigned in protest over a perceived watered-down report. An independent expert, Professor Alison Britton, will examine the process by which the report was concluded and provide recommendations for future procedures.

The final report recommended against offering the procedures routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse, suggested a range of treatments be offered, and advocated for mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a ban, the recommendations will continue to be implemented. The health secretary stated that the power to ban the procedures lies with the UK regulatory body, the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency.

The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to unite the panel members around the controversial final report. Two women who had suffered complications from the surgery, Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, resigned from the review group, claiming parts of the final report had been removed. A consultant also quit the expert group over concerns about the final draft of the report.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Kirsty Wade McColgan's 25-year-old record in the 5K race at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. McColgan initially expressed concerns about the authenticity of the race, as Muir was the only competitor in the 5K and there might not have been drug testing. However, British Athletics confirmed Muir's time is expected to be classified as official. McColgan believes Muir has the potential to win world medals, with her current time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds in the 5K being impressive, but still room for improvement. McColgan also noted similarities between Muir's record-breaking race and her own 25 years ago, as both races were run mostly alone. Muir has previously broken her own British 1500m record and reached the 1,500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

Andy Murray, a British tennis player, won his fourth-round match at Wimbledon against Italian player Fabio Fognini in a tense four-set game. The passage describes an incident at Joe's Bar in Dungiven, where paramedics were called for a sudden death at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police arrived later and found people still at the bar, with till receipts showing alcohol was served as late as 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered closed for three months. Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, has launched a manifesto titled 'Real Partnership'. The passage discusses a motion to be presented in Northern Ireland's assembly, aiming to bring the region in line with England and Wales in terms of pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offenses. This initiative, known as 'Turing's Law', is named after World War Two code-breaker Alan Turing. The law will provide posthumous pardons and allow living men to apply for pardons. The motion in Northern Ireland's assembly will contain provisions for both posthumous and living pardons for gay and bisexual men, with the aim of ensuring equal treatment. The Justice Minister, Claire Sugden, has secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion to pardon convictions related to abolished sexual offenses. Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, set a new Scottish record in the 1500m race with a time of 4 minutes, 19.12 seconds. Steve Smith, aged 26, has been appointed as the permanent captain of the Australian one-day and Twenty20 teams, replacing Michael Clarke who has retired after a heavy defeat by England in the Ashes series. The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. The passage discusses allegations made by Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, against Olam, a Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader, and its main stakeholder, Temasek. The passage discusses the ongoing dispute between Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, and Musa Bility, the boss of the Liberian Football Association (LFA), regarding Scala's participation in the upcoming election to replace long-standing Fifa president Sepp Blatter. Daniel Timbers (29) and Barry Joy (56) were fatally killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road, while working around 9:00 BST on Monday. They were believed to have been working in a paint-spraying area. The bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search was conducted at the company, which manufactures buckets for diggers. The police have made significant progress in their investigation, suggesting a flashover explosion caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source, resulting in a fire-ball effect. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence, including from their inspectors and electrical safety experts.

Tunisia was at risk of expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints lodged against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) following a controversial penalty call in the 2015 tournament. However, they apologized to Caf and were allowed to participate. Morocco, on the other hand, was initially banned from participating in the 2017 qualifying draw due to issues related to the 2015 tournament, but the ban was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Both countries are now preparing for the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations, with Tunisia aiming to set a record of 13 consecutive appearances in the tournament.

In the 95th minute of a football game at Etihad Stadium, Chelsea won 3-1. Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho from Manchester City were sent off, while Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will not face any further action. Aguero received a four-match ban for a high and late challenge on Chelsea defender David Luiz, which was his second dismissal for violent conduct this season. Fernandinho, who clashed with Fabregas in the subsequent scuffle, will serve a three-match ban. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge. City's manager, Pep Guardiola, apologized for his team's part in the incident.

The passage discusses a pilot plan in the Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd area focusing on early detection of lung cancer, as Wales and other parts of the UK contribute to a significant number of diagnostic tools for lung cancer worldwide. Doctors are concerned about the lack of symptoms or signs that would indicate lung cancer, and a visit to Denmark revealed that the healthcare system in Denmark has improved diagnostic tools. The hope is that Wales, which does not have clear symptoms for a long period before diagnosis, will not be a "difficult case" for any diagnostic method. Doctors need to be aware of the symptoms of less obvious lung diseases to detect lung cancer. A clinical trial will be set up in the University Hospital of Wales, Llantrisant, and it is expected that a few cases will be detected and diagnosed each week. Currently, only 35% of lung patients in the Cwm Taf area have symptoms that can lead to a diagnosis. England won the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series 1-1. Joe Root, promoted to number three for this series, was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. He also took four catches and claimed a wicket in Pakistan's first-innings. England made a total of 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, setting up their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment with their performance, particularly their shot selection, and stated that they are short of confidence. The passage discusses the British and Irish Lions' summer tour to New Zealand, led by head coach Warren Gatland. Rob Howley is part of Gatland's backroom team. In the given passage, Southampton and Hull City played a football match at the KCOM Stadium. Charlie Austin scored a penalty for Southampton in the 6th minute, but Hull City came back strongly in the second half, scoring two goals in two minutes through Robert Snodgrass and Michael Dawson. Hull City's win was their first in the league since 20 August, ending a six-game losing streak, but they remain in the bottom three of the league. The match was significant for Hull City as they were missing their starting strikers due to injuries, but Snodgrass, who returned from an ankle injury, played a crucial role in their comeback. The teams will next play Sunderland and Liverpool, respectively, following the international break.

A motorcycle crash occurred at approximately 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, Lincolnshire. The motorcyclist was a local resident and was killed in the collision. The passage describes a political crisis in Macedonia, triggered by covert recordings that appear to show ministers engaging in vote-rigging, cover-ups of a murder, and corruption at the highest levels of government. Swansea, promoted to the Premier League in 2011, is currently in a difficult situation following Bob Bradley's sacking. The club is concerned about the possibility of relegation, as the Championship has become stronger and it may not be easy for Swansea to return to the Premier League if they do get relegated. The passage describes an investigation by Ofsted into illegal schools in Birmingham, particularly in Muslim communities in the Midlands. Three schools have been closed due to squalid conditions, and their owners are under investigation. Sir Michael Wilshaw, the Chief Inspector of Schools, is concerned that these cases may be just the tip of the iceberg and that children are at risk of abuse or radicalization.

However, some places calling themselves part-time education centers or "flexi schools" are operating within the law but are suspected of running illegal schools. Sir Michael has suggested that officials have been slow to take decisive action, and the government has provided funding for a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools. The passage discusses the opening of Lilliard Gin distillery, located at the Born in the Borders visitor center in Jedburgh, marking the first whisky distillery in the Scottish Borders since 1837. The distillery is led by lead distiller Kate Macinnes, who emphasizes the potential for the region to become a "region of distilling excellence." The gin production is on a smaller scale compared to other distilleries in development, and the distillery fits into a cow shed. Lilliard Gin aims to capture the local flavors and 'terroir' of the Teviot valley using Borders botanicals. The distillery takes its name from a legendary Borders figure, Lilliard, who was a heroine of the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545. John Henderson of Born in the Borders views the gin distillery as a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery on the site, and is excited about the prospect of tasting the gin.

Harry Whitlam was tragically killed in August 2013 when Gary Green, who was under the influence of alcohol, reversed a vehicle into him on private land at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds. Green was more than twice the legal driving limit and had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed at 02:00 BST. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks for failing to ensure the safety of others. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her hope that her son's life would be remembered for more than just the day of the accident and that the family can again remember the good times they shared. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) investigated the incident and found that Green had been walking towards a worker in a closed-off area of the farm when he backed the tractor into Harry at about 09:15 on 9 August. HSE inspector Julian Franklin described Green's behavior as "reckless."

Luis Suarez, a Uruguayan striker, has had his ban from all football-related activities reduced by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). The reduction allows him to train, play in friendly matches, attend matches, and participate in promotional activities. However, he will still serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games. Suarez's ban was initially imposed by FIFA for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during Uruguay's 2014 World Cup group match. His legal team argued that the punishment was too strong, and CAS agreed that preventing him from participating in any football activity was excessive. The full explanation of the CAS ruling will be published at a later date. Suarez will now be available for Uruguay's friendlies against Japan and South Korea in September and Saudi Arabia the following month. He joined Barcelona last month for £75m and is expected to make his competitive debut against Real Madrid on 26 October in El Clasico. The decision has been met with mixed reactions, with some arguing that the sanction is still disproportionate, considering Su

On March 18, 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a unique race, the Carry Your Partner Race, in which competitors carry their partners over a 380-meter course that includes hurdles, a steep slope, and water pistol obstacles. The couple, who trained extensively for the event, will now represent their country at the World Championships in Finland in July. The race featured various combinations of competitors, including men carrying women, men carrying men, and one instance of a woman carrying a woman. The Lithuanian team, Vytautas Kirkliauskas carrying his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene, provided strong competition.

The passage discusses the scrapping of the paper system for car tax discs in October 2014, which will be replaced with an electronic system allowing monthly direct debit payments. This change may lead to adjustments in job roles at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) due to a potential reduction in the number of refunds and the withdrawal of the tax disc. However, the minister, Stephen Hammond, has assured that any reductions in staff will be managed through redeployment to other growth areas of the business, rather than redundancies. This news has been welcomed by Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, who represents DVLA employees.

The passage discusses a standoff between Hungary and the European Union (EU) over three issues: Hungary's control of asylum seekers and non-governmental organizations (NGOs), a higher education law, and a draft legislation on NGOs. Hungary's government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, has passed two of these laws and is forcibly housing asylum seekers in secured shipping containers, raising concerns about EU law compatibility.

The higher education law could lead to the closure of the Central European University (CEU), a prestigious institution founded by philanthropist George Soros. Thousands of Hungarians have protested against these laws in recent months. Hungary's government, however, has stated it will not backtrack on these issues, asserting that they are matters of national competence and that the EU should not interfere with domestic issues.

Poland has pledged to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary, as EU rules require unanimous approval for decisions that could strip a member country of its voting rights. The EU has expressed concern over these laws and is under pressure to take action

The passage describes an upcoming live-action adaptation of the Disney film "Beauty and the Beast." Emma Watson has been cast as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as Gaston's sidekick LeFou. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, the father of Belle, and the star will portray Mrs. Potts, the housekeeper magically transformed into a teapot. The film is set to be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017, and Bill Condon, director of Dreamgirls and the last two Twilight films, will direct the movie, which will begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

Adrian Gill, a renowned journalist and published author, passed away due to cancer. He was a long-time columnist for The Sunday Times, known for his witty, fearless, and compassionate writing. Despite his diagnosis, Gill did not feel cheated and considered himself lucky. His final column about coming to terms with his diagnosis will be published tomorrow. Gill was known for dictating his copy over the phone due to dyslexia. His writing often caused controversy, with comments about various groups and individuals, including animal rights groups, Welsh people, residents of Rhyl, Norfolk, the Isle of Man, and Clare Balding. Gill was born in Edinburgh, overcame dyslexia, and had a successful writing career, starting in the 1980s with art reviews for magazines, then writing for Tatler and The Sunday Times. He was married twice and had four children. His engagement to his partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, was prompted by his illness.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa and the lead singer of Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked during a performance in Ulan Bator, the country's capital. The attack involved being hit over the head with a bottle and repeatedly kicked in the face. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident, but has called local press reports "distorted." Sukhbaatar wore a swastika-embroidered Mongolian robe during the performance, a symbol that pre-dates its association with Nazis in Mongolia. His father stated that he spent about 10 days in a coma after the beating. The Russian official accused of the attack has not been identified. The swastika is also used by far-right groups in Mongolia, and there were reports that Sukhbaatar shouted "Heil Hitler" at the show, which were denied by his lawyer, father, and a band member. The case is under investigation by Mongolian police, with the suspect being a Russian diplomatic officer. The embassy denies that the suspect was not arrested due to diplomatic immunity.

On Monday, members of the action group Plane Stupid staged a demonstration against the expansion plans of an unspecified airport. The demonstrators were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area of an aerodrome. They are scheduled to appear in court on 19 August. The protest occurred on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday. The Metropolitan Police have announced that they will review security at the airport following the demonstration.

In the cricket match between Glamorgan and Gloucestershire, Nick Selman scored a century (101 runs off 144 balls), his second in first-class cricket. However, the bowlers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets in cloudy conditions, ensuring Glamorgan's total was 220. Gloucestershire struggled in their response, with Aneurin Donald scoring 36 runs. The day ended evenly balanced, with Glamorgan securing a consolation bonus point. Michael Hogan is leading Glamorgan in the absence of Jacques Rudolph, who has a neck problem. Selman expressed satisfaction with his performance, while Taylor was pleased with his bowling performance. The Gloucestershire batsmen face a tough challenge in the remaining innings.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested in August by North Wales Police for making threats to ambush and shoot police officers on the Dee Estuary. The threats were made online to the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee while Hughes was drunk. He admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. Hughes planned to make a false report to the police to lure them to a scene where he would carry out the attack. He has a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. Despite this, his legal team stated that he did not intend to kill himself and would not have carried out any threat to kill police officers. The Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counselling to people experiencing difficulty.

In the cricket match between Yorkshire and Surrey, Surrey posted a score of 255-7, with Davies and Foakes (90) contributing a stand of 130. Yorkshire's run-chase was disrupted by a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker, resulting in the dismissals of Jonny Bairstow, Gary Ballance, and others. Despite Tim Bresnan making 68, Yorkshire fell short, ending their innings at 236. Yorkshire had hoped to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002, but they were undone by dropped catches and poor batting performances. Surrey's captain, Gareth Batty, praised his team's performance, while Yorkshire's captain, Alex Lees, expressed disappointment with their performance, particularly their inability to make significant contributions with the bat.

A 56ft trawler, 6 miles west of South Stack, experienced water ingress and was unable to manage it with the onboard pump. The crew contacted the coastguards at 07:00 BST. The RNLI lifeboat crew provided an additional pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner from Scotland, will not be able to participate in the 2018 Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. She recently finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. Despite missing the Commonwealth Games, Muir aims to compete in the World Indoor Championships in March. She also expressed her satisfaction with her performance at the World Athletics Championships, where she set a new outdoor personal best time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m. Hellen Obiri won the 5,000m gold in London, with Sifan Hassan finishing third.

The passage discusses the current state of Liverpool's football team, as analyzed by football pundit Robbie Savage in his BBC Sport column. The team is struggling to repeat last season's title challenge, with Steven Gerrard facing a physical and mental battle to secure a long-term future with the Reds.

One of the main issues is the loss of key strikers Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge, who scored a combined 52 goals last season. Rodgers has not been able to find suitable replacements, with the current options (Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini) not being good enough and lacking in work-rate compared to the previous strikers.

Another problem is Liverpool's lack of intensity and pressing high up the pitch, which was a key factor in their success last season. They have scored fewer first-half goals this season and are having to chase games instead of being on the front foot.

Defensively, Liverpool still look vulnerable, despite spending money on players like Mamadou Sakho and Dejan Lovren. Simon Mignolet, the goalkeeper, is criticized for

A  £45m educational campus is to be constructed in Kilmarnock, Scotland, housing primary, secondary, Gaelic, and childcare facilities. The council plans to name the campus after local author William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney, a passionate advocate for education, was an English teacher before becoming a full-time writer in 1975. He gained recognition with his first novel, Remedy Is None, and was known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir" for his acclaimed Laidlaw trilogy and other Glasgow-based works. McIlvanney was also a poet, journalist, broadcaster, and contributed to Scottish politics and sports through columns and TV programs. He passed away on 5 December.

The passage describes an evacuation in a town near Gourock, due to the discovery of a sea mine, believed to be British and dating from the 1940s or 1950s. The evacuation affected three streets and wider safety advice was issued to residents within 500m of the device. An exclusion zone was also set up at sea and small boat owners were advised not to sail during the operation. The evacuation was a precautionary measure, with no immediate danger to the community, according to the local area commander. The mine was moved to a safer location due to concerns about the amount of explosive material it still contained. Ferry services were disrupted as a result of the operation. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the evacuation procedures.

The passage discusses funding decisions for Olympic and Paralympic sports in the UK for the Tokyo 2020 Games. UK Sport has allocated a total of £345m for 31 sports, which is £2m less than the funding for the Rio Games. Notable sports that have had their funding cut include archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and badminton. Cycling, which brought 12 medals in Rio, has had its funding cut by more than £4m. Badminton England is particularly upset about the decision, as they had a podium place in the summer and were set a target of winning a medal in Rio. Judo, which also claimed one bronze medal, has had its funding increased slightly. UK Sport has set Team GB a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo, aiming to maintain the success at Rio 2016. Sports like basketball, handball, and volleyball have previously had their funding withdrawn and are critical of UK Sport's approach to team sports. The funding for the five

In the given passage, a six-storey four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks are planned to replace three Victorian hotels in a conservation area of Bournemouth, East Cliff. The development, proposed by The East Cliff Project LLP, includes a 90-room hotel, a nine-storey, and a seven-storey building with 122 assisted-living apartments. English Heritage and some residents have objected to the demolition, citing the historical character of the area. However, the council, with a majority vote, approved the plans, stating the need to preserve tourism and improve living conditions for older people in the town. The loss of buildings and trees is regrettable, but progress is deemed necessary.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from Carrickfergus, County Antrim, was off-duty and on a night out in Brecon when he was attacked and beaten outside a bar called The Cellar. The attack, which occurred on 8 May, left him unconscious and he was later found by police. The attacker, Jake Vallely, will be sentenced on 8 December. Vallely's friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. The trial revealed that Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and had boasted he was the "hardest man in Brecon" before the attack. The attack was described as a "despicable act" that "shocked" the community of Brecon. Pte Boyd's family described him as an "all-rounder" with a "promising career ahead of him" and expressed their grief over his death. They also praised the community of Brecon for their support during the trial.

Andrew Travers, the former chief executive of Barnet Council, left his position by mutual agreement following an error that caused voting issues in the EU Referendum. On election day, all 155 polling stations in the borough experienced problems due to missing voter names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched to review the appropriateness of the arrangements in place for the EU Referendum, with the findings to be presented publicly by the end of May. In the interim, John Hooton, the deputy chief executive, will take over temporarily. Voters in the area have questioned the fairness of the election results due to the issues that prevented some from voting. Mr. Travers has blamed the electoral registration lists for the problems.

In this passage, a football match between Gateshead and Wrexham is described. Josh Gillies scored a free-kick for Gateshead to take the lead, but Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham with a set-piece before half-time. In the second half, Ryan Bowman scored a header from a cross by Craig Baxter to give Gateshead a 2-1 lead. Malcolm Crosby, the Gateshead manager, praised his team's performance in the second half, while Gary Mills, the Wrexham manager, expressed disappointment with his team's second-half performance. The match ended with a final score of 2-1 in favor of Gateshead.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks the social and economic welfare of individuals aged 60 and above in 96 countries. Norway is ranked as the best country, while Afghanistan is the worst, followed by Mozambique.

The passage discusses the OneWeb project, a planned constellation of at least 600 and potentially up to 2,000 spacecraft aimed at delivering global broadband internet. The project is significant due to its focus on high volume and low cost production, with Airbus adopting new assembly line methods similar to car and plane factories. The first assembly line has been inaugurated in Toulouse, France, with two more to be set up in Florida. The satellites produced are expected to cost less than a million dollars each.

The project aims to have every school connected and requires a large number of launches, with more than 20 Soyuz vehicles booked for the task. The constellation is expected to be fully established by the middle of the decade.

OneWeb and Airbus are not the only companies planning mega-constellations, with SpaceX, Boeing, ViaSat, and others also seeking regulatory approval. However, OneWeb believes it has a first-mover advantage due to already raised equity of $1.7bn and ongoing talks for additional financing.

The project is registered in the UK's Channel Islands

The passage discusses the UK government's spending review and its impact on Scotland. John Swinney, a Scottish government official, states that the UK government's spending review places "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure in Scotland, and that the Scottish government's discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. He also mentions that schools, hospitals, and the police service in Scotland will not be sacrificed due to austerity measures.

The UK government, in response, states that Scotland will have £390m more spending available to it next year, which rises to £750m if you include its own underspend. They also argue that the stability of the UK economy means the block grant will be almost £30bn, and that this is a better deal for people in Scotland than the constitutional alternative favored by the Scottish government.

Labour's public services spokeswoman, Jackie Baillie, criticizes John Swinney for not providing a concrete plan to counteract austerity measures and calls for

The passage discusses the need for Changing Places toilets, which are enhanced facilities designed for people with severe disabilities who require additional space and equipment such as hoists and changing benches. Currently, there are 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but campaigners argue that they should be made compulsory in larger buildings like shopping centers, cinemas, and leisure facilities.

Lorna Fillingham, a mother of a six-year-old with disabilities, is leading a petition to change building regulations to make Changing Places guidelines compulsory. She expresses concern about the lack of truly accessible toilet facilities in town centers, which can lead to stressful and unpleasant experiences for her and her daughter.

Alison Beevers and Bethan Folen also share their experiences of the psychological impact on their families due to the lack of appropriate changing facilities. They describe feelings of isolation, guilt, and a lack of inclusion in society.

However, there are positive examples of businesses and individuals making efforts to provide temporary or permanent Changing Places facilities, which have been well-received by the public. Arsenal Football Club, for instance,

A group of Italian consumers' organizations have filed a formal antitrust complaint against McDonald's with the European Commission, alleging that the fast-food giant forces franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. The complaint also claims that McDonald's makes franchisees sign longer-than-average contracts, preventing them from switching to competitors, and that franchise stores have poorer consumer choice and higher prices compared to those owned directly by the company. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and other European unions are supporting the complaint. McDonald's has denied the allegations, stating that it shares risks and rewards with its licensees and is committed to supporting its franchisees. The European Commission will study the submission and has the power to launch an investigation if it believes the allegations are founded. Franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and the company received $9.27bn in revenues from its franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A social media campaign using the hashtag #prayforjosh was initiated by Bangor Elim Church in support of 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The campaign started on Facebook and Instagram, and quickly went viral. The senior pastor of the church, Gary Beattie, was amazed by the global support received. A mystery donor paid for a billboard with the same hashtag to be erected in Holywood, County Down. The campaign has also received significant support on Twitter from Joshua's classmates at Bangor Grammar School. The campaign has led to widespread support for Joshua and his family during his recovery.

The passage discusses a planned closure of Brecon Barracks in the UK, a military facility with a long history dating back to 1805. The closure is part of a larger military reorganization in the UK. Chris Davies, the Conservative MP for Brecon and Radnorshire, strongly condemns the decision, citing the barracks' historical significance and its role in various conflicts since the early 19th century. He also expresses concerns about the potential impact on local unemployment and the military tourism industry.

The closure does not seem to pose a direct threat to the jobs of the approximately 85 civilian staff and 90 military personnel at Brecon Barracks. However, nearby Sennybridge training ground and infantry school at Dering Lines are not affected by the closure.

The reorganization will see a specialist light infantry center created at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan. Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire, whose closure was previously announced in 2013, will now close in 2024, and a storage depot at Sennybridge will close in 2025

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. The industry, which produces a small percentage of GDP and employs a limited number of fishers, is at risk of being marginalized in Brexit negotiations due to its low priority status for the government. However, the industry argues that Brexit offers an opportunity to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation.

The UK's fishing waters are shared with other EU coastal states, and the majority of UK fish are exported to the EU. The report suggests that continued market access may come at a price, as EU member states may demand more access to UK waters in return for zero tariffs on fish exports to the EU.

The report also recommends retaining many elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) post-Brexit, including basing total allowable catches and quotas on scientific advice and continuing international obligations to cooperate with neighboring states. However, the CFP framework treating the UK as one entity may fall away, potentially leading to four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland.
