The passage discusses the state of apprenticeships in England compared to other European countries, particularly Germany, and the concerns raised by the Sutton Trust about their quality and quantity. The Sutton Trust, in a report prepared by the Boston Consulting Group, states that only a small percentage of apprenticeships in England are rated at level three, which is equivalent to A-levels. The report also notes that England has a more complex and less respected vocational education system than countries like Germany, with a higher number of qualifications and a lower percentage of apprenticeships offered by employers.

The report calls for a radical expansion of apprenticeships, with a majority at level three or higher for a minimum of three years, and no more than 10% at level two. The Sutton Trust chairman, Sir Peter Lampl, emphasizes the importance of apprenticeships for social mobility and economic competitiveness.

The Department for Education acknowledges the need to reform apprenticeships to improve standards, but the Association of Colleges expresses concerns about the feasibility of creating 300,000 new apprenticeships

The passage describes the victory of a British Paralympian named Sarah Storey in a cycling event in Nottwil, Switzerland. She finished more than two minutes ahead of Anna Harkowska from Poland. Storey, who is 37 years old, is aiming for her 17th title in the upcoming road race. She is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with a total of 22 medals, including 11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze medals. Storey has won her medals in both cycling and swimming across six Paralympics. She won four golds at the 2012 Games in London and has now won 21 world titles across both sports. Storey began her sporting career in the pool, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, and later switched to cycling in 2005. She is targeting further Paralympic success at the upcoming Games in Rio de Janeiro in 2016.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Football Conference due to unpaid debts totaling £148,000 to various football creditors, including former manager Martin Foyle, players, staff, and other clubs. The Conference had extended the deadline for payment three times, but Hereford failed to meet the final deadline on June 12. The last team to be expelled from the Conference was Chester City in 2010. Chester has taken Hereford's place in the Conference Premier, following a dramatic final day of the season in 2014 when Hereford managed to stay up. Hereford still owes over £70,000 to clear the latest PAYE tax demand from HM Revenue and Customs. The downward spiral of Hereford's financial situation has been exacerbated by falling gates, with the average attendance at Edgar Street in the 2013-14 season being little over half the average gate they attracted in League Two just five years ago.

The passage is about a football player named Milner, who played for Manchester City and England. He won 61 caps for the England senior team, debuting in 2009, and was a squad member at four major tournaments (two World Cups and two European Championships). However, he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps, which he earned from 2004. He scored his only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers. Milner has now left the England team, stating that his decision was based on common sense.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and early-music movement exponent, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. He was a founder member of the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and the Early Music Consort of London. In 1973, he established the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), serving as its director for over 30 years across six continents. The AAM produced more than 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. One of his most famous recordings, the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah, was named by BBC Music Magazine as one of the top 20 recordings of all time. Hogwood studied at Cambridge University and later at other institutions. He was a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University. He was also the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. His colleagues and students praised his generosity, intelligence, and contribution to histor

The passage describes a boy from Northern Ireland who requires special education due to unspecified needs. His family chose to remove him from mainstream schooling in June due to his inability to cope. They requested a place for him at a special school but are still waiting, as all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area are full. The family is concerned about the lack of available special school places and the potential impact on other families. The Education Authority is currently reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland and aims to ensure places are available closer to where children reside, with the goal of assisting with placements from 2016. The Education Authority cannot comment on individual cases due to privacy concerns. The boy's mother is worried about her son's isolation and the potential long-term impact on other families facing similar situations.

The passage discusses a takeover bid by the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) for the Newport Gwent Dragons, who share Rodney Parade with Newport County AFC. The lease for the ground, which includes primacy of fixtures for Newport County if they remain in the Football League, extends until 2023. Newport County is currently two points clear of League Two relegation and can secure survival with a win this weekend. The WRU's takeover of Newport Gwent Dragons will be voted on by shareholders on May 9, 2017. Both Newport County and the Newport Squash Club, also based at Rodney Parade, are protected under their current agreements. The WRU's plan to install an artificial surface at the stadium is against Football League rules. Relegation to the National League would be a significant setback for both the fans and the city of Newport.

The passage describes the life experiences of an unnamed individual from Sierra Leone, who was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels during the country's civil war in 1991. The individual was trained to use a gun and initiated into the group, with the RUF branding him with the letters RUF on his chest. The individual was forced to commit atrocities, including beatings and killings, under the influence of drugs such as marijuana and cocaine.

After escaping from the jungle and living alone in Freetown, the individual was caught and sent to jail. While in jail, he met a preacher named Richard Cole, who encouraged him to change his ways and become a leader in rebuilding the nation. After his release from jail, the individual joined a project called Lifeline Nehemiah, which provided hope and a home for people like him.

In 2014, during the Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone, the individual and others from the project developed a clinic to treat suspected Ebola cases. Through education, support, and collaboration with other agencies, they were able to save many lives

In September, a fundraising campaign was launched to prevent approximately 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from being auctioned to pay off a pottery firm's pension debt. The campaign was successful, and the collection will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund, which led the campaign, will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, where it will be loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The Wedgwood Museum inherited the pension bill from Waterford Wedgwood plc after the firm collapsed in 2009. The collection was at risk of being sold and scattered around the globe had the money not been raised. The collection is considered important for Staffordshire and plays a crucial role in defining Britain's cultural development over centuries.

Dan Groves has stated that the specific details of a potential deal where Wright might acquire 20% of Billericay football club are still undisclosed. The Sun has reported that Wright is expected to become a club director. Billericay is currently in the eighth position in the Isthmian League Premier Division, with a three-point deficit from a play-off spot. Wright, a former runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, has played non-league football for various clubs, including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. Glenn Tamplin, a multi-millionaire, recently took over the club and has expressed comfort in investing £10,000 per week. Billericay signed former England international Paul Konchesky, aged 35, at the start of March.

In the football match between Blackpool and Colchester United, the score ended 1-1. The first goal was scored by Jamille Matt for Blackpool after 12 minutes, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized after a goalmouth scramble from a corner kick. Both teams had chances to score, with Blackpool's Tom Aldred heading wide from a good position and Colchester's George Elokobi and Kurtis Guthrie having shots saved. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle. There were numerous fouls and injuries throughout the match.

The passage discusses the planned redevelopment of the disused Fawley Power Station, which closed in 2013 after more than 40 years of operation. The developers, Fawley Waterside, intend to make the power station's chimney, standing at 198 meters, the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard. The chimney will be the centerpiece of a "merchant city" development, estimated to cost £1bn, which will include a petal-shaped glass structure, a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The application for outline planning permission is due later this year, and construction could begin in 2018. The power station, commissioned in 1971, was capable of powering one million homes and was fueled by the nearby Esso refinery. The 300-acre site was sold to Fawley Waterside developers in 2016.

The passage describes the results of the Hong Kong championships for cycling. Ethan Hayter earned GB's second medal, a bronze, in the men's scratch race, chasing down Adrian Teklinski of Poland who won gold and Lucass Liss of Germany who got silver. In the men's team pursuit, GB was beaten by Italy for the bronze medal. In the women's team pursuit, GB finished fifth and failed to make the bronze-medal ride. Elinor Barker, an Olympic gold medallist, was part of the team but they were unable to compete for a medal. Joe Truman, the sole British rider in the men's keirin, was outclassed in his semi-final. Katy Marchant, an Olympic bronze medallist, was eliminated from the women's sprint in the first round. The passage also mentions the positive outlook of the young cyclists and the bright futures ahead of them, with four years until Tokyo.

The passage discusses the return of Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell in the soap opera EastEnders from 1990-1999 and again in 2005 and 2006, for a brief reunion with his character's family. This return is prompted by Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell, announcing her character's return to the show and revealing that her cancer has returned. Producers have revealed that Peggy will die from the disease in emotional scenes to be screened in the spring. Kemp stated that he was looking forward to going back to EastEnders and filming what are set to be some classic EastEnders episodes. Grant Mitchell is an iconic character in EastEnders' 30-year history, and this return will allow him to say goodbye to his mother and be reunited with his old loves, including his brother Phil, played by Steve McFadden.

Sadio Mane scored twice for Liverpool in a 2-1 win over second-placed Tottenham Hotspur at Anfield. The defeat was disappointing for Spurs, who have won just twice on the road since September, including losses at Chelsea and Manchester United. Spurs' manager, Mauricio Pochettino, expressed concern about his team's lack of desire and ability to cope with pressure, stating that if Chelsea win their upcoming game against Burnley, they could extend their lead at the top of the Premier League to 12 points, which would be a "big problem" for Spurs. Former Liverpool and Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy criticized Spurs' performance, noting their poor play against top-six teams and a lack of pace and a different mindset when playing away from home.

In the provided passage, the All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP lost key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, as well as Adamawa, one of the states affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC's victory has relegated the PDP to a regional party, with the APC doing well in the north and the south-west, while the PDP performed well only in the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, but overall were more peaceful than in previous years. The PDP will have to undergo a period of introspection and rebuild itself under a new leader, as voters felt it was

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will offer an augmented reality experience through an app. This feature will allow visitors to access online information from signs and posters on the site, including videos and band interviews. Notable acts for this year include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The festival organizers aim to provide this new feature to enhance the festival experience for attendees, while also allowing people worldwide to interact with the festival and experience its atmosphere. The app's content will be updated leading up to and during the event, allowing users to access information, buy tickets, and get a taste of the festival from anywhere.

The passage discusses the situation of several schools in Birmingham, England, that have been rated inadequate by Ofsted, the Office for Standards in Education, Children's Services and Skills. The schools in question are Park View, Nansen Primary, Oldknow Academy, and Golden Hillock School. The funding agreements for Park View and Nansen Primary will be terminated, and the Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running the schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School were warned they could lose funding unless concerns, such as less favorable treatment of non-Muslims, segregation of boys and girls, and a narrow curriculum, are addressed. The head teacher of one of the schools spoke about parents trying to undermine her authority during an Ofsted inspection. The passage also mentions a culture of fear and intimidation in Birmingham schools, as well as allegations of an organized campaign to target certain schools to impose a narrow, faith-based ideology. The schools have responded with various statements, some expressing a desire to challenge the Ofsted reports and improve their ratings. Parents have criticized the reports and accused inspectors of bias.

Vincent Barker, also known as Vinnie, passed away in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The eye specialist, Honey Rose, is on trial for gross negligence manslaughter, as her conduct during the test is alleged to have been so poor it was "criminal." The prosecution claims that Rose failed to detect swollen optic discs in Vinnie's eyes, which led to a build-up of fluid in his brain, increased pressure in his skull, and ultimately his death. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, a 42-year-old man, was found guilty of coercing a woman to engage in sexual activity and intercourse with another man between September 2013 and September 2014. He also intentionally caused the woman's sister and father to view sexual images and behaved in a threatening or abusive manner on Christmas Day 2014. The court heard that he had set up these meetings and filmed them. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and was found guilty following a trial at Dundee Sheriff Court. Due to the court's limited sentencing powers, the case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh. The judge, Lady Wolffe, stated that the sentence must reflect society's abhorrence of such conduct. Weatherhogg, a first-time offender, was assessed as posing a moderate risk of sexual re-offending.

In the T20 match in Greater Noida, Ireland scored 165-5 with notable contributions from Stuart Thompson (56), Gary Wilson (41 no), and captain William Porterfield (39). However, Afghanistan reached 171-4, winning by 6 runs with two overs remaining. The opening pair of Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47) led Afghanistan's charge. Amir Hamza was the only bowler to take more than one wicket, with 2-23. Ireland's early loss of opener Paul Stirling (duck) and the absence of paceman Boyd Rankin due to a back problem contributed to their defeat. Rankin is expected to return for the ODI series against Afghanistan, starting on 15 March.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the transfer of Neymar from Santos to Barcelona. Barcelona initially paid £48.6m for Neymar, but it has been alleged that the actual cost of the player was significantly higher due to additional fees such as signing-on fees, agents fees, and wages. This has led to investigations into the transfer, with Barcelona's president, Sandro Rosell, resigning and denying any wrongdoing.

Recently, Barcelona made a voluntary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to address potential tax-related issues related to Neymar's transfer. However, the club maintains that the original tax payment was in line with their fiscal obligations. The outcome of the investigation is not yet confirmed. Neymar has scored a total of 10 goals in 25 matches for Barcelona this season across both the league and Champions League.

The passage describes the discovery of the bodies of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge on a beach in Koh Tao, Thailand on September 15. Two Burmese suspects are being held by Thai police for the murders, rapes, and robberies of Miller and Witheridge. UK detectives have been working with Thai police, reviewing the investigation, and have now completed their work. They will return to the UK to compile a report and update the families of the victims on their findings. The suspects have confessed to the crimes and could face the death penalty if found guilty. However, there have been concerns about the police investigation, including the verification of DNA samples and allegations of mistreatment of the suspects. The UK police visit was arranged after a meeting between the Thai Prime Minister and British Prime Minister. Post-mortem examinations found that Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Witheridge died from head wounds. DNA found on Witheridge matched samples taken from the suspects.

The Scots are currently leading their qualifying group for a major soccer competition, with five wins in five matches. They are set to play Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, with a victory securing a near-guarantee of their place in the finals. Iceland, ranked one place above the Scots, are also unbeaten and the outcome of the match and the return fixture in Reykjavik on 20 September will likely decide who tops the group. The Scots have 12 players in their squad who play outside Scotland, including Bayern Munich forward Jane Ross, who recently won the women's Bundesliga in her first season at the club. Ross believes playing in top leagues benefits the national team as they close in on a first major finals.

The passage discusses a security issue involving third-party software being used to steal intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud. Apple has introduced a two-step verification system to prevent such infiltrations, which requires an extra step after a user types their username and password into a device they haven't used before. This includes entering a four-digit code sent via text or Apple's Find My iPhone app. However, this security measure is an opt-in choice. Experts suggest that Apple should make it the default option.

The two-step verification system was previously not active when users used iCloud's back-up service, allowing hackers to download a complete back-up of data even with the two-step feature enabled. A software called Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, often used by hackers, has been discussed in hacker forums. Apple's recent changes have made the technique used by this software ineffective.

The passage also mentions concerns about the recovery key, which is used to regain access to the account if the trusted device is lost or stolen. There's a risk of losing the recovery key or it being stolen, which could

In the provided passage, the core pieces of information are campaign expenditures for several political parties in the UK's May election for the European Parliament. UKIP spent the most at £2,956,737, followed by the Conservatives at £2,980,815, Labour at £1,027,339, Lib Dems at £1,580,575, and the Green Party at £534,249. The Lib Dems lost all but one of their MEPs, while Labour came second. The spending per vote for each party was UKIP at 68p, Labour at 26p, Conservatives at 79p, Lib Dems at £1.45, and the Green Party at 43p. The six highest-spending parties collectively spent £9,347,087 on campaigning, and all but Labour spent more than they did during the 2009 European election campaign.

In the provided passage, two football transfers are discussed. Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has mutually terminated his contract with Barrow and is joining their National League rivals. He has previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. Anderson could potentially play against his old club on February 18. The second transfer involves striker Keating, a 21-year-old recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Keating's move is subject to international clearance. Nicholson describes Keating as a leader-type he has been seeking, while Keating is described as young, raw, but hungry to prove himself. The Gulls, currently four points above the relegation zone, have won only one of their last six games. The passage also mentions a dedicated page for all the latest football transfers.

The passage describes an incident at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day where the Irish-bred horse Many Clouds, aged 10 and previously known for winning the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, collapsed and died after narrowly beating Thistlecrack in the Cotswold Chase. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage". Despite being rare, the BHA is determined to understand what causes such symptoms and whether more can be done to prevent it. Many Clouds had shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, but not on the day of the race in question. The passage also mentions that Many Clouds had a history of overheating, but no significant underlying health issues. The report concludes that Many Clouds was the victim of a haemorrhage rarely seen on the racetrack, and questions have been raised as to whether his overheating condition was linked to his death, but this report does not provide a definitive answer.

The passage describes the farewell speeches of three MSPs (Members of the Scottish Parliament) who are stepping down ahead of the election on May 5th: Tricia Marwick, Alex Salmond, and Duncan McNeil.

Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, shed tears during the speeches of both Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond. Alex Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, repeated his belief that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse" in his valedictory address. He welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill but criticized it for not fulfilling the pledges made by unionist politicians during the referendum campaign.

Duncan McNeil, a Scottish Labour backbencher, warned that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly with regard to the committee system. He expressed concern about accountability and scrutiny in the parliament and urged the new MSPs to meet the challenge or face the consequences.

Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, also announced her departure from Holyrood. In

The passage describes a live-action remake of the Disney film "Beauty and the Beast." Emma Watson has been cast as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, the father of Belle, and Harry Potter star Emma Thompson will play Mrs. Potts, the teapot character voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version. Josh Gad will voice Gaston's sidekick LeFou. The film is set to be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017 and will begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May, with Bill Condon directing.

The passage discusses an upcoming meeting by the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) with relatives of the 96 football fans who were fatally injured in the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster in Sheffield. Last year, new inquests concluded that the fans were unlawfully killed. In January, files of evidence relating to 23 suspects were referred to the CPS to decide whether charges should be brought, with 15 cases related to the investigation into the causes of the disaster and the other 8 related to the conduct of South Yorkshire Police and West Midlands Police in the days and weeks following the disaster. The families will be informed of the CPS's decisions at a private meeting in Warrington, and Margaret Aspinall, chairwoman of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, has expressed anticipation and mixed emotions about the meeting, stating that the families are determined to never give up and seek accountability.

The passage discusses the issue of contraband, specifically mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, being frequently smuggled into Chelmsford Prison. This is evidenced by numerous packages being thrown over the prison walls and witnessed by residents living near the prison. The prison authorities have acknowledged these incidents and are working to prevent such occurrences. The Justice Secretary has also asked for measures to ensure prisons have the necessary tools to combat this issue. A local resident has reported witnessing packages being thrown over the wall four times in two weeks. The Ministry of Justice has stated that there is no evidence of drones being used to smuggle contraband into the Chelmsford site. Additionally, the Ministry has introduced laws that could imprison individuals who smuggle packages over prison walls for up to two years.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being hit by Brian Wright's VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. The incident occurred when Mrs. Blackburn was on duty, helping a woman and her six-year-old daughter cross the road as the traffic lights turned red. Wright, who is 55 and from Kempston, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light. He has admitted striking Mrs. Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The trial is ongoing, with Wright expressing remorse for his actions and their impact on Mrs. Blackburn and her family.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner from Scotland, finished 4th and 6th in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. Due to her veterinary medicine studies and exams in May, she will not be able to participate in the Commonwealth Games in April 2022. She is disappointed about missing the event but prioritizes her education. Muir aims to compete in at least two more Olympics and considers the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target. She recently set a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships in London.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old man from County Kildare, went missing in December 2000 after a Christmas party. A search for potential evidence in his disappearance has started at a three-acre site in Chapelizod, Dublin. The search, which involves excavations and is expected to take several weeks, was prompted by a review of Deely's case conducted by a team of six detectives earlier this year. CCTV footage from the night of his disappearance shows Deely talking to a man in black outside his workplace, the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street. Deely was returning to get an umbrella after the party. The man seen in the CCTV has not yet been identified, and the appeal for him to come forward has been renewed by gardaí.

Juan Martin Del Potro, ranked 165th due to injury issues, won a challenging match against Stan Wawrinka (3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3) at Wimbledon. Del Potro, who reached the semi-finals in 2013, is in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray. He will face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young next. Del Potro had three wrist operations and this is his first Grand Slam since the Australian Open in 2014.

Nick Kyrgios, ranked 15th, also advanced in the same half of the draw as Murray. He came back from two sets to one down to beat Dustin Brown (6-7 (3-7) 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4) in a rain-affected match. Kyrgios will face Spanish 22nd seed Feliciano Lopez in the third round, with the winner potentially facing Murray or John Millman in the last 16.

Tunisia was at risk of expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints lodged against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) following a contentious penalty call in the 2015 tournament. However, they apologized to Caf and were allowed to participate. Morocco, on the other hand, was initially banned from participating in the 2017 qualifying draw due to issues related to the 2015 tournament, but the ban was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas). Both Tunisia and Morocco are now preparing for the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations, with Tunisia aiming to set a record of 13 consecutive appearances in the tournament.

The passage discusses the history and current state of McLaren, a Formula 1 team that has achieved significant success in the past, including 12 drivers' world championships, 8 constructors' titles, and 182 grand prix wins. However, the team is currently experiencing a slump, with their best possible grid position being the third row and their focus on decent points. The team's struggles are primarily due to issues with the Honda power-unit.

The team's current predicament is a cycle of triumph and decline that has been a part of McLaren's F1 history since its establishment. The team's first decade was spent building up the team into an increasingly powerful force, with their maiden title coming in 1974. They experienced another period of dominance in the 1980s, particularly with the partnership with Honda, but have since had periods of decline.

The team's current struggles began in 2013, and they are currently led by two world champions, Fernando Alonso and Lewis Hamilton. Alonso returned to the team in 2015 partly because he felt the renew

The passage describes an incident at Joe's Bar in Dungiven, where paramedics were called for a sudden death at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police arrived later and found people still at the bar, with till receipts showing alcohol was served as late as 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered closed for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas, both from the same address, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The court was told that the licensing laws in Dungiven were not strictly adhered to, and the premises had been running well into the morning. Ms O'Neill, who has an "appalling record," was fined £3,000, while Mr Thomas was fined £1,000. The judge expressed concern about not having the power to impose a custodial sentence.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA three-point record by scoring eight three-pointers in a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers, rallying the Golden State Warriors. Curry entered the game four shy of his previous record of 272 three-pointers, set two years ago. Klay Thompson also contributed with 26 points, helping the Warriors avoid a three-game losing streak.

In a separate game, the Chicago Bulls dealt a significant blow to Miami's playoff hopes by coming back from a 19-point halftime deficit to win 89-78. Pau Gasol had 16 points and 15 rebounds, and Derrick Rose scored 12 points in his comeback from injury. The Bulls were outscored 33-12 in the second quarter but responded with a 39-8 run in the second half. Miami struggled offensively, missing their first 12 shots after halftime and being outscored 57-27 in the second half. Hassan Whiteside had 19 points and

In the provided passage, it is detailed that four Liverpool football players, Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic, had an unexpected encounter with YouTube star Bas van Velzen at their training ground, Melwood. The Liverpool players were led to believe that van Velzen was a competition winner who would meet them and receive a dead-ball masterclass. However, it quickly became apparent that van Velzen was not an ordinary fan, as he showcased his impressive free-kick skills during the session.

Van Velzen, who has gained YouTube fame by uploading videos of his free-kick exploits, impressed the Liverpool quartet with his skills. Balotelli even managed to score a free-kick of his own, which he was pleased with. Van Velzen expressed his delight at meeting the players and pretending to be bad at free-kicks, finding it satisfying to see the players' reactions when he shot.

In a final surprise, van Velzen revealed Balotelli's infamous slogan, a reference to an incident during Balotelli's time at Manchester City. Overall, the experience was enjoyable for

he passage discusses a study that suggests women diagnosed with breast cancer due to carrying the BRCA1 gene, like Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of death by having their ovaries removed. The procedure, known as an oophorectomy, was associated with a 62% reduction in breast cancer death in women with a BRCA1 mutation, but this was not observed in those with a BRCA2 mutation. The study found a 65% reduction in death from all causes associated with oophorectomy. The protective effect of oophorectomy against breast cancer was apparent immediately after diagnosis and lasted for 15 years. The authors of the study suggest that oophorectomy should be considered as part of the treatment discussion for women with early-stage breast cancers who carry the BRCA mutation. The passage also mentions that women who inherit the faulty BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes have a 50 to 80% chance of developing breast cancer during their lifetime, and genetic tests are available for women who are likely to have a mutation. The BRCA gene faults are more common in the Ashkenazi Jewish population

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were killed by an Amtrak train (Train No. 80, the Carolinian) in Durham, North Carolina, on Easter Sunday morning. The accident occurred on property owned by Norfolk-Southern. None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, although a man who fell ill during the delay did receive treatment. The couple may have been homeless, as a man who met them while collecting scrap metal suggested they lived in a homeless camp. The train continued its journey after a delay of about 2 hours and 45 minutes. Durham is approximately 25 miles northwest of the train's next destination, Raleigh. The trip from Charlotte to New York City usually takes about 13 hours and 30 minutes.

arlos Toro, a 66-year-old former member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s due to a confrontation with his boss. He provided valuable information about his former bosses and associates, including Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega, and was one of the DEA's most important assets. However, despite being promised US citizenship for his work, Toro is now facing deportation after declining health forced him to retire. He is currently living in the US illegally and is in limbo while trying to obtain a green card or a passport. Toro's fears of deportation are reasonable considering his work aided in the prosecution of cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. DEA agent Mike McManus, who was Toro's handler for two years, has spoken out in support of Toro and criticized the government's handling of his case.

The passage discusses the issue of a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., using the new top-level domain name '.sucks' to extract high fees from celebrities and companies, such as Kevin Spacey, YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, Yahoo, and Telus Mobility, to remove their names from the domain. The U.S. body that regulates internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating whether the actions of Vox Populi are illegal. The company initially charged $2,499 a year for the privilege, but will offer consumers the right to secure a '.sucks' address for $10 a year starting in September. The advisory body has called the practice a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory." Kevin Spacey is among the celebrities who have reportedly paid to have their names removed from the domain.

A mother was arrested 27 years after the body of her stillborn baby was found in a pond in 1988. The body was exhumed last year during a case review, and DNA samples led police to the mother. She was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but the charge was dropped after she explained the baby had been stillborn and she had concealed the pregnancy. The baby was reburied at Weasenham St Peter Church, Norfolk, with a new headstone. The police are now satisfied that nobody else was involved, and the woman remains on bail while the CPS decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The case remained unsolved for 27 years, but advances in DNA technology helped solve the mystery. A support group for parents of stillborn children paid for the new headstone.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to passenger Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of a moving taxi driven by Young. The incident occurred five years ago in Bath, Somerset, when Young mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to avoid paying the fare and decided to drive him back to the taxi rank to teach him a lesson. When Hicks objected, Young continued driving for almost a mile, leading Hicks to jump from the vehicle while it was traveling at more than 20mph. Hicks suffered devastating brain injuries, developed epilepsy, and now requires round-the-clock care from his mother. The judge ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, and while the exact amount of compensation is yet to be decided, it is set to be around 50% of what the family had requested. The judge also awarded Hicks an additional £250 for unlawful imprisonment. Hicks, who is now 27, was with his girlfriend Abigail Noad at the time of the incident. Lawyers representing Hicks stated that he has undergone extensive treatment and rehabilitation but has developed post

On Wednesday night, several storms in Kansas brought reports of tornadoes, with one spotted about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, posing potential risks to other communities. Nighttime tornadoes were reported as the most deadly and dangerous. Other tornado reports came from Southwestern Kansas. Additionally, a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis, causing wind damage, flooding, and fallen trees. A Twitter user in Farmington reported hail the size of baseballs. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

uke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to clash in a middleweight fight in New Jersey. Rockhold, who is aiming for his fourth consecutive victory since losing to Vitor Belfort two years ago, plans to dominate Machida by being the aggressor, cutting off Machida's movements, and making him fight on Rockhold's terms. Rockhold believes he has identified weaknesses in Machida's game and is confident in his mixed martial arts skills. Machida, on the other hand, is confident he can upset Rockhold and earn a title shot. Both fighters have recently won their respective fights, with Rockhold's last victory against Michael Bisping in November 2015 and Machida's against CB Dollaway in Brazil. Machida is also confident in his preparation for the fight, having had eight weeks of training camp with several other fighters.

A light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar plane, made an emergency landing at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, without deploying its landing gear. The plane skidded along the runway on its belly, causing damage to the propellers and the undercarriage. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, aged 85, managed to take off again and fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely. The incident was caused by human error, as the pilot forgot to deploy the landing gear before touchdown. The FAA is investigating the incident.

n the provided passage, Manchester City midfielder Yaya Toure has been underperforming this season, leading to criticism from manager Manuel Pellegrini. Despite this, Pellegrini has vowed to support Toure until the end of the season. It is also revealed that Manchester City will listen to offers for Toure in the summer. Manchester City is currently facing a faltering campaign and is in fifth place, with captain Vincent Kompany likely to miss the rest of the season due to a muscle injury. City goalkeeper Joe Hart has admitted that the players have underperformed and let Pellegrini down. Meanwhile, West Ham left back Aaron Cresswell is attracting interest from Manchester City and Chelsea, with Sam Allardyce warning Cresswell not to make the same mistake as other English players who moved to City and did not play a significant role.

Domenico Rancadore, known as the 'Godfather of Uxbridge' and a Sicilian mafia fugitive, will be allowed to remain in the UK after his seven-year sentence for being a member of the Cosa Nostra, handed down in 1999, was dropped. Rancadore's conviction remains intact, but Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed. The case will still have to be heard by the Italian Supreme Court. Rancadore's solicitor, Karen Todner, stated that the Italian court of appeal agreed to extinguish Rancadore's conviction due to its age and that the Italian government will withdraw their application for a European arrest warrant. The matter will be dealt with in court, and Rancadore does not have to be present. Rancadore was first arrested on a European arrest warrant in 2013 and spent two decades living under the name Marc Skinner in Uxbridge, London. There was an angry reaction from legal experts regarding the amount of time and money spent on Rancad

The passage discusses the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. The three 7-2 co-favorites for this race are Mr Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, Irish raider Special Tiara, and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre. Mr Mole will be ridden by AP McCoy, who will have six rivals in the race. This will be AP McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race. His final book of rides for his last day as a professional jockey will not be finalized until Friday morning. Mr Mole was the horse AP McCoy rode to victory at Newbury in February, and it was after this win that he announced his intention to retire from racing. Other runners in the Celebration Chase include Mick Channon's Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, whose daughter Marcia was murdered in 1975, recently chose to view crime scene photos of her daughter's body after decades of refusal. Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett, and her body was found 33 days after she disappeared. Ritter's then-husband advised against seeing the body and photos, but Ritter persisted and viewed them last year. The photos showed Marcia's body with signs of strangulation, sexual assault, and physical trauma. Ritter expressed anger and a desire for revenge upon seeing the photos. Jerome Sydney Barrett was convicted of second-degree murder for Marcia's death in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison.

ory McIlroy, the world number one golfer, aims to win the Masters to complete the career grand slam, joining an elite group of six players who have achieved this feat. He considers winning the Masters as a career-long goal and believes it is "unthinkable" not to win it at some point. McIlroy has had one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, but he is hoping to win his first green jacket this year. He has previously experienced a collapse in the final round of the Masters in 2011, which he considers the most important day of his career as it taught him valuable lessons about himself and his game. McIlroy is set to tee off at the Arnold Palmer Invitational Golf Tournament on March 19. Despite the distractions of calling off his wedding and a legal dispute, McIlroy had an extraordinary successful year in 2014, winning multiple majors. He hopes to use the golf course as his "sanctuary" from the pressure and hype surrounding the Masters.

The passage discusses several trending stories from the past week. A notable rainbow sighting occurred in the New York area, captured by Amanda Curtis, CEO of a fashion company. In rural China, the practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes is becoming common, but is now under scrutiny due to a crackdown on vice. Robert Downey Jr. (RDJ) became agitated during an interview about his personal life. A new trend, lip plumping, has emerged, with people attempting to resemble Kylie Jenner by sucking on jars. Ewan McGregor will play Lumiere in the upcoming movie "Beauty and the Beast," and Johnny Depp is nearly unrecognizable in the trailer for "Black Mass." Unique pregnancy and military dad photobomb announcements also trended this week.

The passage discusses the issue of Foetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) in the UK. According to the Official Health and Social Care Information Centre, 272 children were hospitalized due to FAS over the past 12 months. However, experts warn that the actual number could be much higher. The World Health Organization's research suggests that about 7,500 babies in the UK could suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure in the womb.

One example of a child affected by FAS is 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who requires assistance with daily activities, has no sense of danger, and will never be able to live independently. She was diagnosed with FAS at the age of five, after her adoptive parents noticed her struggles at playschool.

The passage also mentions other medical issues associated with alcohol consumption during pregnancy, such as problems with the liver, kidneys, heart, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. A axe-wielding robber named Shaun Andrew McKerry, known as Boomerang Boy or Homing Pigeon Boy in his youth, attempted to rob a store in Shildon, County Durham, at 8 PM on March 15. He burst into the post office and stores, demanding cash from the assistant, Andrea Brighty, while wearing a mask and wielding an axe. The shop owner, Sab Dhillon, tackled the robber, causing him to fall to the floor and sending shelves and produce tumbling. During the struggle, Sab Dhillon's wife Sam hit McKerry with a baseball bat twice, helping to disarm him and reveal his face to the cameras. The police arrived and arrested McKerry, who was later sentenced to six years in jail for attempted robbery. McKerry has a history of criminal activity, including shoplifting at the age of 12, and has been arrested over 100 times for various offenses such as aggravated vehicle-taking, sending indecent letters, and burglary. Four Royal Navy sailors, Joshua Finbow (23), Simon Radford (31), Craig Stoner (24), and Darren Smalley (35), charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a Canadian barracks, must remain in Nova Scotia until their trial. They appeared in court in Dartmouth, near Halifax, where they were given unusual bail conditions, including surrendering their passports and living at the Stadacona Naval Base in Halifax. The alleged sexual assault took place on April 10 after the sailors had returned to the barracks from a hockey game. The four men had been playing for the Royal Navy ice hockey team in a tournament at the Shearwater Naval Base. They were ordered to return to court on May 27 and must not leave Nova Scotia or apply for new passports. They must remain employed by the navy and must not resign without the court's permission. The four are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, offenses that are punishable by up to 14 years in prison. The investigation is still at an early stage, and the results of forensic tests

he passage describes the story of a mother, Valerie Jackson, whose four-year-old son, RJ Jackson, suffers from a rare skin disease called Netherton's Syndrome. This condition makes his skin appear red and scaly. Valerie has to regularly apply creams to RJ's skin to prevent it from drying out. Unfortunately, due to the appearance of RJ's skin, they have faced accusations of child abuse and taunts from strangers. RJ has also been targeted by bullies, both children and adults. The passage highlights the ignorance and misunderstanding of this rare condition, which affects one in 200,000 births in the UK. The family has found support through a Facebook group for Netherton's Syndrome. Despite the challenges, Valerie sees RJ as a beautiful little boy.

he passage discusses a controversy surrounding a Protein World advertising campaign featuring a bikini-clad model with the slogan "Are you beach body ready?". The advertisements have been placed on the London Underground and have received significant backlash from feminists, body image campaigners, and social media users who find the campaign offensive, unrealistic, and sexist. The advertisements have been defaced, and a Change.org petition calling for their removal has gathered over 50,000 signatures.

Transport for London (TFL) has confirmed that the posters will be removed because they have come to the end of the three-week advertising period that Protein World paid for. TFL has also received over 200 complaints from people saying that the adverts promote an unhealthy body image. Protein World has defended the campaign, claiming that the image is unphotoshopped and that the campaign is targeted at health-conscious individuals looking to get fit in time for summer.

The controversy has also attracted the attention of TV personalities such as Susanna Reid, who described the campaign as "anxiety-inducing" during

In the provided passage, it is stated that rail firms are planning to increase fares by up to 87% just ten days after the general election, despite promises from main party leaders to freeze prices. The prime minister, David Cameron, has personally intervened and written to First Great Western to request an urgent review of its decision to almost double fares on the route between London and the Cotswolds, which passes through his Witney constituency. Other significant fare hikes are planned by train companies, including a 24.5% increase on the cost of an anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool, and a 22% increase on an anytime first-class day return on Virgin from Manchester to Stoke. However, Virgin defends these increases by stating that the majority of the price hikes affected "Virgin trains-only fares," which are at least 20% cheaper than tickets offered by rival firms.

A former soldier, John Young, aged 66, has been left blind in one eye after being hit with a brick thrown through his front door in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The attack occurred while he was at home with his wife Elaine, 54, who also works for the Alzheimer's Society charity. The couple had been married for just three weeks and were writing thank-you cards for their wedding gifts when their home was targeted by yobs at around 11 pm on April 18. The police have launched an investigation into the attack, but there appears to be no known motive, and it could be a case of yobs "messing around." John and Elaine are moving to a flat in Southport due to feeling unsafe in their Oldham neighborhood. The police are urging anyone with information about the incident to contact them immediately.

om Poynton, a 25-year-old wicketkeeper for Derbyshire, has signed a one-year contract extension after successfully returning from leg injuries sustained in a road accident that claimed the life of his father, Keith, in April 2014. Poynton underwent an ankle operation and made his playing comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Derbyshire's Elite Performance Director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's resilience and hard work, expressing delight at his return to the field. The new contract is expected to boost Poynton's confidence and he will be available for the start of the 2015 season, committing himself to Derbyshire until the end of the 2016 season.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw, from Stretford, battled an aggressive form of cancer (neuroblastoma) for a year and was recently given the all-clear by doctors. The cancer affected his kidney, lungs, bones, and neck. During his treatment, Harley wore a superhero mask, which he helped decorate like a ninja turtle, to help him feel stronger and brave. His story made headlines worldwide, and he received a box of ninja turtle presents from Nickelodeon for Christmas. Harley underwent 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, an operation to remove his kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy at the Christie Clinic in Manchester. He is now cancer-free but will undergo regular check-ups to ensure he stays that way. Harley's family is overjoyed and looking forward to the future. Neuroblastoma is a rare and aggressive childhood cancer that affects fewer than 100 children in the UK each year, most of whom are younger than five years old. The passage discusses the advice given by Aston Villa manager Tim Sherwood to Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old player who starred in Villa's FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool. Sherwood suggests that Grealish should focus on his club career rather than his international future, as he is currently the center of a tug-of-war between the Republic of Ireland and England. Grealish has impressed Sherwood and is expected to choose between the two countries at the end of the season. Grealish's father, Kevin, also agrees that his son should prioritize his club football first. The passage also mentions that Grealish is confident and skilled on the field, and that the more opportunities he gets, the better he will become.

The passage discusses the issue of landing fees at airports for private jet travelers, a concern that is not typically encountered by average travelers. These fees can vary significantly, with some unexpectedly popular transport hubs for the rich and famous charging high fees. Examples include Salzburg in Austria and Darwin in Australia. The luxury of owning a private jet is only affordable by the wealthy, and continuous payment of landing charges, which can reach thousands, is required. The private jet industry is worth $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe. The busiest weekends often occur during major sporting events, such as the Super Bowl in America and the Monaco Grand Prix. Private jet companies like Privatefly estimate costs for a round-trip from New York to Glendale for the Super Bowl this year at around $38,000 on a medium jet and $54,000 on a long-range jet. The passage also provides a list of the most expensive airports for landing fees, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo, Japan being the most expensive at £4,559 ($6,850). Other expensive airports

The passage describes an incident where Katie Gallegos, a dog resort owner from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her dogs Cooper and Daisy to a McDonald's drive-thru for an ice cream treat. While Daisy took a few licks, Cooper quickly devoured the entire ice cream cone in one bite. The video of this incident has been viewed over seven million times. Some viewers criticized Gallegos for feeding her dogs ice cream, but she defended her actions, stating that Cooper is in good health and enjoys these treats as a weekly routine. Daisy, being smaller, only gets a few licks due to her size. Another video shows the dogs visiting a Starbucks for a "pup-uccino," with Cooper again consuming the entire beverage in one gulp. Gallegos clarified that the beverage does not contain coffee and is just a dollop of whipped cream in a cup. It is implied that Cooper and Daisy have a fondness for fast food.

Gary Locke, the former Hearts boss, has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock after a successful interim period. He joined Kilmarnock as assistant boss to Allan Johnson last summer but took over when Johnson resigned in February. Locke has lost only once in seven games since taking charge at Rugby Park, and he will speak at a press conference on Friday morning after signing a three-year deal with the club.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp from Eustis, has accused Seminole County Elementary School of threatening to suspend her autistic five-year-old son, Logan, due to essential oils he uses to manage his illness. The oils, manufactured by Doterra, are applied by Kemp on Logan's head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. Teachers and a teacher's aide complained about the oils' smell and distraction to other students. Kemp received a letter from the school board stating the oils created a problem for staff and students. Despite the threat of punishment, Kemp intends to continue using the oils, claiming they have a positive impact on her son. The Lake County School District has since stated they will not suspend Logan, citing it as a health issue. Doterra, the company that produces the oils, has scents such as lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton, known as the Sandpiper Complex, was destroyed by a severe and intense fire on Wednesday afternoon. The fire spread through 90 condos, causing them to collapse. The cause of the fire is currently unknown, but it was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the fire, but were unable to enter any of the summer homes. The building manager, Rob Taber, who lived and worked in the complex, lost everything. The fire is currently being investigated, with claims that it may have started near a car parked by the complex. The Sandpiper Complex is used as a holiday home by residents between May and November.

The passage describes Queen Elizabeth II, who is 88 years old, enjoying a ride on her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. The queen has been riding horses since she was four and has a long-standing love for equines. She has been encouraged to wear a riding helmet for safety but prefers a silk scarf instead due to her hair. The queen has ridden less in recent years due to a knee injury but remains an enthusiastic equestrienne. The passage also provides information about the history and characteristics of fell ponies, which the queen breeds at Hampton Court. These ponies have been around since the Neolithic period and were used by various invaders, including the Romans and Vikings, as pack ponies. Today, they are a popular choice for riders of all ages, with the queen being one of the breeders.

A neighbor dispute over noise levels in Brisbane escalated into a tragic incident, resulting in the death of a 55-year-old man, Leon Yeaman. The alleged perpetrator, 28-year-old Philip Pama, was charged with manslaughter after he reportedly punched Yeaman during an argument. Pama, a married father of three who works a 3 am shift at a nearby warehouse, was sleeping at the time of the commotion. Yeaman was known for getting drunk, playing loud music, and yelling at people. Pama confronted Yeaman, and during the confrontation, Pama allegedly hit Yeaman, who was later pronounced dead at the scene. Pama was granted conditional bail, with conditions including surrendering his passport, adhering to a curfew, and reporting to the local police station twice a week. Pama's defense lawyer stated that Pama was being pushed at the same time he threw the punch and did not see it connect. The case is due to return to court on May 18.
