The Heritage Lottery Fund (HLF) is contributing £18.8m towards the project, while Haringey Council is contributing £6.8m. The entire east wing will be refurbished at a cost of £26.6m, with the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust committing to raising the final £1m by summer 2017. The theatre still retains much of its original decor and stage machinery, and was originally designed to showcase opera, musicals, plays, and early cinema screenings.

The passage is about a former Manchester City player, aged 30, named Milner. He has represented England in 61 senior matches, starting from 2009, and was part of the squad for two World Cups and two European Championships. However, he only played for 3 minutes during Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, which he earned from 2004. He scored his only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers. Milner has announced his decision to step away from the England team, wishing success for the team, staff, and supporters in the future.

Marcy Smith and her family, including her son David, were awakened by a house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador. The house was completely destroyed, and their pets did not survive. The fire was started by rubbish burned in the wood stove, an action Mrs. Smith had done before without incident. The fire alarm did not go off. The family escaped with only their pyjamas, but the community has provided them with clothing, shoes, and a bike for David. Mrs. Smith credits David for their survival, as he was the only one awake and alerted the family to the fire. She is proud of her son for his quick actions.

The energy drinks giant is considering a £200m offer for West Ham United, a Premier League football club. Sullivan and Gold bought a majority stake in West Ham in 2010 for £105m and currently own over 85% of the club. There have been previous takeover links from Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan mentioned last year that a minority shareholding could be sold to clear debts, but they intend for the ownership to be passed on to their children.

The passage describes an awards ceremony, not the Oscars, held in Los Angeles. The fan-voted awards included categories like best kiss, best shirtless performance, and best movie. The Fault in Our Stars won best movie, and its star Shailene Woodley won best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Other winners included Bradley Cooper for best male performance, Channing Tatum for best comedic performance, Meryl Streep for best villain, and Kevin Hart for the comedic genius award. Robert Downey Jr won the Generation Award, and clips from upcoming summer releases like Pitch Perfect 2, Judd Apatow's Trainwreck, and Marvel's Avengers: Age of Ultron were shown.

In the provided passage, it is stated that Cameron Smith, a 21-year-old football player who has scored five goals this season while on loan from Dundee United to United, previously made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 and scored four times in 89 appearances for the Pittodrie side. Jack Ross, the boss of St Mirren, a Championship bottom side, has expressed his excitement about Smith joining their team, referring to him as a "really good player" and a "good, mature boy" who will provide another option in the attacking area. The passage concludes with the information that St Mirren will host Falkirk on Saturday.

The passage discusses a plan by Northumberland County Council to address pothole issues in the county. They aim to fill approximately 145 potholes daily for the next four months, using their Jetpatcher machines. Additionally, extra staff will be deployed to repair damaged drainage systems and clear debris from gutters, likely in response to heavy rain.

The passage describes an incident that occurred on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland in December 2016. Six workers, employed by Wood Group under a contract with EnQuest, were exposed to low levels of Naturally Occurring Radioactive Material (NORM) while removing pipework. The workers were not wearing proper Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) at the time. EnQuest and Wood Group have since taken additional precautionary steps to prevent further exposure. The workers are undergoing ongoing blood tests due to cancer fears. Rigging supervisor Steve Innes claims EnQuest failed in its duty of care and has struggled to find work since raising concerns. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) was made aware of the incident but no investigation was carried out as it was not reportable under the current RIDDOR system and no staff raised the issue with HSE separately. The Unite union believes the workers have been treated poorly and calls for openness and transparency about safety incidents to create a safer working environment offshore.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 (£420,000) from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The dealer was later found guilty of trafficking antiquities and selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the bronze sculpture. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. The decision to return the sculpture was made after discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Indian government body looking after its antiquities, the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). The ASI submitted an official request for the return of the sculpture in May. The ACM is taking legal action to seek compensation for the apparent fraud. The museum also bought 29 other objects from the art dealer, although none of the others are thought to be listed as stolen. The ASI was reportedly allowed to view them.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake occurred in Garfagnana, Italy, 35km north of Lucca, at a depth of 15.5km. The quake was felt in cities such as Milan, Florence, and Milan, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or significant damage. The area is prone to earthquakes, with a previous incident in May 2021 causing over 20 deaths. The quake struck at 15:48 GMT and was followed by several aftershocks. Power supplies were cut, phone lines were down, and schools were evacuated in the Garfagnana area as a precaution. The earthquake was described as "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow" by Alessandro Amato of the National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology (INGV). Italy is still recovering from the aftermath of the 2009 earthquake in L'Aquila, where six scientists and an ex-official were convicted of multiple manslaughter for providing false reassurances about the danger of the tremors before the deadly quake.

A 62-year-old man named Austin Grant from Sheffield, South Yorkshire, has successfully grown avocados in his garden. Despite initial doubts about the climate suitability, he has finally seen some results. The avocados are still attached to the plant and are not yet ripe enough to eat. Austin was overjoyed upon seeing the fruits.

The passage discusses the delay of the release of Grand Theft Auto V from 27 January to 24 March due to testing and polishing needs. Rockstar assures that this delay is in the best interest of the game and fans. The company also announced that online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release. Screenshots of the PC version have been released, promising improved visuals with 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and support for up to triple monitor configurations. While waiting for the game, PC users can ensure their systems meet the minimum requirements. GTA V holds the record for the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, generating $1bn in revenue in just three days upon its initial release in 2013.

The passage describes the 76-year-old artist, Malcolm Simpson, winning the John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)" at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. The painting depicts a leper squint, a hole in medieval churches for the undesirable to observe services. Simpson has been a shortlisted artist for the prize on multiple occasions and said winning was "very nice indeed." Judge Ansel Krut praised the painting as "quite extraordinary" and a "tone poem." The painting is about 7ft in height and Simpson entered it into the competition because of its size and familiarity. He plans to use the prize money of £25,000 on art supplies such as canvas, stretches, and paints. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig. Sir Peter Blake, now the prize's patron, won the junior title in 1961.

Two pro-government newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, in Istanbul, Turkey, were attacked simultaneously in the early hours of Thursday. The attacks involved gunfire, resulting in damaged windows and numerous spent bullet casings at both scenes. No casualties were reported. The police are currently investigating and have cordoned off the areas around the buildings. Neither attack has been claimed by any group as of yet. This incident follows a similar attack on the daily Hurriyet's offices last September, where pro-government protesters accused the paper of misquoting President Erdogan.

A 24-year-old footballer, who was previously under contract with the Stags, has agreed to join Marcus Bignot's team, the Mariners, on a free transfer starting from 1 January. He spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances. This will be Bignot's first signing for the Mariners, and he previously played for Burton.

The passage discusses two main topics: Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger's comments on England manager candidate, Gareth Southgate, and Wenger's plans for Arsenal defender Hector Bellerin.

1. Arsene Wenger, whose contract with Arsenal runs until the summer, has been linked with the England manager position. Current England manager Gareth Southgate, who took over from Sam Allardyce in September, is seeking a permanent position after overseeing England's 2-0 win against Malta and a 0-0 draw with Slovenia. Wenger praised Southgate's experience and competency, stating that he should prove his worth through his decisions. Southgate has upcoming World Cup qualifiers against Scotland and a friendly against Spain to impress the Football Association.

2. Regarding Arsenal, Wenger announced that 21-year-old defender Hector Bellerin will be offered a new contract. Despite interest from Barcelona and Manchester City, Wenger expressed his desire for Bellerin to stay at Arsenal long-term. Additionally, Wenger mentioned that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss "one

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. The incident is being jointly investigated by Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive. The company is cooperating fully with the investigation.

The Transport Minister, Humza Yousaf, announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a long-standing dispute over seafarers' pay. The issue concerned workers on two freight boats being paid less than £4 an hour. The charter change will transfer contracted services back to operator Serco Northlink from next month, as Seatruck, the current operator, argued that the national minimum wage was not applicable to the crew, many of whom are non-UK residents. Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap and backdate it, but Seatruck declined. The new arrangements, subject to some financial and regulatory details, will ensure all crew members are paid at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink has been operating three ferries and two cargo boats to the Northern Isles on a heavily subsidized route since 2012.

Ken Dickie, aged 64, passed away in a hospital six days after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. The incident occurred following an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother, which involved Jamie Mitchell, aged 35. Mr Mitchell had admitted intervening in the argument and was found guilty by a jury at Winchester Crown Court. The trial revealed that Mr Mitchell and Mr Dickie had been in a relationship for several years and were going through a difficult phase at the time. On 7 May, Mr Mitchell visited his mother at the park and, after getting drunk in the holiday park bar, there was a confrontation between him and Mr Dickie outside. Mr Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault in relation to the fight. Additionally, he and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, aged 57, admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the events to the police. The pair will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a British songwriter, died last week at the age of 66 after a brief battle with cancer. He is best known for his work with Michael Jackson, writing hits such as Off The Wall, Rock With You, and Baby Be Mine. Temperton also wrote for Jackson's album Thriller, including the title track and The Lady in My Life. His songs were also popular with other artists like Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin, and The Brothers Johnson. Temperton was nicknamed The Invisible Man due to his low profile and traced his songwriting ability back to his father's influence. He won a Grammy Award in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986. His family has requested privacy at this time.

A team of archaeologists, including Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott from Swansea University, have discovered ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in the western Brazilian Amazon. These discoveries include over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs" that were hidden for centuries by bamboo-dominated rainforest. The function of these sites is still unclear, but they are unlikely to be villages and may have been used sporadically as ritual gathering places, similar to the Maya pyramids or Stonehenge. Dr Loader's research suggests these geoglyphs were built amidst taller vegetation, unlike the Maya pyramids, and raises questions about their purpose. The research also indicates that the Amazonian forests were not pristine ecosystems, but had been influenced by humans for over 6,000 years, with a variety of plant species spread across the region. This suggests that people may have transformed their environment by concentrating on economically valuable trees, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products. Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, won his match against world number 29 Querrey in straight sets (6-4, 6-4) in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of a tournament. Kyrgios recently won the Japan Open and is approaching the top 10 in the world rankings. However, he was quieter than usual during the match, attributing his lack of vocalism to feeling tired and having a difficult time. Kyrgios mentioned that his success in Japan and the travel involved in playing at the Qi Zhong Stadium, an hour from Shanghai city center, had taken a toll on him, as he had a poor sleep the night before and the ride to the courts was not ideal. Kyrgios had previously been fined $1,500 for a foul-mouthed outburst at the Shanghai Masters last year, where he described the tournament as a "circus."

The passage discusses the call from scientists, charities, and organizations for the Welsh government to expand the HPV vaccination program to protect against head and neck cancers, in addition to the current protection against cervical cancer. The HPV vaccine is currently given to girls aged 12 and 13 in Wales, but the Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision. The increase in head and neck cancer cases, particularly among younger men who are non-smokers, is a concern. In 2008, a vaccination program was rolled out in schools in Wales, and 85% of girls have been vaccinated. The Welsh government has stated that they will consider the implications of any proposed changes to the HPV vaccination program after receiving recommendations from the committee.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old student at West Calder High School, was battling a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. He documented his life and treatment on a Facebook page called Jak's Journey, which attracted over 28,000 Likes. Jak's story and his positive attitude touched many people. He attended a school prom held in his honor on Saturday but had to leave due to feeling unwell. He was greeted at the event by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson. Jak's family collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity at the prom.

Jak was visited by various sports teams and the cast of the musical Wicked during his stays at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children in Edinburgh and Yorkhill Hospital in Glasgow. He also enjoyed experiences like visiting the Kelpies, having a romantic meal with his girlfriend, and going to a party in his honor.

Unfortunately, on January 23, Jak was informed by doctors that his cancer had spread throughout his body, and they decided not to pursue any

In a dull game with few chances, Egypt scored a late goal against Uganda, securing a 1-0 victory. The goal was scored by Abdallah El Said, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda had an earlier goal disallowed for offside. Egypt's win means they will play Ghana for the top spot in Group D on Wednesday, while Uganda are eliminated from the tournament, having not qualified since 1978. Ghana had already secured their place in the quarter-finals with a 1-0 victory over Mali earlier in the day. The game was played on a deteriorating pitch, with both goalkeepers making key saves. Uganda failed to register a shot on target, despite creating chances in the second half. Egypt appeared to be heading for a goalless draw, but Salah provided the decisive moment late in the game. Uganda will face Mali in their final group game on Wednesday, with Mali needing a win and a large margin of victory for Ghana to qualify.

The passage discusses a plan by Lancashire County Council to develop land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College, which are currently unused. The decision was made following a study by Network Rail. The council, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, plans to establish two direct trains to Liverpool per hour from Skelmersdale, a town that was designated a new town in 1961 and currently lacks its own railway station. The preferred location has good highway access and connectivity to the town and surrounding area. The council has initiated the process of acquiring the relevant land for this project.

The passage describes the discovery of plants in an elaborate grow house during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene. The core pieces of information are the discovery of plants in a grow house, the location of the warehouse (near Ashbourne), and the arrest of a man.

A 28-year-old woman of Kurdish origin was found with serious injuries, having been dragged by the neck through several streets in Hamelin, Lower Saxony. She underwent an emergency operation and was flown to a specialist clinic. The suspect, a 38-year-old man also of Kurdish origin from nearby Bad Muender, has handed himself in to authorities. The motive for the attack is currently unclear, and police are investigating, calling for witnesses to come forward.

The passage discusses a study conducted by the Cass Business School and universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, which found that while women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, they are less likely to receive one. The study, based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, found no evidence to support the theory that women are reticent about asking for more money. The study also found no evidence that women are reluctant to ask for a salary increase due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from a perceived female stereotype. The study took into account various factors such as the size of the employer, industry, whether the workers were parents, and their qualifications. The study's findings suggest that there is some element of discrimination against women in the workplace, and the researchers found that women and men under 40 ask for and receive pay rises at the same rate, indicating a potential change in negotiating behavior.

The passage discusses the issue of limited burial space in Oxford, England. Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years but has not found a suitable one due to various reasons such as size, ground conditions, high water table, or covenants restricting the use of the sites. The two remaining cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021 respectively. After these are full, the council plans to only offer options like reopening family plots, using a few reserved plots, and interment of ashes. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, offers an augmented reality experience through an app. This feature allows visitors to access online information from signs, posters, videos, and band interviews on their phones and tablets. Notable acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The festival organizers aim to provide this new feature to enhance the festival experience for attendees, while also allowing people worldwide to interact with the festival and experience its atmosphere. The app's content will be updated leading up to and during the event.

The passage describes the death of a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds, who won the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage" and was treated by veterinary staff before being pronounced dead. Despite being a rare incident, the British Horseracing Authority is determined to understand the causes and prevent such incidents in the future. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, but not on the day of his death. He was a well-known horse, having won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and was considered the "horse of a lifetime" by his trainer. The passage also mentions that Many Clouds had received treatment for a tendency to overheat in the past, but it does not conclusively link this condition to his death, as he was the victim of a rare pulmonary haemorrhage.

A 15-year-old girl met a man named David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Ayrton, now known as Davina, is currently on trial for allegedly raping the girl while two others were asleep in the garage. The victim clearly recalled the events, having only consumed half a can of Foster's. Davina, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer, has been remanded into custody at a male prison in Winchester due to concerns about her safety and potential to skip court. The trial took place at Portsmouth Crown Court, where Davina discussed her sexuality and denied making any physical changes to her body or taking medication. In 2014, Davina disclosed the attack to a worker at a care home where she lived in Fordingbridge, Hampshire.

The Serbs, specifically Novak Djokovic and an unspecified team, lost a doubles match 6-4 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This loss occurred a day after Djokovic was defeated in the singles by Juan Martin del Potro. Previously, Djokovic, who is the world number one, suffered a surprise third-round defeat in the Wimbledon singles by American Sam Querrey. However, he did win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics. The passage encourages readers to subscribe to the BBC Sport newsletter for more sports news, features, and videos.

The passage describes an upcoming event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, where over 20 competitors are expected to participate. These competitors are carvers from various countries, including Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US. The unique rule of the competition is that only chainsaws can be used for carving logs into animal and human shapes, and any other carving tools are prohibited. The defending champion, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will return to compete for the Claymore Trophy, the prize for the first-place winner.

The passage discusses the injury status and return plans of rugby player, Dan Biggar (referred to as Webb in the text). He has been out due to a serious foot injury sustained in a World Cup warm-up match with Italy in September. Webb is currently in a pre-season stage of recovery and aims to be fit for the Six Nations tournament starting in February. He expects to return around the beginning of February, but has asked his physios to expedite his recovery by a couple of weeks. The Six Nations tournament begins with Wales playing Ireland in Dublin on 7 February. Webb has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down offers from other clubs to stay with his home region. He made his debut with Ospreys in 2007.

The passage describes an incident involving drug smuggling from Canada to the US, specifically from Washington to San Francisco. Two men, Jeffrey Laviolette and Nathan Hall, were initially encountered by US border agents carrying backpacks containing approximately 58lbs (26kg) of MDMA (ecstasy). One of the men, whose identity is not specified, dropped his backpack, fired a weapon at the agents, and fled. Laviolette was immediately arrested. Hall was later arrested by the Abbotsford Police Department in British Columbia.

A Bellingham, Washington woman, Kali Henifin, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were also involved in the plot. They were accused of planning to pick up the two men at the border and transport the drugs to San Francisco. Lambert allegedly agreed to this for a payment of $11,000. Henifin told agents they had left the area after hearing a report of a shooting on a police radio.

All three defendants in US custody are facing charges of conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution. The wooded area near the border crossing is known for drug and firearm smuggling, and such cases are

The NSPCC's Childline service reported a significant increase in the number of children seeking help, with over 4,500 children counseled in the past year compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. The majority of these children experienced online abuse, with some as young as seven being tormented and scared to go to school. Online trolls were identified as the main cause of misery and humiliation for thousands of children. Dame Esther Rantzen, the president of Childline, urged adults, parents, and teachers to intervene to protect children, as bullying does not stop on its own and can have severe impacts on young people's lives. The report is being released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, which is coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance. The group is working with parents, schools, and other organizations to combat the problem. One young person shared their experience of cyber-bullying, expressing feelings of upset and helplessness. Advice given by young people on dealing with bullying includes asking for help.

The passage describes a series of events related to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. After a UN Security Council resolution, calling for an end to settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem, the US abstained from vetoing it, which Israel found infuriating. Israel's Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, claimed that the White House had helped draft the resolution and "pushed hard" for its passage, a claim denied by the US state department. The resolution states that settlements have no legal validity and constitute a violation under international law. Israel rejected the resolution, particularly the condemnation of building in East Jerusalem. In response, Israel postponed a planned vote on authorising new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot, at the request of the prime minister's office, to avoid further straining relations with the US. This postponement occurred ahead of a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry on his vision for ending the Israel-Palestinian conflict. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas sees the resolution as paving the way for a Middle East peace conference in France on 15 January.

The passage describes various events and celebrations marking Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday. The Queen, accompanied by other members of the royal family, visited Windsor and participated in several events, including meeting staff at a Royal Mail delivery office, opening a new bandstand, and viewing an exhibition. The royal family also posed for a picture that was released as a set of stamps to commemorate the Queen's birthday.

In addition, the passage discusses a BBC interview with Prince William, in which he paid tribute to the Queen, calling her a "guiding example" of what a good monarch should be. He also addressed recent criticisms about his commitment to royal duty, stating that he takes his responsibilities seriously but is trying to find his own way in his role as a future heir.

Finally, the passage mentions that the Queen will have two birthday celebrations, one on her actual birthday and another on a Saturday in June, and that there has been some criticism about the amount of coverage given to the Queen's birthday by the BBC.

In the EFL Cup match, West Ham United, a Premier League team, defeated League Two side Cheltenham Town 2-0. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored for West Ham before half-time, with assists from Sam Byram and a goal-less performance from Adrian in goal. Cheltenham Town came close on several occasions but failed to score, with their best chance coming from Harry Pell's volley. West Ham made seven changes following losses at Manchester United and Southampton, while Cheltenham were unchanged from their 3-0 league defeat by Carlisle. The two sides' only previous meeting was four years ago, resulting in a 2-1 win for West Ham at Upton Park. The victory ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup before the third-round draw.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a car collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday. The driver responsible for the accident, Andreas Werner, a 46-year-old from Leipzig, failed to see the motorcyclist while turning his VW Transporter, causing the fatal crash. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court and was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not wish for Werner, who was staying in a cottage near Bala, to be sent to jail, as they saw it as a momentary lapse and nothing could bring the victim back. Werner expressed remorse for the accident but could not offer an explanation for it.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British jihadist from Southall, west London, is facing a possible life imprisonment for his activities in Syria. He left the UK in January 2014 and called himself Abu Daigham al-Britani. In Syria, he was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State, and was involved in producing propaganda videos and appeals for donations. His activities online included posting videos and pictures of his personal jihad, including one where he showed off his weight-lifting skills. However, some of the group's material online showed gruesome scenes of death, including a picture of Khawaja holding a bag containing a head. Khawaja returned to the UK in June 2015, but was arrested upon arrival and is currently facing prosecution at the Old Bailey. He has admitted four offences, and an additional charge of soliciting to murder was made against him, although it will lie on file. Khawaja was held in a special unit for high risk terrorism suspects at London's maximum security Belmarsh prison while on rem

Kayden Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, contributing to their eighth-place finish in the table. He has been signed by Barnsley for the upcoming season, making him their third acquisition. Barnsley will play in the League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday. Paul Heckingbottom, the caretaker boss, stated that Jackson's speed and attacking style will suit Barnsley's play. Jackson declined a contract offer from Wrexham for the next season. The passage also mentions a dedicated page for football transfers.

In the passage, it is reported that bottles, possibly from a container lost from the MV Blue Ocean, have been washing up on Poldhu Cove and other nearby coves in Cornwall. The National Trust and conservationists are concerned about the potential harm to wildlife and marine life, as the bottles contain a detergent called Vanish. However, the Maritime and Coastguard Agency states that there is no current evidence to confirm that these bottles are from the container lost by the MV Blue Ocean; all evidence is circumstantial. The National Trust is clearing away the bottles, and the public is advised to keep a safe distance from them. Cornwall Council is monitoring the beaches in the area, and the authority and partners will take action if necessary. Vanish has not yet commented on the situation.

The passage describes an incident that occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at around 14:00. This incident resulted in a crash, and several people received minor injuries. The road was closed, and diversions were set up via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is currently conducting ongoing inquiries into the incident.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French center-back, made 14 appearances last season to help Bolton Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made a total of 83 appearances in all competitions. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite's contribution towards the end of the campaign. Dervite is the latest player to sign a new contract with Bolton, following their promotion to the Championship, joining David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

The passage describes a disagreement between the Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) and Labour over Brexit-related issues. Initially, they worked together to defeat the government on amendments regarding the rights of EU citizens and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. However, when these amendments were rejected, the Lib Dems insisted on them, while Labour was prepared to defer to the Commons. A Labour source in the Lords criticized the Lib Dems for raising false hopes among people concerned about their future in Britain, while the Lib Dems accused Labour of supporting the government's hard Brexit plans. The two parties have a history of forming alliances on various issues, but a Labour source predicts residual tensions between them.

The passage discusses the current state of defense spending and policy in the UK, focusing on the upcoming election. Most political parties have defense low on their list of priorities, with the public showing a sense of combat fatigue after military interventions in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Libya. The UK's armed forces are facing significant cuts, with the regular Army being reduced from 102,000 to 82,000, the Royal Navy having a fleet of just 19 warships, and the RAF having eight front-line fast jet squadrons. The UK has fallen from fourth to sixth place in global defense spending, and there is a conspicuous absence of a commitment to spend 2% of the nation's wealth on defense. Only UKIP and the Democratic Unionist Party have pledged to continue meeting the 2% goal. The military top brass expect more cuts in defense, and the question is by how much. The Ministry of Defense (MoD) has reason to be nervous, as it has the second largest non-protected budget, after welfare, of £34bn a year. The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the transfer of Neymar to Barcelona. Despite paying £48.6m for the Santos striker, it has been alleged that the actual cost of Neymar was significantly higher due to additional fees, including signing-on fees, agents fees, and wages. Barcelona's president, Sandro Rosell, resigned following accusations of misappropriating money and is currently under investigation.

Recently, a judge in Spain ruled there was sufficient evidence against Barcelona to continue investigations into the transfer. In response, Barcelona made an additional tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to cover potential interpretations of the contracts related to Neymar's signing. However, the club denies any tax-related crime and maintains that the original tax payment was in line with their fiscal obligations. Neymar has scored a total of 10 goals in 25 matches for Barcelona this season across both La Liga and the Champions League. The outcome of the investigation is yet to be confirmed.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver from Nottingham, was killed in a car accident caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, who was driving the wrong way on a motorway. Luciw's family, including his mother Andrea Shelton and brother Simon, are advocating for regular driving tests for older drivers, citing Luciw's untimely death as a result of an older driver's poor driving. Age UK supports the idea of older people being able to drive for as long as possible, but also emphasizes the importance of safety. Luciw's family and a colleague who survived the accident believe that regular medical examinations and driving tests should be implemented for older drivers. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must renew their licenses every three years and report any medical conditions that could affect their driving, but there are no mandatory medical or driving tests. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) has no plans to restrict licensing based on age, stating that older drivers are not more likely to cause serious accidents than others. The incident is being further discussed on BBC One East Midlands' Inside Out program.

The passage discusses the safety concerns surrounding transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse in women. Two members of the initial review group resigned in protest over a perceived watered-down report. An independent expert, Professor Alison Britton, will examine the process by which the report was concluded and provide recommendations for future procedures.

The final report recommended against offering the procedures routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse, suggested a range of treatments be offered, and advocated for mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a ban, the recommendations will continue to be implemented. The health secretary stated that the power to ban the procedures lies with the UK regulatory body, the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency.

The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to unite the panel members around the controversial final report. Two women who had suffered complications from the surgery, Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, resigned from the review group, claiming parts of the final report had been removed. A consultant also quit the expert group over concerns about the final draft of the report.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Kirsty Wade McColgan's 25-year-old record in the 5K race at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. McColgan initially expressed concerns about the authenticity of the race, as Muir was the only competitor in the 5K and there might not have been drug testing. However, British Athletics confirmed Muir's time is expected to be classified as official. McColgan believes Muir has the potential to win world medals, with her current time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds in the 5K being impressive, but still room for improvement. McColgan also noted similarities between Muir's record-breaking race and her own 25 years ago, as both races were run mostly alone. Muir has previously broken her own British 1500m record and reached the 1,500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

In the passage, Jung won the equestrian event in the Rio Olympics, with Astier Nicolas of France taking silver and Phillip Dutton of the USA winning bronze. William Fox-Pitt of Great Britain, who competed just 10 months after being in an induced coma following a fall, finished 12th. Fox-Pitt had led after the dressage phase but dropped to 21st due to time penalties in the cross-country phase. Jonty Evans of Ireland finished ninth. The passage also mentions Henry the mechanical horse and encourages readers to subscribe to the BBC Sport newsletter for equestrian news and updates.

Andy Murray, a British tennis player, won his fourth-round match at Wimbledon against Italian player Fabio Fognini in a tense four-set game. The score was 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5, with the match point clinched at 20:57 BST. Murray will play Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Earlier, fellow British player Johanna Konta reached the second week of Wimbledon for the first time with a win over Maria Sakkari of Greece. Murray described the match as up and down, with moments of poor play but managed to win. Fognini had five set points to force a fifth set but Murray won five games in a row to secure the victory. The match was dramatic, with both players showing their talents and temperaments, and Fognini was penalized for a visible obscenity. Murray expressed satisfaction with getting through the first week of the tournament and hopes to improve his movement and play better tennis in the next round.

The passage describes an incident at Joe's Bar in Dungiven, where paramedics were called for a sudden death at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police arrived later and found people still at the bar, with till receipts showing alcohol was served as late as 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered closed for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas, both from the same address, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The court was told that the licensing laws in Dungiven were not strictly adhered to, and the premises had been running well into the morning. Ms O'Neill, who has an "appalling record," was fined £3,000 and faced concerns about a custodial sentence. Mr Thomas was fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, has launched a manifesto titled 'Real Partnership'. He emphasizes that partnership is preferable to domination and wants the election to serve as a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle. However, his comments have led to internal party discord, with senior colleague Danny Kennedy distancing himself. Nesbitt has denied any regrets or mistakes and encourages voters to support Ulster Unionists, followed by their preferred candidate. He prefers a coalition with the SDLP over Sinn Féin, should they enter Stormont Castle. The manifesto includes proposals for tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritizing the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community, and ensuring no group is negatively impacted by Brexit. Nesbitt criticizes the DUP and Sinn Féin's 10-year tenure in Stormont Castle and accuses them of incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption. The ongoing controversy over his SDLP preference may impact the resonance of this message.

The passage discusses a motion to be presented in Northern Ireland's assembly, aiming to bring the region in line with England and Wales in terms of pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offenses. This initiative, known as 'Turing's Law', is named after World War Two code-breaker Alan Turing. The law will provide posthumous pardons and allow living men to apply for pardons. The motion in Northern Ireland's assembly will contain provisions for both posthumous and living pardons for gay and bisexual men, with the aim of ensuring equal treatment. The Justice Minister, Claire Sugden, has secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion to pardon convictions related to abolished sexual offenses. The pardons are intended to address past wrongs and provide resolution sooner than an assembly bill would. The motion is now ready for consideration by the assembly.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, set a new Scottish record in the 1500m race with a time of 4 minutes, 19.12 seconds. This erased Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60 and moved Muir to second place on the British all-time list, behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir is also the current Scottish record holder for the mile. She finished second in the recent race behind Faith Kipyegon. Muir is aiming to secure an Olympics place for Great Britain in Rio at the British trials in Birmingham from 24 to 26 June. She recently completed her fourth year of veterinary school and is fitting her training around her studies. Her husband, Tom Mooney, congratulated her on Facebook. Muir started her season with an 800m victory in Montbeliard, France, last week and will next compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm in a week's time.

The passage presents a collection of pictures from Scotland's top 26 beaches, which have been rated as having excellent water quality. The core information provided is the listing of these 26 beaches, but no further details about the beaches or the water quality criteria are given in the passage.

The passage describes the summary of an inquiry into the murder of Alexander Litvinenko in London in 2006. Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Litvinenko, but the Russian state was likely to have been involved in the plot due to having "reasons aplenty" to harm or kill him. The two suspects are believed to have poisoned Litvinenko with a fatal dose of radioactive substance polonium-210 during a meeting. Horwell suggested that the Russian state's involvement was the only credible explanation for Litvinenko's murder, but he stressed that this did not necessarily mean Russian President Vladimir Putin was involved or gave the order. Defecting to the UK and making personal attacks on Putin could have been seen as "akin to treachery." Horwell also mentioned that Litvinenko was poisoned twice in the run-up to his death, and the risk to the general public from polonium radiation will never be known. Steve Smith, aged 26, has been appointed as the permanent captain of the Australian one-day and Twenty20 teams, replacing Michael Clarke who has retired after a heavy defeat by England in the Ashes series. David Warner, aged 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain despite a history of disciplinary issues. Smith has previously captained the side in three Tests against India, and has played in 32 Tests for Australia, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. Warner has been praised for maturing and developing into an important senior figure in the Australian team, and is expected to respond well to the added responsibility of leadership. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval.

The passage discusses the stance of a newly elected Liberal Democrat leader, Mr. Farron, on LGBT-plus rights. He is passionate about defending equal marriage and extending marital rights for transgender people. The passage describes the reopening of a drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, previously owned by Sanofi, which closed in 2015 resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. The new owner, Accord Healthcare, plans to use the plant for pharmaceutical production, with the intention of hiring many former Sanofi employees. The local leader of Newcastle City Council, Councillor Nick Forbes, views this as positive news for the local economy, as Accord is a global player in the pharmaceutical industry and the jobs and investment bring a welcome boost. In the provided passage, it is stated that three senior officials, Richard Ellis (former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive), Ciaran Monaghan (head of the chief executive's office), and Ewan Sutherland (head of human resources and customer services), are leaving their positions at the council. The English rider, Martin, had a crash at this year's TT and his bike, the Fireblade, has been experiencing mechanical issues. Despite initial reports suggesting he was quitting road racing, Martin clarified on Facebook that he hasn't given up on racing but has no plans to do more road racing on Hondas this year. He missed the North West 200 due to a team-mate's crash and will not compete in next month's Ulster Grand Prix because the bike is not expected to be competitive. Martin expressed dissatisfaction with the TT, stating it was a "disaster," and expressed interest in racing classics and "oddball stuff" instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP lost key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, as well as Adamawa, one of the states affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, they managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC's victory has relegated the PDP to a regional party, as they failed to get a national spread of votes, doing well only in the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. The PDP won eight governorships, with Taraba being the only result still outstanding, and the election in Imo state being declared inconclusive. Elections were not held in seven states. The APC's historic gains have raised hopes that Nigeria's democracy is maturing, but the elections were

The passage discusses allegations made by Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, against Olam, a Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader, and its main stakeholder, Temasek. The allegations accuse Olam of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may contribute to the haze caused by fires in Southeast Asia. Olam denies these claims and states it has a "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" compliance policy. The company has resisted releasing the names of its suppliers but agreed to do so on Monday. Temasek, the majority stakeholder in Olam, also denies the allegations and states it fully supports no-burn policies for land clearance. The passage also mentions concerns about Olam's practices in the African state of Gabon, where it is accused of bulldozing rainforests to establish palm oil plantations. Olam denies these accusations and states its private-public partnerships in Gabon strive to be both responsible and transparent. The palm oil industry is projected to be worth $88bn by 2022 but is often accused of unfair and illegal labor

The passage describes a restaurant that started serving "puppy platters" after a new law was introduced, allowing dogs to eat at restaurants outdoors. The meal is referred to as a "right dog's dinner." A video clip is provided for viewing.

The passage discusses the injury status of three players from Forward Fernando Forestieri (knee), Derby County striker David Nugent (groin), and midfielder Jacob Butterfield. The passage discusses the lifting of the ban on YouTube in Pakistan, which was initially imposed by the Supreme Court in 2012 due to the upload of the controversial US-made film "Innocence of Muslims." The ban was lifted following the launch of a Pakistan-specific version of YouTube by Google. However, Google has stated that requests for the removal of content will not be automatically granted and will only be considered after a thorough review. Some activists have called for greater transparency regarding the terms of the deal between Google and the Pakistani government. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) has confirmed that all internet service providers have been directed to open access to YouTube. The ministry of information technology in Pakistan has stated that Google will restrict access to offending material upon request by the PTA. A YouTube spokeswoman has also confirmed that requests by governments for content to be removed will be recorded in YouTube's Transparency Report.

The passage discusses the ongoing dispute between Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, and Musa Bility, the boss of the Liberian Football Association (LFA), regarding Scala's participation in the upcoming election to replace long-standing Fifa president Sepp Blatter. Scala is Swiss-Italian, as is one of the presidential candidates, Gianni Infantino.

In 2015, Scala excused himself from the elections due to sharing nationality with a candidate, Swiss Sepp Blatter. Now, Bility has threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday, as Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations states that any member of the Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee with a conflict of interest must be replaced.

In 2015, Scala and Claudio Sulser also stepped aside for the same reason during the elections between Blatter and Prince Ali of Jordan. However, Andreas Bantel, a spokesman for Scala, argues that Scala's nationality does not

Daniel Timbers (29) and Barry Joy (56) were fatally killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road, while working around 9:00 BST on Monday. They were believed to have been working in a paint-spraying area. The bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search was conducted at the company, which manufactures buckets for diggers. The police have made significant progress in their investigation, suggesting a flashover explosion caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source, resulting in a fire-ball effect. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence, including from their inspectors and electrical safety experts.

Tunisia was at risk of expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints lodged against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) following a controversial penalty call in the 2015 tournament. However, they apologized to Caf and were allowed to participate. Morocco, on the other hand, was initially banned from participating in the 2017 qualifying draw due to issues related to the 2015 tournament, but the ban was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Both countries are now preparing for the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations, with Tunisia aiming to set a record of 13 consecutive appearances in the tournament.

In the 95th minute of a football game at Etihad Stadium, Chelsea won 3-1. Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho from Manchester City were sent off, while Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will not face any further action. Aguero received a four-match ban for a high and late challenge on Chelsea defender David Luiz, which was his second dismissal for violent conduct this season. Fernandinho, who clashed with Fabregas in the subsequent scuffle, will serve a three-match ban. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge. City's manager, Pep Guardiola, apologized for his team's part in the incident.

The passage discusses a pilot plan in the Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd area focusing on early detection of lung cancer, as Wales and other parts of the UK contribute to a significant number of diagnostic tools for lung cancer worldwide. Doctors are concerned about the lack of symptoms or signs that would indicate lung cancer, and a visit to Denmark revealed that the healthcare system in Denmark has improved diagnostic tools. The hope is that Wales, which does not have clear symptoms for a long period before diagnosis, will not be a "difficult case" for any diagnostic method. Doctors need to be aware of the symptoms of less obvious lung diseases to detect lung cancer. A clinical trial will be set up in the University Hospital of Wales, Llantrisant, and it is expected that a few cases will be detected and diagnosed each week. Currently, only 35% of lung patients in the Cwm Taf area have symptoms that can lead to a diagnosis. Dr. Gareth Davies, the head of the Cancer Network Wales, believes the plan will help detect cancer and also manage the process. If a doctor sees a patient with symptoms but is unsure of what it is and suspects it might be cancer

England won the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series 1-1. Joe Root, promoted to number three for this series, was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. He also took four catches and claimed a wicket in Pakistan's first-innings. England made a total of 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, setting up their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Pakistan batted for only 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second on a pitch that offered little assistance. Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment with their performance, particularly their shot selection, and stated that they are short of confidence. The third Test will take place at Edgbaston on 3 August.

The passage discusses the British and Irish Lions' summer tour to New Zealand, led by head coach Warren Gatland. Rob Howley is part of Gatland's backroom team. Forwards coach McBryde will take over head coach responsibilities for the third time, having led Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches to assist McBryde. WRU chairman Gareth Davies, who is also on the Lions' selection panel, believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team, as it provides an opportunity for coaches to develop in different environments. The tour is expected to provide a challenging and inspiring experience for all involved.

In the given passage, Southampton and Hull City played a football match at the KCOM Stadium. Charlie Austin scored a penalty for Southampton in the 6th minute, but Hull City came back strongly in the second half, scoring two goals in two minutes through Robert Snodgrass and Michael Dawson. Hull City's win was their first in the league since 20 August, ending a six-game losing streak, but they remain in the bottom three of the league. The match was significant for Hull City as they were missing their starting strikers due to injuries, but Snodgrass, who returned from an ankle injury, played a crucial role in their comeback. The match was also significant for Southampton as they had celebrated a famous win against Inter Milan in the Europa League a few days prior. Despite the loss, Southampton manager Claude Puel acknowledged that they lacked concentration and urgency in the second half. The teams will next play Sunderland and Liverpool, respectively, following the international break.

A motorcycle crash occurred at approximately 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, Lincolnshire. The motorcyclist was a local resident and was killed in the collision. The tractor driver was unharmed. The police have requested witnesses to the collision to come forward. The B1191 was closed in both directions following the incident, between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle. No further details about the motorcyclist have been released.

The passage describes a political crisis in Macedonia, triggered by covert recordings that appear to show ministers engaging in vote-rigging, cover-ups of a murder, and corruption at the highest levels of government. President Ivanov has cancelled an investigation into these claims, citing a desire to "defend national interests" and "put an end to the agony." This decision has been condemned by the opposition and EU officials, who view it as a breach of the rule of law and a potential risk to Macedonia's EU membership ambitions. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev has urged protests in the capital Skopje, while EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn has expressed his disapproval of President Ivanov's actions. The crisis has been ongoing since the recordings were released in 2015.

Swansea, promoted to the Premier League in 2011, is currently in a difficult situation following Bob Bradley's sacking. Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge of the upcoming match against Bournemouth. Swansea aims to appoint a new manager, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement being the first choice. The club is concerned about the possibility of relegation, as the Championship has become stronger and it may not be easy for Swansea to return to the Premier League if they do get relegated. Swansea's decline is attributed to frequent management changes and the loss of key players since Michael Laudrup left in 2014. However, Curtis believes the current squad is capable of staying up, and he reminds new signings of Swansea's history and the importance of staying in the Premier League for the club and the local area.

In the provided passage, Dagenham & Redwich (The Daggers) were relegated from League One to the National League, ending their 9-year stay in the Football League. This relegation was confirmed after a 3-2 loss to Leyton Orient, with goals from Jay Simpson, Armand Gnanduillet, Jamie Cureton, and Clevid Dikamona. Dagenham had initially reached the Football League for the first time in 2007, and under manager John Still, they had climbed from the Conference to League One. However, this season, they have the worst goal difference in League Two, having conceded 20 more goals than at the same point last season. In attack, 40-year-old striker Jamie Cureton has scored nine goals, compared to the 20 he scored during the 2014-15 season when Dagenham finished 14th.

Leyton Orient, on the other hand, remain in the play-off race, now two points behind the play-off spots following their victory. The interim manager, Andy Hessent

Steven Gerrard, former Liverpool captain, is returning to his former club as a youth coach in February, marking his first job since retiring as a player. Jürgen Klopp, Liverpool's current manager, expressed enthusiasm about Gerrard's appointment, noting that Gerrard aspires to become a manager in the future. Gerrard, who made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and retired in November after a 19-year career, had previously been linked with the manager's job at League One side MK Dons but felt the opportunity came too soon for him. He is also working towards obtaining his Uefa A coaching license, a requirement for managing in the Premier League.

In the provided passage, Morton scored four goals against Alloa, with McManus scoring twice and Denny Johnstone scoring once. The first goal was scored by McManus at the quarter-hour mark, and Ross Forbes' deflected strike made it 2-0. Alloa scored one goal before half-time, but McManus and Johnstone scored in the second half to secure a comfortable 4-1 win for Morton at home.

The passage describes an investigation by Ofsted into illegal schools in Birmingham, particularly in Muslim communities in the Midlands. Three schools have been closed due to squalid conditions, and their owners are under investigation. Sir Michael Wilshaw, the Chief Inspector of Schools, is concerned that these cases may be just the tip of the iceberg and that children are at risk of abuse or radicalization.

Any place where children are taught for more than 20 hours a week must register as a school. However, some places calling themselves part-time education centers or "flexi schools" are operating within the law but are suspected of running illegal schools. Ofsted and ministers are concerned that some are taking advantage of the legal right to home educate.

Sir Michael has suggested that officials have been slow to take decisive action, and the government has provided funding for a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools. The investigation will not be limited to Muslim communities but will apply to all religious groups operating in unsafe or unhygienic conditions.

The education secretary has stated her intention to prosecute unregistered schools identified by Ofsted, but a prosecution requires her consent. A government consultation

The passage discusses the opening of Lilliard Gin distillery, located at the Born in the Borders visitor center in Jedburgh, marking the first whisky distillery in the Scottish Borders since 1837. The distillery is led by lead distiller Kate Macinnes, who emphasizes the potential for the region to become a "region of distilling excellence." The gin production is on a smaller scale compared to other distilleries in development, and the distillery fits into a cow shed. Lilliard Gin aims to capture the local flavors and 'terroir' of the Teviot valley using Borders botanicals. The distillery takes its name from a legendary Borders figure, Lilliard, who was a heroine of the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545. John Henderson of Born in the Borders views the gin distillery as a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery on the site, and is excited about the prospect of tasting the gin.

Harry Whitlam was tragically killed in August 2013 when Gary Green, who was under the influence of alcohol, reversed a vehicle into him on private land at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds. Green was more than twice the legal driving limit and had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed at 02:00 BST. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks for failing to ensure the safety of others. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her hope that her son's life would be remembered for more than just the day of the accident and that the family can again remember the good times they shared. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) investigated the incident and found that Green had been walking towards a worker in a closed-off area of the farm when he backed the tractor into Harry at about 09:15 on 9 August. HSE inspector Julian Franklin described Green's behavior as "reckless."

Luis Suarez, a Uruguayan striker, has had his ban from all football-related activities reduced by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). The reduction allows him to train, play in friendly matches, attend matches, and participate in promotional activities. However, he will still serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games. Suarez's ban was initially imposed by FIFA for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during Uruguay's 2014 World Cup group match. His legal team argued that the punishment was too strong, and CAS agreed that preventing him from participating in any football activity was excessive. The full explanation of the CAS ruling will be published at a later date. Suarez will now be available for Uruguay's friendlies against Japan and South Korea in September and Saudi Arabia the following month. He joined Barcelona last month for £75m and is expected to make his competitive debut against Real Madrid on 26 October in El Clasico.
