On March 18, 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a unique race, the Carry Your Partner Race, in which competitors carry their partners over a 380-meter course that includes hurdles, a steep slope, and water pistol obstacles. The couple, who trained extensively for the event, will now represent their country at the World Championships in Finland in July. The race featured various combinations of competitors, including men carrying women, men carrying men, and one instance of a woman carrying a woman. The Lithuanian team, Vytautas Kirkliauskas carrying his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene, provided strong competition.

The passage discusses the scrapping of the paper system for car tax discs in October 2014, which will be replaced with an electronic system allowing monthly direct debit payments. This change may lead to adjustments in job roles at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) due to a potential reduction in the number of refunds and the withdrawal of the tax disc. However, the minister, Stephen Hammond, has assured that any reductions in staff will be managed through redeployment to other growth areas of the business, rather than redundancies. This news has been welcomed by Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, who represents DVLA employees.

The passage discusses a standoff between Hungary and the European Union (EU) over three issues: Hungary's control of asylum seekers and non-governmental organizations (NGOs), a higher education law, and a draft legislation on NGOs. Hungary's government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, has passed two of these laws and is forcibly housing asylum seekers in secured shipping containers, raising concerns about EU law compatibility.

The higher education law could lead to the closure of the Central European University (CEU), a prestigious institution founded by philanthropist George Soros. Thousands of Hungarians have protested against these laws in recent months. Hungary's government, however, has stated it will not backtrack on these issues, asserting that they are matters of national competence and that the EU should not interfere with domestic issues.

Poland has pledged to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary, as EU rules require unanimous approval for decisions that could strip a member country of its voting rights. The EU has expressed concern over these laws and is under pressure to take action

The passage describes an upcoming live-action adaptation of the Disney film "Beauty and the Beast." Emma Watson has been cast as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as Gaston's sidekick LeFou. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, the father of Belle, and the star will portray Mrs. Potts, the housekeeper magically transformed into a teapot. The film is set to be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017, and Bill Condon, director of Dreamgirls and the last two Twilight films, will direct the movie, which will begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

Adrian Gill, a renowned journalist and published author, passed away due to cancer. He was a long-time columnist for The Sunday Times, known for his witty, fearless, and compassionate writing. Despite his diagnosis, Gill did not feel cheated and considered himself lucky. His final column about coming to terms with his diagnosis will be published tomorrow. Gill was known for dictating his copy over the phone due to dyslexia. His writing often caused controversy, with comments about various groups and individuals, including animal rights groups, Welsh people, residents of Rhyl, Norfolk, the Isle of Man, and Clare Balding. Gill was born in Edinburgh, overcame dyslexia, and had a successful writing career, starting in the 1980s with art reviews for magazines, then writing for Tatler and The Sunday Times. He was married twice and had four children. His engagement to his partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, was prompted by his illness.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa and the lead singer of Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked during a performance in Ulan Bator, the country's capital. The attack involved being hit over the head with a bottle and repeatedly kicked in the face. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident, but has called local press reports "distorted." Sukhbaatar wore a swastika-embroidered Mongolian robe during the performance, a symbol that pre-dates its association with Nazis in Mongolia. His father stated that he spent about 10 days in a coma after the beating. The Russian official accused of the attack has not been identified. The swastika is also used by far-right groups in Mongolia, and there were reports that Sukhbaatar shouted "Heil Hitler" at the show, which were denied by his lawyer, father, and a band member. The case is under investigation by Mongolian police, with the suspect being a Russian diplomatic officer. The embassy denies that the suspect was not arrested due to diplomatic immunity.

On Monday, members of the action group Plane Stupid staged a demonstration against the expansion plans of an unspecified airport. The demonstrators were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area of an aerodrome. They are scheduled to appear in court on 19 August. The protest occurred on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday. The Metropolitan Police have announced that they will review security at the airport following the demonstration.

In the cricket match between Glamorgan and Gloucestershire, Nick Selman scored a century (101 runs off 144 balls), his second in first-class cricket. However, the bowlers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets in cloudy conditions, ensuring Glamorgan's total was 220. Gloucestershire struggled in their response, with Aneurin Donald scoring 36 runs. The day ended evenly balanced, with Glamorgan securing a consolation bonus point. Michael Hogan is leading Glamorgan in the absence of Jacques Rudolph, who has a neck problem. Selman expressed satisfaction with his performance, while Taylor was pleased with his bowling performance. The Gloucestershire batsmen face a tough challenge in the remaining innings.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested in August by North Wales Police for making threats to ambush and shoot police officers on the Dee Estuary. The threats were made online to the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee while Hughes was drunk. He admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. Hughes planned to make a false report to the police to lure them to a scene where he would carry out the attack. He has a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. Despite this, his legal team stated that he did not intend to kill himself and would not have carried out any threat to kill police officers. The Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counselling to people experiencing difficulty.

In the cricket match between Yorkshire and Surrey, Surrey posted a score of 255-7, with Davies and Foakes (90) contributing a stand of 130. Yorkshire's run-chase was disrupted by a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker, resulting in the dismissals of Jonny Bairstow, Gary Ballance, and others. Despite Tim Bresnan making 68, Yorkshire fell short, ending their innings at 236. Yorkshire had hoped to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002, but they were undone by dropped catches and poor batting performances. Surrey's captain, Gareth Batty, praised his team's performance, while Yorkshire's captain, Alex Lees, expressed disappointment with their performance, particularly their inability to make significant contributions with the bat.

A 56ft trawler, 6 miles west of South Stack, experienced water ingress and was unable to manage it with the onboard pump. The crew contacted the coastguards at 07:00 BST. The RNLI lifeboat crew provided an additional pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner from Scotland, will not be able to participate in the 2018 Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. She recently finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. Despite missing the Commonwealth Games, Muir aims to compete in the World Indoor Championships in March. She also expressed her satisfaction with her performance at the World Athletics Championships, where she set a new outdoor personal best time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m. Hellen Obiri won the 5,000m gold in London, with Sifan Hassan finishing third.

The passage discusses the current state of Liverpool's football team, as analyzed by football pundit Robbie Savage in his BBC Sport column. The team is struggling to repeat last season's title challenge, with Steven Gerrard facing a physical and mental battle to secure a long-term future with the Reds.

One of the main issues is the loss of key strikers Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge, who scored a combined 52 goals last season. Rodgers has not been able to find suitable replacements, with the current options (Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini) not being good enough and lacking in work-rate compared to the previous strikers.

Another problem is Liverpool's lack of intensity and pressing high up the pitch, which was a key factor in their success last season. They have scored fewer first-half goals this season and are having to chase games instead of being on the front foot.

Defensively, Liverpool still look vulnerable, despite spending money on players like Mamadou Sakho and Dejan Lovren. Simon Mignolet, the goalkeeper, is criticized for

A  £45m educational campus is to be constructed in Kilmarnock, Scotland, housing primary, secondary, Gaelic, and childcare facilities. The council plans to name the campus after local author William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney, a passionate advocate for education, was an English teacher before becoming a full-time writer in 1975. He gained recognition with his first novel, Remedy Is None, and was known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir" for his acclaimed Laidlaw trilogy and other Glasgow-based works. McIlvanney was also a poet, journalist, broadcaster, and contributed to Scottish politics and sports through columns and TV programs. He passed away on 5 December.

The passage describes an evacuation in a town near Gourock, due to the discovery of a sea mine, believed to be British and dating from the 1940s or 1950s. The evacuation affected three streets and wider safety advice was issued to residents within 500m of the device. An exclusion zone was also set up at sea and small boat owners were advised not to sail during the operation. The evacuation was a precautionary measure, with no immediate danger to the community, according to the local area commander. The mine was moved to a safer location due to concerns about the amount of explosive material it still contained. Ferry services were disrupted as a result of the operation. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the evacuation procedures.

The passage discusses funding decisions for Olympic and Paralympic sports in the UK for the Tokyo 2020 Games. UK Sport has allocated a total of £345m for 31 sports, which is £2m less than the funding for the Rio Games. Notable sports that have had their funding cut include archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and badminton. Cycling, which brought 12 medals in Rio, has had its funding cut by more than £4m. Badminton England is particularly upset about the decision, as they had a podium place in the summer and were set a target of winning a medal in Rio. Judo, which also claimed one bronze medal, has had its funding increased slightly. UK Sport has set Team GB a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo, aiming to maintain the success at Rio 2016. Sports like basketball, handball, and volleyball have previously had their funding withdrawn and are critical of UK Sport's approach to team sports. The funding for the five

In the given passage, a six-storey four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks are planned to replace three Victorian hotels in a conservation area of Bournemouth, East Cliff. The development, proposed by The East Cliff Project LLP, includes a 90-room hotel, a nine-storey, and a seven-storey building with 122 assisted-living apartments. English Heritage and some residents have objected to the demolition, citing the historical character of the area. However, the council, with a majority vote, approved the plans, stating the need to preserve tourism and improve living conditions for older people in the town. The loss of buildings and trees is regrettable, but progress is deemed necessary.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from Carrickfergus, County Antrim, was off-duty and on a night out in Brecon when he was attacked and beaten outside a bar called The Cellar. The attack, which occurred on 8 May, left him unconscious and he was later found by police. The attacker, Jake Vallely, will be sentenced on 8 December. Vallely's friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. The trial revealed that Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and had boasted he was the "hardest man in Brecon" before the attack. The attack was described as a "despicable act" that "shocked" the community of Brecon. Pte Boyd's family described him as an "all-rounder" with a "promising career ahead of him" and expressed their grief over his death. They also praised the community of Brecon for their support during the trial.

Andrew Travers, the former chief executive of Barnet Council, left his position by mutual agreement following an error that caused voting issues in the EU Referendum. On election day, all 155 polling stations in the borough experienced problems due to missing voter names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched to review the appropriateness of the arrangements in place for the EU Referendum, with the findings to be presented publicly by the end of May. In the interim, John Hooton, the deputy chief executive, will take over temporarily. Voters in the area have questioned the fairness of the election results due to the issues that prevented some from voting. Mr. Travers has blamed the electoral registration lists for the problems.

In this passage, a football match between Gateshead and Wrexham is described. Josh Gillies scored a free-kick for Gateshead to take the lead, but Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham with a set-piece before half-time. In the second half, Ryan Bowman scored a header from a cross by Craig Baxter to give Gateshead a 2-1 lead. Malcolm Crosby, the Gateshead manager, praised his team's performance in the second half, while Gary Mills, the Wrexham manager, expressed disappointment with his team's second-half performance. The match ended with a final score of 2-1 in favor of Gateshead.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks the social and economic welfare of individuals aged 60 and above in 96 countries. Norway is ranked as the best country, while Afghanistan is the worst, followed by Mozambique.

The passage discusses the OneWeb project, a planned constellation of at least 600 and potentially up to 2,000 spacecraft aimed at delivering global broadband internet. The project is significant due to its focus on high volume and low cost production, with Airbus adopting new assembly line methods similar to car and plane factories. The first assembly line has been inaugurated in Toulouse, France, with two more to be set up in Florida. The satellites produced are expected to cost less than a million dollars each.

The project aims to have every school connected and requires a large number of launches, with more than 20 Soyuz vehicles booked for the task. The constellation is expected to be fully established by the middle of the decade.

OneWeb and Airbus are not the only companies planning mega-constellations, with SpaceX, Boeing, ViaSat, and others also seeking regulatory approval. However, OneWeb believes it has a first-mover advantage due to already raised equity of $1.7bn and ongoing talks for additional financing.

The project is registered in the UK's Channel Islands

The passage discusses the UK government's spending review and its impact on Scotland. John Swinney, a Scottish government official, states that the UK government's spending review places "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure in Scotland, and that the Scottish government's discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. He also mentions that schools, hospitals, and the police service in Scotland will not be sacrificed due to austerity measures.

The UK government, in response, states that Scotland will have £390m more spending available to it next year, which rises to £750m if you include its own underspend. They also argue that the stability of the UK economy means the block grant will be almost £30bn, and that this is a better deal for people in Scotland than the constitutional alternative favored by the Scottish government.

Labour's public services spokeswoman, Jackie Baillie, criticizes John Swinney for not providing a concrete plan to counteract austerity measures and calls for

The passage discusses the need for Changing Places toilets, which are enhanced facilities designed for people with severe disabilities who require additional space and equipment such as hoists and changing benches. Currently, there are 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but campaigners argue that they should be made compulsory in larger buildings like shopping centers, cinemas, and leisure facilities.

Lorna Fillingham, a mother of a six-year-old with disabilities, is leading a petition to change building regulations to make Changing Places guidelines compulsory. She expresses concern about the lack of truly accessible toilet facilities in town centers, which can lead to stressful and unpleasant experiences for her and her daughter.

Alison Beevers and Bethan Folen also share their experiences of the psychological impact on their families due to the lack of appropriate changing facilities. They describe feelings of isolation, guilt, and a lack of inclusion in society.

However, there are positive examples of businesses and individuals making efforts to provide temporary or permanent Changing Places facilities, which have been well-received by the public. Arsenal Football Club, for instance,

A group of Italian consumers' organizations have filed a formal antitrust complaint against McDonald's with the European Commission, alleging that the fast-food giant forces franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. The complaint also claims that McDonald's makes franchisees sign longer-than-average contracts, preventing them from switching to competitors, and that franchise stores have poorer consumer choice and higher prices compared to those owned directly by the company. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and other European unions are supporting the complaint. McDonald's has denied the allegations, stating that it shares risks and rewards with its licensees and is committed to supporting its franchisees. The European Commission will study the submission and has the power to launch an investigation if it believes the allegations are founded. Franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and the company received $9.27bn in revenues from its franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A social media campaign using the hashtag #prayforjosh was initiated by Bangor Elim Church in support of 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The campaign started on Facebook and Instagram, and quickly went viral. The senior pastor of the church, Gary Beattie, was amazed by the global support received. A mystery donor paid for a billboard with the same hashtag to be erected in Holywood, County Down. The campaign has also received significant support on Twitter from Joshua's classmates at Bangor Grammar School. The campaign has led to widespread support for Joshua and his family during his recovery.

The passage discusses a planned closure of Brecon Barracks in the UK, a military facility with a long history dating back to 1805. The closure is part of a larger military reorganization in the UK. Chris Davies, the Conservative MP for Brecon and Radnorshire, strongly condemns the decision, citing the barracks' historical significance and its role in various conflicts since the early 19th century. He also expresses concerns about the potential impact on local unemployment and the military tourism industry.

The closure does not seem to pose a direct threat to the jobs of the approximately 85 civilian staff and 90 military personnel at Brecon Barracks. However, nearby Sennybridge training ground and infantry school at Dering Lines are not affected by the closure.

The reorganization will see a specialist light infantry center created at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan. Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire, whose closure was previously announced in 2013, will now close in 2024, and a storage depot at Sennybridge will close in 2025

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. The industry, which produces a small percentage of GDP and employs a limited number of fishers, is at risk of being marginalized in Brexit negotiations due to its low priority status for the government. However, the industry argues that Brexit offers an opportunity to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation.

The UK's fishing waters are shared with other EU coastal states, and the majority of UK fish are exported to the EU. The report suggests that continued market access may come at a price, as EU member states may demand more access to UK waters in return for zero tariffs on fish exports to the EU.

The report also recommends retaining many elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) post-Brexit, including basing total allowable catches and quotas on scientific advice and continuing international obligations to cooperate with neighboring states. However, the CFP framework treating the UK as one entity may fall away, potentially leading to four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland.

The passage discusses the revelation by Ed Snowden, a former technical worker for the CIA, that the US National Security Agency (NSA) has access to a vast amount of individual data, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. This access is facilitated through a program called Prism, which reportedly enables "backdoor" access to the servers of nine major technology companies. The NSA has been accused of eavesdropping on citizens' activities, with concerns raised about privacy and data protection. The US government argues that such surveillance is necessary for national security, but critics question the true extent of the NSA's powers and the legality of its activities. It is not clear whether other governments are involved in the use of Prism, and privacy concerns persist, with no legal way for individuals to "opt out" of monitoring activity.

OpenAI is a venture backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, Amazon Web Services, and others. The organization aims to advance digital intelligence with a focus on positive human impact, while acknowledging the potential risks associated with AI, such as the threat to humanity and the possibility of AI outpacing biological evolution. The venture aims to ensure AI is an extension of individual human wills, broadly and evenly distributed, and only a small portion of the $1 billion pledged will be spent in the near future.

L/Bdr Parkinson, a resident of Doncaster, was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006. Despite his injuries, he was chosen to carry the Olympic torch on June 26, 2012. Due to Facebook's limit of 5,000 friends per personal page, he has been unable to accept all the thousands of friend requests he has received. He walked with the torch for nearly half an hour with an assistant. His nomination for the torch relay highlighted his resilience and unchanged intelligence and wit, despite his brain injury. He spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab, and the rest of his time raising money for military charities and serving as patron of the Pilgrim Bandits. His mother, Diane, has been overwhelmed by the support and friendship he has received, with over 5,000 friend requests, 19,000 hits on his page, and hundreds of requests to visit places with the torch. Facebook suggested he consider having a page instead of a profile or using the subscribe feature to allow people to see his public updates without becoming a friend. A

In 2011, the poverty rate in the United States remained at 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans. Real median household income decreased by 1.5%. The average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6% for the first time since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance also decreased slightly, from 16.3% to 15.7%. Notably, poverty in the US had reached a record high in 2010 at 15.1%.

The passage describes a 25-year-old cricket player named Jos Buttler, who moved to Lancashire from Somerset in 2013 and recently signed a contract to stay with the club until 2019. Buttler is a specialist in short-format cricket and holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries. He has been praised by cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles for his talent, contributions to the team, and positive influence in the dressing room. Buttler is currently playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians but will return to Lancashire for a T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates (HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall) are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to register interest, and final decisions are not expected until spring. The government aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the capacity of the UK's industry. MP Penny Mordaunt prefers a reef and diving attraction for at least one frigate, as it could generate income through tourism. The Ministry of Defence is considering all options to ensure the best financial return for the taxpayer. Last year, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold as scrap for £3m. No proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted as of the date mentioned in the passage.

The passage describes the political instability and racial tensions in Fiji since 1987, which have led to several coups, including one in 1987, 2000, and 2006. These coups caused harm to the economy, particularly the tourism industry, and damaged Fiji's international reputation. The country was suspended from the Commonwealth in 2009 due to lack of progress towards democracy. In 2012, the government agreed to hold free elections in 2014, leading to the restoration of full diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand. Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with the latter being largely driven out by coups and agitation. Mixing between the two groups is minimal, and informal segregation runs deep at almost every level of society. Fiji's economy is diverse, relying on sugar, tourism, gold, silver, limestone, services, and some light manufacturing, but it has been hampered by persistent trade and budget deficits, making it one of the world's largest per capita recipients

Syria, under its Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad, is attempting to comply with the international timetable to destroy its chemical weapons stockpile. However, Syria missed the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile on Wednesday. Al-Mekdad blames attacks on two shipments of weapons for the delay, claiming they were intercepted by "terrorist groups." The Syrian government is also under fire for its use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, with reports of over 240 deaths, including 73 children, in the last five days. The government denies bombarding civilian areas and accuses the US of supporting terrorist elements in the country. Regarding the central prison in Aleppo, both the Syrian government and the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights deny that rebels have seized most of the prison. The Syrian government has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only about 4% (30 tonnes) having been removed from the country so far. The US and Russia have expressed concern over the delay in the destruction process, with a deadline of 1 March set by Russia for the transfer of all

The passage discusses the shortlist for the 46th annual Booker Prize, which is open to all authors writing in English. The favorite to win is Mukherjee's The Lives of Others, set in 1960s Calcutta, followed by Richard Flanagan's The Narrow Road to the Deep North. Other shortlisted authors include former Booker winner Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, and David Mitchell. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night and will receive £50,000. The passage also mentions that the shortlist has been criticized for being weak and that there may be reluctance to make Howard Jacobson a two-time winner due to Hilary Mantel's recent double win. Each shortlisted author receives £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book. The ceremony will be covered by the BBC News Channel and BBC Arts.

A celebrity, referred to as PJS, is appealing to the Supreme Court against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on his identification in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether to grant the appeal and decide if the case should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction remains in place until the hearing. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish an account of the celebrity's alleged extra-marital activities, but PJS argues for privacy and has taken legal action. The Court of Appeal judges ruled on Monday that the details about the allegations are now "so widespread" that confidentiality has "probably been lost," making it a "hopeless task" for PJS's solicitors to remove stories in breach of the injunction.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, was purchased in August for £345.5m. The new owners, Crown Estates, are planning improvements to address parking and traffic congestion, as well as the appearance of units. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, mentioned that the new owners view Fosse Park as an investment and are aiming to improve its appearance. Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, stated that they aim to address parking and congestion issues, and improve the quality of common areas and facilities to enhance Fosse Park's overall appeal.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the release of the live-action remake of "Beauty and the Beast" in Malaysia. The film, which features a "gay moment," was initially scheduled for release on Thursday but was held for a content review by Disney. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film with a minor edit regarding the gay moment. Homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia, but the country's tourism minister considers a ban on the film as "ridiculous." The LPF has approved the film, but the release date and screening location are not under their jurisdiction. Local cinema chains are offering refunds to customers who purchased tickets in advance. The "gay moment" in the film involves LeFou, the sidekick of the main antagonist, struggling with feelings for Gaston. The decision to review the film in Malaysia has received criticism from netizens.

The passage discusses the issue of unlicensed Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMOs) in Southampton. Landlords who let properties to more than three unrelated people are required to apply for a HMO license, but many are deterred due to the cost of the license (up to £1,000). Despite this, they face potential fines of up to £20,000. There are an estimated 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area, and tenants often express concerns about living in poorly maintained properties and the threat of eviction. Mandatory licensing for HMOs nationally applies to houses of three storeys or more and occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, the licensing affects properties in Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (Designation 1) and in Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (Designation 2). The council has had success in gaining prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals who have failed to obtain the necessary licenses.

In the provided passage, Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil aim to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government but won't support a program for government. Water charges, a contentious issue, are a major hurdle in reaching an agreement. Proposals include establishing a commission to consider the future of Irish Water, the national water utility. Fianna Fáil wants immediate removal of water charges, while Fine Gael sees a role for them. After the recent election, Fine Gael has 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party seven. However, no party has been able to form a majority government, and TDs have yet to elect a Taoiseach (Prime Minister).

The passage describes an incident where a ship named The Sorrento, en route to Valencia, caught fire approximately 27km from Mallorca. The fire quickly got out of control, leading to the evacuation of passengers onto lifeboats. Three people were injured and transported to the hospital by helicopter, with one reported to be seriously hurt. The cause of the fire remains unclear. Several ships, including two passenger ferries, were sent to assist. The evacuated passengers and crew were eventually taken aboard the Puglia, a ferry, and are expected to arrive at Palma de Mallorca port in a few hours. Psychologists are being requested to provide counseling at the port. The Balearic Islands port authority has stated that due to the fire, The Sorrento may sink in its current position. The incident was reported to have started at 13:50 local time, with distress signals sent out by the Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione that owns the ferry.

In the provided passage, it is stated that during the 8 June election, a record number of 46.8 million people were registered to vote, with a turnout of 68.7%, the highest since 1997. There was a surge in applications to register in the days after the election was called and before the deadline. However, concerns were raised about duplicate applications, which is a criminal offence. The Electoral Commission reported that about 4.9 million applications were submitted, but the net increase in the number of entries on the electoral register was only 1.4 million, suggesting a significant proportion of applications were likely duplicates. The Commission suggested that clearer information on registration sites and a verification function could help address this issue. Despite efforts to prevent duplicate registrations, the Commission took seriously claims of people voting twice, emphasizing that it is an offence punishable by an unlimited fine. The Commission also called for people who are registered in two seats to choose in advance which one they will vote in at future general elections. Labour warned against making it harder for young people to register to vote, expressing concern that a blanket ban on being registered at two addresses could

Lawrence Phillips, a former star football player at the University of Nebraska and NFL player for the St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers, is believed to have committed suicide at the age of 40. Despite his promising career, Phillips was often troubled, both on and off the field. After his NFL career, he had numerous legal issues, including assault convictions. Most recently, he was serving a prison sentence of over 30 years for assaulting a former girlfriend and killing his cellmate. On Tuesday, a judge found enough evidence to try him for the death of his cellmate. The circumstances of his suicide are unclear.

In the given passage, Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram officially recognized as a soldier, was promoted to the rank of Lance Corporal by Brigadier Andrew Williams in Chester. This promotion marked eight years of the Mercian Regiment. Derby XXX, the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th Century, joined the regiment in February 2014. He has his own army number, receives pay for his rations, and takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. Notable events in his career include helping switch on the Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at the unveiling of a memorial commemorating the 1914 Christmas Truce.

The passage describes a dramatic football match between Liverpool and Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League, which Liverpool won 4-3 in injury time. The victory was significant as it moved Liverpool closer to qualifying for the Champions League. The match was marked by intense emotion, with Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp showing passionate support from the sidelines. The match was also notable for Liverpool's comeback from a 2-0 deficit, with Divock Origi scoring a crucial goal. The victory was seen as a turning point for the Klopp era at Liverpool, with many fans becoming believers in the team's potential. The match was played at Anfield, with a special atmosphere created by the fans and the singing of "You'll Never Walk Alone." The victory was also compared to Liverpool's comeback in the Champions League Final in 2005. After the match, Klopp expressed his pride in the team's performance and spoke of the need to write more "nice stories" at Anfield. The passage also mentions the individual performances of players such as Divock Origi and Philippe Coutinho, as well as areas for improvement, such as Liverpool's vulnerability

The passage discusses a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, where the UK government and the devolved administrations of Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland discussed the Brexit negotiations. Mr Davis, a UK government representative, emphasized the need for regular meetings to share analysis and foster a "two-way information flow" with the devolved administrations. He also stated that the UK government will work positively with the devolved administrations to get the best deal for the whole of the UK.

However, Mr Russell, a representative from the Scottish government, expressed concern about the lack of transparency regarding the UK government's plans. He highlighted the need for clarity on the UK's intentions regarding EU market access, specifically whether the UK aims to remain inside the single market or the customs union. Mr Russell also made it clear that membership of the single market is essential for the economic prosperity of Scotland.

The passage also mentions that the UK government hopes the High Court judgment on how Article 50 will be triggered will be overruled on appeal to the Supreme Court next month, and the Scottish government intends to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court during

The passage describes a physical examination of a flock of 13 cloned sheep, including Daisy, who are identical twin sisters of Dolly the sheep, the first cloned mammal born in 1996. The examination is being conducted by veterinary surgeon Dr Sandra Corr to check for signs of disease or osteoarthritis. The study's lead author, Professor Kevin Sinclair, explains that the results of the examination could have significant implications for the future of cloning, as there are concerns about whether cloned animals age in a normal way and how healthy they are. The study aims to determine if cloned animals are more prone to diseases associated with aging, such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results of the study will be published next week, and for now, the cloned sheep, which are approaching their ninth and tenth birthdays, seem to be in good health.

In the given passage, the unbeaten 4-7 favorite horse, whose name is not specified, won a race by a length and three quarters, beating runner-up Vintage Folly. This horse, trained by John Gosden, will not compete in the Oaks at Epsom, but will instead go to Chantilly. Gosden's other horses, Enable and Coronet, are top contenders for the Epsom Oaks. Tasleet, trained by William Haggas, won the Duke of York Stakes. Shutter Speed, who previously beat Enable into third, won the Musidora Stakes for Gosden and Dettori. Shutter Speed will compete in France's Oaks, a race of a mile and a quarter, while Gosden will rely on Enable and Coronet in the longer Epsom Oaks. Gosden is concerned about the ground conditions for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes, a Derby trial, and may not run him due to the short time between the Dante and the Derby. Shutter Speed and Cracksman are both in good form, with Shutter

The passage discusses the volatility of the British pound against various currencies, particularly the dollar, euro, and Japanese yen, in the context of the upcoming Brexit referendum. The pound initially recovered but then fell again, with the "volatility index" reaching levels last seen during the 2008 financial crisis. This volatility is attributed to investors' uncertainty about the referendum outcome and global economic concerns.

Two polls over the weekend showed the Leave campaign ahead, causing the implied probability of a Remain vote to drop from almost 80% to 68.5%. This shift in polls is expected to increase the volatility of the pound further. Hedge funds have been short-selling sterling, expecting its value to decrease further.

The passage also mentions the impact of the Brexit referendum on the UK's stock markets. Asian stock markets experienced a big fall, and the FTSE 100 in London initially showed muted reactions but ended the day down 1.1%.

Nigel Farage, a Leave campaigner, argued that the pound had recently been strengthening and that a

The Iron, a part-time football team, are currently in sixth place in the National League, just outside the play-off spots. They recently lost a game to Barrow, extending their losing streak to three games. Despite this, their manager, Cowley, remains optimistic, noting their impressive performance against a strong Barrow team and expressing that their current journey, despite its challenges, has been remarkable. Barrow, on the other hand, extended their unbeaten league run to nine games with the victory.

The passage discusses a proposed change in Northern Ireland's planning system, where responsibility for planning decisions will shift from the Planning Service to local councils and their elected politicians starting from April 2015. This change is seen as a democratic move, offering local councils the opportunity to develop their own community and development plans. However, concerns have been raised about the skills and potential biases of politicians in handling planning matters, with references to historical issues of discrimination in the allocation of public housing in the 1960s.

Environmental group Friends of the Earth warns of the need for a strict code of conduct to ensure fair and transparent handling of planning matters, citing potential issues of favoritism towards certain communities and close relationships between developers and political parties. They also advocate for increased transparency in political donations. Some local politicians remain opposed to the change due to concerns about donor deterrence. The final decision on the transparency of political donations lies with the Northern Ireland Secretary.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times, requiring amputation of its left back leg and extensive treatment. The owner, Sarah Nisbett, found Teenie injured and is concerned about the safety of children in the area. The Scottish SPCA is investigating and urges anyone with information to come forward. The incident highlights the concern for licensing air weapons, as a majority of respondents in a previous Scottish government consultation opposed the plan. The Scottish SPCA believes a licensing regime would help ensure only those with a lawful reason possess such weapons. However, in the previous consultation, 87% of respondents rejected the idea, describing it as "draconian" and "heavy-handed."

Christian Benteke, a Belgian international forward, has joined Liverpool on a long-term contract, becoming their second most expensive signing. Liverpool triggered a release clause in Benteke's contract to acquire him for an undisclosed fee, following the sale of Raheem Sterling to Manchester City. Benteke scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa after joining from Genk for £7m in 2012. He is Liverpool's seventh summer signing and is expected to help revive their attack, which struggled last season due to the sale of Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge. Benteke has previously scored 15 goals in the 2014-2015 season, helping Villa stay in the Premier League and reach the FA Cup final. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge are optimistic about Benteke's performance at Anfield.

The passage discusses the increasing use of tablet devices in schools, particularly in the UK, and the impact they have on students. The study, commissioned by Tablets for Schools, found that tablets are used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with 9% of schools having an individual tablet device for every pupil. The highest use of tablet computers was within academy schools.

Despite the widespread use of tablets, the study found no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using these devices. Researchers were unable to isolate the impact of technology as the specific cause of a rise in attainment. However, head teachers reported a positive impact, and tablets were found to help motivate disengaged pupils and increase family involvement.

The study also found that young people are immersed in technology at school and home, with many pupils taking tablet devices to bed for social media and other activities. A separate study suggested that touch-screen computers, including tablets, were particularly useful in helping boys and poorer pupils to learn to read.

Simon Mason, head of Honywood Community School in Essex, is a strong

The exhibition 'Growing Up in the City' at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs spanning over 100 years, showcasing the lives of children in Liverpool. The images range from the 1880s to the 1990s and offer a glimpse into childhood experiences, as well as providing a social history of life in Liverpool. The exhibition, curated by Kay Jones, includes photographs of children at play, as well as those depicting children working. The oldest image is from 1887 and shows the Rollo children dressed up for a fancy dress ball. The exhibition runs until September 25th.

Anderson, a 27-year-old center-back, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join their National League rivals. He has previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. He could debut against his former club on February 18. Keating, a 21-year-old striker, is joining Torquay United, subject to international clearance. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson recommended Keating, who has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, Finn Harps, and Port Vale. Nicholson believes Keating is the leader-type he has been seeking. Torquay United is currently four points above the relegation zone and has won only one of their last six games.

The passage discusses a new law in Bolivia that allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, reflecting the country's needs as one of the poorest in South America. The law also sets harsher punishments for violence against children, including a 30-year sentence for child homicide. Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera signed the law into effect in the absence of President Evo Morales. Over 500,000 children in Bolivia already work to supplement family income, with many working in cities and others facing extreme conditions in mines and agriculture fields. The law aims to help eradicate extreme poverty in Bolivia, but it is not in line with international conventions that prohibit children under 15 from working. The International Labour Organisation is studying the legislation to determine if it breaches international regulations on child labor.

A 50-year-old woman, who is a well-known actress, fell ill at home with symptoms such as sudden nausea and aches. She searched for women's heart attack symptoms online, took aspirin, and visited a cardiologist the next day. The cardiologist inserted a stent into an artery that was 99% blocked. The woman revealed that the type of attack she experienced was known as the "widow maker." She did not call emergency services but urged her readers to be aware of heart attack symptoms and to call 911. The woman, who has acted in several films and TV shows, recently hosted The Rosie Show on the Oprah Winfrey Network, but the show was cancelled in March due to low ratings.

A 16-year-old boy named Che Labastide-Wellington was stabbed and died at a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, London, after a later scuffle in an alleyway. The incident occurred around 00:30 GMT on Saturday. Another 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is currently in stable condition in a north London hospital. The party, which was well-attended by adults, was not believed to be the initial cause of the altercation. Che was targeted later, according to police. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, along with two boys aged 15 and 16, who have been bailed until mid-December. A 14-year-old is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon. Police are seeking witnesses near the alleyway between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate at the time of the incident.

The passage discusses a new approach to diagnosing cancer in Denmark, which was implemented due to concerning cancer survival statistics from more than 15 years ago. The approach aims to address less obvious cancer cases, particularly those with vague or difficult-to-diagnose symptoms. The new model of care in Denmark has three routes:

1. Fast-track diagnosis and treatment for patients with "alarm" symptoms of specific cancers, with strict time targets.
2. Diagnosis centres, set up in 2007, where patients with symptoms GPs cannot diagnose are given a range of tests and scans quickly to find out what is wrong with them.
3. "Yes-no" centres for patients with minor symptoms, which offer a simple test or scan to identify problems quickly.

The changes have not resulted in a surge of GP referrals but have improved the organization of patient diagnosis within existing resources. The results show better survival rates, with Denmark catching up to and surpassing other European countries, including Norway, Sweden, and Finland. The passage suggests that there may be lessons to be learned from Denmark's approach that could be applied in Wales.

The passage discusses the UK government's decision to disband the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) and replace it with a new service, to be delivered by Powys, for handling complaints and issuing warnings or banning orders against estate agents who breach estate agent laws or act dishonestly. The new service will receive £170,000 annually to carry out this work. Complaints will still be made to local authority trading standards departments, but they will refer cases to Powys if they suspect a breach of the Estate Agents Act. James Munro from Powys council will lead the new team, and he hopes this new role will demonstrate Powys' ability to take on more contracts and outside work in the future.

The passage discusses a plan to reshape the NHS workforce, which consists of 1.3 million employees, to help address staffing shortages, particularly in the areas of junior doctors and GPs. The plan, supported by NHS Employers, involves training existing staff to take on additional tasks, such as nurses filling in for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs. However, unions have warned against using this as a quick fix for NHS problems.

The Nuffield Trust, a think tank, has highlighted examples of areas already experimenting with this approach. The report suggests that this could help cover for doctor shortages and make sense due to the changing nature of care, with a focus on managing long-term conditions like diabetes and heart disease.

The report also acknowledges that more funding would be needed to ensure this reshaping of the workforce happens. The author of the report, Candace Imison, sees "huge opportunities" in this reshaping, both for improving patient care and providing staff with more rewarding roles.

However, the British Medical Association (BMA) leader, Dr Mark Porter, supports increasing the skills of the work

The passage describes an incident where Avon and Somerset Police closed a section of the Lower Bristol Road in Bath due to a crash at Rackfield Place outside the First depot. The A36 road closure, which occurred at 03:00 GMT and was lifted at 14:00 GMT, caused disruptions and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. Investigations are ongoing to determine the cause of the collision. First, the bus company affected, stated that while some services had resumed normal operations, it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal. The managing director of First expressed hope for a full service by the evening commute and expressed gratitude to the public and staff for their support and efforts in managing the situation.

The passage discusses a dispute between Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) and Natural Resources Wales (NRW) over the potential impact of the Swansea tidal lagoon project on fish populations. NRW has estimated that the lagoon could result in 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying each year, while TLP claims that their own computer modeling shows a "worst case scenario" of the lagoon killing only 2% of all species of fish. TLP has criticized NRW for not sharing its methodology for calculating the impact on fish, while NRW asserts that it has shared a large amount of information and data with TLP and has the confidence of independent experts in its methodology. The UK government is currently considering the viability of the Swansea tidal lagoon project, and the Welsh Government is supportive of the scheme, but is seeking clarity on the UK government's position.

A new industry-led agri-food marketing body is being established in Northern Ireland, as announced by Arlene Foster, the Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister. This body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, aims to provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities in the agri-food sector, which includes farming, fishing, retail, and distribution, and employs nearly 100,000 people. The Agriculture Minister, Michelle O'Neill, has welcomed the announcement, acknowledging the need for better coordination of current marketing activities. However, she also notes potential implications for the work of other organizations, including her own department, and looks forward to discussing the plans with the Agri-Food Strategy Board.

On Saturday afternoon, the Woodland Trust is organizing a tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, inviting the public to participate. This is part of a larger four-year project across the UK to plant millions of native UK trees in commemoration of those who died during WW1. In Brackfield Wood specifically, the goal is to plant 40,000 trees, in tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The event aims to create a woodland area with wildflowers, including poppies, where wildlife can thrive and people can walk, relax, and reflect. The charity is providing saplings and advises volunteers to wear welly boots or stout footwear. The event takes place about seven miles outside Derry city, with limited parking available. The trees planted will serve as a living tribute to the Irish people who were part of the war.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her book "Someone Else's Skin," which is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. The book was praised for its emotional impact, fine writing, and handling of the subjects of domestic violence and honor crime. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution award for her 23-year career writing about detective VI Warshawski, a female private investigator from Chicago. Paretsky is known for being a trailblazer in crime fiction, creating a strong female protagonist and founding Sisters In Crime, an organization to support female crime writers. The crime writing festival in Harrogate, where the awards were given, had a particularly strong shortlist this year, according to Ann Cleeves, the festival's programming chair.

Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016. His injury was a significant setback for the team's hopes of qualifying. Santner will rejoin Worcestershire following the ICC Trophy in England in 2017. Previously, Worcestershire signed John Hastings, an Australia pace bowler, as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats of the game.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was unlawfully killed in a hit-and-run accident on a dual carriageway in Kiev in 2008. The car involved was speeding and had stolen license plates, and did not brake or stop. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina (also known as Anna), was 19 years younger than him and was suspected of involvement in his death due to her quick claim of his assets, selling his belongings, and moving funds from his bank account. The inquest also revealed that she was having an affair with a Ukrainian man. Despite strenuous attempts, Ziuzina did not attend the inquest in Exeter County Hall. The coroner, Dr Elizabeth Earland, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating that the evidence was overwhelming. The case is still active in Ukraine but not actively pursued.

Sophie Fearns' son, Charlie, from Merseyside, requires experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital due to a failed transplant in the UK. The family was left heartbroken when the first transplant did not work. Charlie has been ill since the age of three and after a third relapse in April, there was no more treatment available in the UK. An anonymous donor has paid for Charlie's treatment, which the family is extremely grateful for. The treatment will start as soon as possible after receiving financial clearance from the hospital. The family expects to find out the treatment date next week.

The passage discusses a security issue involving the theft of intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud. The issue is addressed by Apple implementing a two-step verification system to prevent unauthorized access to iCloud accounts. This system requires an extra step after a user types their username and password into a device they haven't used before, including entering a four-digit code sent via text or Apple's Find My iPhone app.

However, the two-step verification system is an opt-in choice, and until now, it did not apply when users used iCloud's back-up service. This meant that even if users had enabled two-step verification, attackers could still download a complete back-up of their data using third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker.

Apple has now made changes to guard against this technique, and Elcomsoft's owner has acknowledged that their program can no longer access iCloud data in this way. However, concerns remain about the security system, particularly the risk of losing the 14-character recovery key, which is needed to regain access to the account if the trusted device is lost or stolen.

Exper

The passage discusses a potential deal where football player Dan Groves, who was a runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011 and has played for various non-league clubs, could buy 20% of Billericay football club. The deal details are not yet finalized. Billericay is currently in the eighth position in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off spot. The club has recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is investing £10,000 a week. Notably, Billericay signed former England international Paul Konchesky, aged 35, at the start of March.

Mr Ashley, the owner of Sports Direct, has been asked to give evidence about the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into the company's warehouse working practices. He has until 21 March to respond to a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee. The letter states that the committee will be keeping the treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage under review. The BIS Committee has offered several dates for a meeting at Westminster, but Mr Ashley has not accepted any of them. If he fails to respond, the committee reserves the right to take further action, including seeking support from the House of Commons. Sports Direct has not responded to the BBC's request for a comment. The company has previously pledged to review worker rights, with oversight by Mr Ashley, who also owns Newcastle United Football Club.

The passage describes a report titled 'Putin. War', which was not written by the murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov but was completed by his colleagues, led by Ilya Yashin. The report is based on facts that have been reported in Russian and foreign media since the annexation of Crimea in March 2014 and the conflict in eastern Ukraine. The report accuses President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own ends, providing evidence of Russian soldiers and equipment being involved in the conflict in eastern Ukraine, with Russian generals directing the main battles. The report also mentions the salaries of volunteer soldiers and the Russian spending on the conflict. The report is hard to publish and distribute due to fear and lack of interest from the public. The opposition plans to seek donations to extend the initial print run of only 2,000 copies. The passage also mentions that earlier works published by Boris Nemtsov, such as reports on corruption in the president's entourage and the true cost of the 2014 Sochi Olympics, failed to galvanize protests against President Putin.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. He was 34 years old and from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham. The cause of death was determined to be head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses the tension between the UK government and the Welsh government over the Brexit negotiations. Carwyn Jones, the first minister of Wales, expressed his displeasure about not being consulted in the drafting of the Article 50 letter and being treated with a lack of respect. Alun Cairns, the Welsh Secretary, defended the UK government, stating they have been discussing the contents of the letter for months and are acting in the interests of the whole UK. In her letter to Donald Tusk, Theresa May mentioned that the UK government will consult fully on which powers should be devolved to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland after Brexit, but the specific powers and the funding for them are currently unclear. Carwyn Jones has expressed concerns about the lack of funding for these devolved powers after 2020. Some in Whitehall think the way EU money has been spent in Wales could be an argument for transferring those powers to Westminster, but politically, it looks less likely now. A white paper on the Great Repeal Bill may provide more details on the process and the identity of the powers the UK government wants to see devolved on Thursday.

The passage describes an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night, where two cars were damaged. The incident involved attacks on PSNI (Police Service of Northern Ireland) officers. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his disapproval of these attacks, stating they were mindless and harmful to the Newry community. Additionally, the PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that the police were performing their duties when attacked, and they appealed to parents to know their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and allegations of misuse of company funds. The company's board filed a court document stating they do not expect him to return, citing evidence of sexual harassment, racially derogatory remarks, and violations of the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy. Mr. Charney's lawyer disputes these claims. Recently, a restraining order was granted to American Apparel, preventing Mr. Charney from making negative statements about the company in the press and attempting to remove board members.

The passage discusses an upcoming basketball game between Great Britain (GB) and Greece. The game will take place at the Copper Box in London and will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. The game is a chance for GB to avenge their earlier loss to Greece, as three Greek players will not be participating. GB guard Teddy Okereafor is excited about the game, as it is being held in his hometown and will help prepare the team for the upcoming FIBA EuroBasket 2017. The game will be GB's only home game before the EuroBasket tournament, which starts in September in Istanbul, Turkey. After the game against Greece, GB will travel to a four-team tournament in Poland for their final warm-up games before the EuroBasket starts. The game will be held from 17:30-19:30 BST.

The passage describes the introduction of the iPhone by Apple in 2007, which was a significant event in technology history. The author, a journalist, recalls being asked to cover the launch but not having access to the phone. However, he managed to secure an interview with Apple's marketing chief Phil Schiller and was allowed to briefly handle the iPhone. The iPhone was described as a revolutionary product that promised a step change in the way people lived, and it was compared to the Model T Ford in terms of its impact.

The author also discusses how the iPhone changed the way people thought about photography and other activities, as it made it possible to do more on the move. He notes that while there were cameras on phones and mobile devices before the iPhone, its attractive user interface made it easier for people to use their phones for more than just talking and texting.

The passage also mentions that the smartphone has been the key transformative technology of the last decade, putting powerful computers in the hands of more than two billion people and disrupting various industries. The author reflects on his initial skepticism about the iPhone's impact, but now looks back on the launch as a moment in history. He

In the passage, a charity reports that several cats in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire have been poisoned by a toxic substance, specifically antifreeze. The most recent case involved a 7-month-old cat named Meereen, who died on Monday. Meereen's owner, Adria Pearce, found her foaming at the mouth and trying to vomit at home on Friday. Meereen was taken to the vet but died three days later. The RSPCA is unsure if the poisonings are accidental or deliberate and is urging residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, especially antifreeze, to prevent further incidents.

The passage discusses the current situation in Greece, specifically focusing on the Syriza government's agreement to implement more austerity and liberalization measures, mandated by creditors. Despite this, tourism in Greece is increasing, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals this year, up from 21 million. The Greek government, led by Alexis Tsipras, is negotiating a third bailout of €86bn from the eurozone and possibly the IMF. Despite failing to deliver on promises to end austerity, Tsipras remains popular. The new bailout will only be successful if Tsipras can offer hope of better times ahead. The passage suggests that for genuine recovery, creditors, particularly Brussels and Berlin, should avoid triumphalism and consider debt forgiveness in response to Athens' capitulation. The economic situation in Greece is described as a "vicious economic squeeze" that will further impoverish the Greek people.

The passage discusses the return of Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell in the soap opera EastEnders from 1990-1999 and again in 2005 and 2006, for a brief reunion with his character's family. Dame Barbara, who plays Peggy Mitchell, announced her character's return after a hiatus from 2010, revealing that her character's cancer has returned. Producers have revealed that Peggy will die from the disease in emotional scenes to be aired in the spring. Kemp expressed excitement about reuniting with his on-screen family, particularly his brother Phil, played by Steve McFadden. Grant Mitchell is described as a legendary character in EastEnders' 30-year history, known for his family dramas, including an affair with his brother's wife and marrying his ex-wife. The Mitchell brothers' reunion and farewell to their mother is anticipated to be a significant part of the show.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon was found guilty of stalking and fatally attacking Alice Ruggles. Two days before her death, her mother, Dr Hills, tried to reassure Alice about Dhillon, but her daughter's friend warned her that Dhillon might kill Alice. After Alice's death, her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, expressed feelings of guilt and realized the seriousness of the situation despite the signs. They have since established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking and remember Alice as a vibrant, cheerful person. Dhillon was sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

The passage discusses the £18bn Hinkley Point nuclear power plant project in Somerset, primarily financed by French firm EDF. The project has been approved by EDF's board, but the UK government, led by Business Secretary Greg Clark, has announced a further review, causing uncertainty. This review was unexpected and seems strategically timed. Critics have raised concerns about environmental damage, escalating costs, foreign investment, and potential energy supply issues.

The project is significant as it is expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity requirement. However, EDF, the main contractor, faces financial challenges, despite receiving third-party funding from Chinese investors. The project has been delayed due to concerns about EDF's financial capacity and potential risks.

The delay in the project's approval has been criticized by industry leaders, who argue that it could lead to higher costs, more reliance on dirty power, and potential problems with energy supplies. Environmentalists also express concerns about the project's environmental impact. The Hinkley Point project was initially proposed in 2006, and construction was approved in 2013. In 201

The new divorce application form in England and Wales includes a section to name the person a spouse has committed adultery with. Family lawyers and legal experts express concern that this addition may increase conflict and complexity in divorce cases. They advise that it is not necessary to name the third party, as it is "not normally necessary" according to the form's guidance. However, they warn that most people are likely to fill in this section, potentially involving the third party in the court case, which could lead to delays and additional costs. The form is designed to make the legal process more user-friendly, but the smaller print may be overlooked by some applicants. Adultery was the reason for 12,148 divorces out of 100,000 granted in England and Wales in 2015. It has always been possible to name the person believed to have been involved in the adultery, but there is no obligation to do so.

The passage discusses the concerns about the balance between environmental policy and commercial forestry in Wales. Britain is the third largest importer of wood globally, and Wales, in particular, has a significant timber industry, worth over £450m annually. Conifer forests have been prevalent for half a century, but Confor warns that 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need to be replanted. The woodland is managed by both Natural Resources Wales and private companies.

However, there is a conflict between the desire for native, broadleaf species of trees for environmental purposes and the need for commercial forests. Some forests are difficult to reach and harvest, causing conflicts with local residents during timber transportation. The Welsh government aims for a balance between environmental, economic, and social aspects in forestry development, with initiatives like the Glastir scheme encouraging woodland planting.

Martin Bishop, representing Confor, believes the emphasis on environmental aspects is given more attention than commercial forestry and criticizes the current system as too bureaucratic for creating new woodland areas. He suggests that 20,000 he

The passage describes an incident in Coatbridge where a boy was severely injured after being struck. The incident occurred on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at approximately 16:40. Emergency services were called to the scene. The boy was then transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, and his current condition is reported to be serious.

The passage describes the presentation of Ushakov medals to veterans of the Arctic Convoys by Defence Attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko. These convoys, consisting of vessels that traveled from Britain to northern Russia during World War II, were under constant threat of attack by German U-boats and aircraft, and also had to deal with severe cold, storms, and ice floes. By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, with more than 3,000 men losing their lives. The Russian Embassy initially attempted to award the Medal of Ushakov to these veterans in 2012, but the Foreign Office blocked the move due to its rules on foreign medals. However, an "exception to the rules" was allowed last year, and President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals during his visit to London on 16 June 2013. The Ushakov medal is awarded to sailors who have displayed courage in the course of defending Russia or its interests. Able seaman Charles Lewis, 91, from Calmore, Hampshire, was among

The passage discusses issues with the implementation of community payback (unpaid work) for offenders in the UK. The HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays in getting offenders to start their work and a tendency to let offenders go if they do not attend. An example is given of an offender who completed only 16 hours in 17 months. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the report's recommendations. Community payback can range from 40 to 300 hours for offenses like shoplifting, theft, drug offenses, or criminal damage. In 2014, about 70,000 offenders were ordered to do unpaid work. The report identified problems such as organization, with offenders often having chaotic lives and substance abuse issues, making it difficult to ensure they attend work on time. Sanctions for non-attendance can lead to imprisonment, but if not applied, the sentence cannot be enforced. The report recommended improvements, including reducing the number of times offenders are turned away when they report on time, creating objectives for unpaid work that match the offender's circumstances, and viewing community payback as a

The passage discusses a comedian, Russell Brand, who is often accused of hypocrisy due to his advocacy for economic and political revolution for the poor while living in a luxury home. The accusation was made by a newspaper, The Sun, and Brand responded by calling the journalist "a snide" and not replying to a request for comment about potential legal action. Brand has previously addressed the hypocrisy accusations, stating that he is aware of the irony of his wealth and fame, acknowledges the need for personal change, and plans to share wealth as part of that change. He also argues that the system that has made him wealthy is a problem that needs to be addressed. Brand's Twitter handle is @BBCNewsbeat and his videos can be found on Radio1Newsbeat on YouTube.

Dr. J Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, is known for his work in human genomics and the creation of synthetic life forms. He was criticized for his competitive approach to mapping the human genome and his perceived lack of modesty about his achievements. After the publication of the human genome, he focused on creating a synthetic life form, which he and his team at the J Craig Venter Institute have been working on for over a decade. They have now published details of the result, an organism called Synthia, in the prestigious journal Science.

Before his scientific career, Dr. Venter was a surfer in Southern California and was drafted into the Vietnam conflict, where he worked as an orderly in a naval field hospital. This experience inspired him to become a doctor and instilled a sense of urgency in him. He excelled in research during his medical training and, in the 1980s, he realized the importance of decoding genes. He developed an automated decoding machine and switched his attention from the DNA blueprint to messenger molecules (RNA), which allowed him to churn out gene sequences at unprecedented rates.

The passage discusses a research study commissioned by England's School Food Trust, which found that most children who eat school lunches in England have tried new foods at school that they had not tried at home. Half of the parents surveyed reported that their children had asked for school-tried foods to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables among the children were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. The study was initiated due to a previous survey by Mumsnet suggesting that some parents give their children packed lunches because they think their children are too fussy to eat school meals. Approximately four in 10 primary school children in England now eat school lunches, with more children in Scotland (about 46%) eating school lunches.

Alvaro Morata, a 23-year-old striker, joined Juventus from Real Madrid in 2014, with an option for Real to buy him back for up to €30m. He has since scored three goals for Spain at Euro 2016. The British supermarket giant, Tesco, plans to sell its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, to a private equity firm, Yucaipa.
