The passage discusses the shrinking of glaciers in the French Alps between the late 1960s/early 1970s and the late 2000s. The total area covered by glaciers decreased from approximately 375 sq km to about 275 sq km, representing an average loss of around 26% over the 40-year period. This retreat is not uniform across the French Alps, with the greatest losses occurring in the southern sectors, such as the Belledonne and Ecrins Massifs. The northern region, which includes the largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, has experienced less significant retreat. The research was presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting and was conducted by Marie Gardent and colleagues from the University of Savoie. They used map archives, past satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, along with manual inspection to verify the accuracy of automatic delineation methods. The only existing glacial inventory from the French Alps was published four decades ago and found the overall area of ice to be about 375 sq km. Since

The Scots have won all five qualifiers for a major competition and are hosting Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday. A win would almost guarantee their place in the finals. However, the Scots, including Bayern Munich forward Evans, are cautious after previous play-off losses for Euro 2013 and the 2018 World Cup. Stuart Campbell, a blogger and vocal campaigner for Scottish independence, was arrested in the west of England on allegations of online harassment made by a woman in her 30s from south London. The passage discusses a controversy over the mascot of Skegness, a seaside resort in Lincolnshire. The current mascot, known as the Jolly Fisherman, was commissioned in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway. People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) has criticized the Jolly Fisherman, stating that it evokes images of animal cruelty, particularly in the fishing industry. In the rugby match between Scotland and Georgia, Scotland led from the start, scoring six tries to Georgia's two. In this passage, a rugby league match between Widnes and Castleford is described. Widnes took a 14-6 lead at half-time, with Castleford's Paddy Flynn scoring twice against his parent club. Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old man who was held at the US detention facility in Cuba since 2002, was released after a review panel concluded he was no longer a "continuing significant threat." He was arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, a charge he denies. He had challenged his detainment in the US Supreme Court. After his release, he boarded a Kuwaiti government plane and is expected to spend at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. He had argued that he traveled to Afghanistan and Pakistan to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid. He is the first inmate to be freed since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl. His release brings the total number of inmates at the US naval base to 148. The facility was opened by the US in January 2002, following the 9/11 attacks in America, and President Barack Obama has repeatedly promised to shut it down.

Anzac Day, commemorating the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One, was celebrated with a series of services and parades in London. Thousands attended the early morning service at Hyde Park Corner, and up to 400 people took part in a parade before the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey, where the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung. The first Anzac Day commemoration in the capital was in 1916, when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service a year after the Anzac landings at Gallipoli. Since then, the services have become an important moment for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians, who honor the sacrifices of their countrymen and women in all wars. The eight-month campaign on the Gallipoli peninsula in Turkey was one of the bloodiest of the war and the allied operation was an attempt to force the Ottoman empire out of the war.

Player Clarkson, aged 30, has returned to Premiership team Well for a second stint in July. He could make his debut for St Mirren in the Championship game against Alloa on Saturday. St Mirren is currently eighth in the Championship, seven points ahead of bottom side Alloa. Clarkson is optimistic about the upcoming game, aiming to help the team climb the table.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. There were initial concerns about the new owners not maintaining the existing workers' pension scheme, but Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed that all current agreements will be honored. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and members currently have an alternative pension scheme unaffected by the takeover. The Boparan Private Office, representing Mr. Boparan, confirmed that the current pension arrangements with Bernard Matthews would continue under the new ownership. Mr. Harley met with Boparan representatives and reported that the new owner aims to restore Bernard Matthews to its former profitability by investing in the business, making cost savings, and utilizing the existing capacity to process not just turkeys, but also chicken.

The passage discusses issues with a new ferry in Cowes, which has experienced breakdowns, run aground, and training issues since its launch on May 14. The council has authorized the manufacture of ramp extensions to address the problem of vehicles scraping the concrete, and groundings have been resolved.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. The industry, which produces a small percentage of GDP and employs a limited number of fishers, is at risk of being marginalized in the Brexit negotiations due to its low priority status for the government. However, many in the industry argue that Brexit offers an opportunity to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation.

The UK's fishing waters are shared with other EU coastal states, and the majority of UK fish are exported to the EU. The report suggests that continued market access may come at a price, as EU member states may demand more access to UK waters in return for zero tariffs on fish exports to the EU.

The report also highlights the need to retain elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) post-Brexit, such as basing total allowable catches and quotas on scientific advice and continuing to cooperate with neighboring states. However, the CFP framework that treats the UK as one entity may fall away, potentially leading to four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland.

Timothy Geaney, a former teacher, admitted to downloading and permitting the taking of images of young boys in erotic poses between April 2004 and February 2014. He was sentenced to a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and ordered to participate in a special program for sex offenders earlier this year. In February, it was heard in Dumfries Sheriff Court that most of the images he had downloaded did not depict sexual activity.

In a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, it was determined that Geaney's offenses were incompatible with being a registered teacher. The panel found that he had failed to uphold the standards expected of the profession and that his offending behavior had occurred over a lengthy period, demonstrating a pattern of behavior. The panel concluded that there was a strong likelihood of the offending behavior recurring and removed Geaney from the professional register. Geaney was prohibited from re-applying to the register for a period of two years. He was not present at the hearing.

In summary, a fire occurred on 2 March at a site in Duncan Street, causing disruptions to train services and travel. The cause of the fire remains unknown, and the company has until 7 August to appeal the decision. The company could not be reached for comment. The site is operated by Asset and Land Group.

Syria is facing criticism for missing a deadline to hand over its entire chemical weapons stockpile. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is doing its best to comply with the timetable and blamed attacks on shipments for the delay. The Syrian government is also accused of using barrel bombs in Aleppo, resulting in the death of hundreds of civilians, including children. The government denies these allegations and claims to be defending against terrorist attacks. Additionally, there are reports of rebels seizing control of Aleppo's central prison, but the Syrian government denies these claims. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, and only about 4% has been removed from the country so far. The US and Russia have expressed concern over the delay in the destruction of these weapons.

In the second Test of a four-match series between England and Pakistan at Old Trafford, England won by a significant margin of 330 runs, leveling the series. The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. The review aims to gather experiences from older people, their friends, and families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will focus on factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. The commissioner will also consult with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. The review aims to give a voice to older people and their families, ensuring those accountable for and running services understand the day-to-day realities of living in residential care in Wales and the action required to deliver the change needed to ensure that older people living in residential care have the best quality of life. However, the Care Forum Wales, a group dedicated to developing and promoting best practice in social care, has expressed disappointment that no provider expert is on the main advisory panel for the review.

The passage discusses the appointment of former Dons midfielder Paul Sheerin as the new manager at Aberdeen, replacing Neil Cooper. Swansea City, following the sacking of Bob Bradley, will be led by Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams for the upcoming match against Bournemouth. Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, is known for his work in human genomics and the creation of synthetic life forms. He was criticized by the scientific community for his competitive approach to mapping the human genome and his perceived lack of modesty about his achievements. After the publication of the human genome, he focused on creating a synthetic life form, which he and his team at the J Craig Venter Institute have been working on for over a decade. They have now published details of the result, an organism called Synthia, in the prestigious journal Science.

Venter's early life was marked by a lack of academic focus, with him spending his youth surfing in Southern California. He was drafted into the Vietnam conflict and served as an orderly in a naval field hospital, which inspired him to become a doctor and instilled a sense of urgency in him. During his medical training, he excelled in research rather than practice.

The passage discusses the state of apprenticeships in England compared to other European countries, particularly Germany, and the concerns raised by the Sutton Trust about their quality and quantity. The Sutton Trust, in a report prepared by the Boston Consulting Group, states that only a small percentage of apprenticeships in England are rated at level three, which is equivalent to A-levels. The report also notes that England has a more complex and less respected vocational education system than countries like Germany, with a higher number of qualifications and a lower percentage of apprenticeships offered by employers.

The report calls for a radical expansion of apprenticeships, with a majority at level three or higher for a minimum of three years, and no more than 10% at level two. The Sutton Trust chairman, Sir Peter Lampl, emphasizes the importance of apprenticeships for social mobility and economic competitiveness.

The Department for Education acknowledges the need to reform apprenticeships to improve standards, but the Association of Colleges expresses concerns about the feasibility of creating 300,000 new apprenticeships

The passage describes the victory of a British Paralympian named Sarah Storey in a cycling event in Nottwil, Switzerland. She finished more than two minutes ahead of Anna Harkowska from Poland. Storey, who is 37 years old, is aiming for her 17th title in the upcoming road race. She is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with a total of 22 medals, including 11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze medals. Storey has won her medals in both cycling and swimming across six Paralympics. She won four golds at the 2012 Games in London and has now won 21 world titles across both sports. Storey began her sporting career in the pool, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, and later switched to cycling in 2005. She is targeting further Paralympic success at the upcoming Games in Rio de Janeiro in 2016.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Football Conference due to unpaid debts totaling £148,000 to various football creditors, including former manager Martin Foyle, players, staff, and other clubs. The Conference had extended the deadline for payment three times, but Hereford failed to meet the final deadline on June 12. The last team to be expelled from the Conference was Chester City in 2010. Hereford still owes over £70,000 to clear the latest PAYE tax demand from HM Revenue and Customs. The passage is about a football player named Milner, who played for Manchester City and England. He scored his only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers. Milner has now left the England team, stating that his decision was based on common sense.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and early-music movement exponent, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. He was a founder member of the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and the Early Music Consort of London. In 1973, he established the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), serving as its director for over 30 years across six continents. The AAM produced more than 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. One of his most famous recordings, the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah, was named by BBC Music Magazine as one of the top 20 recordings of all time. Hogwood studied at Cambridge University and later at other institutions. He was a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University. The passage describes a boy from Northern Ireland who requires special education due to unspecified needs. The passage discusses a takeover bid by the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) for the Newport Gwent Dragons, who share Rodney Parade with Newport County AFC. The WRU's plan to install an artificial surface at the stadium is against Football League rules. Relegation to the National League would be a significant setback for both the fans and the city of Newport.

The passage describes the life experiences of an unnamed individual from Sierra Leone, who was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels during the country's civil war in 1991. The individual was trained to use a gun and initiated into the group, with the RUF branding him with the letters RUF on his chest. The individual was forced to commit atrocities, including beatings and killings, under the influence of drugs such as marijuana and cocaine.

After escaping from the jungle and living alone in Freetown, the individual was caught and sent to jail. While in jail, he met a preacher named Richard Cole, who encouraged him to change his ways and become a leader in rebuilding the nation. After his release from jail, the individual joined a project called Lifeline Nehemiah, which provided hope and a home for people like him.

In 2014, during the Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone, the individual and others from the project developed a clinic to treat suspected Ebola cases. Through education, support, and collaboration with other agencies, they were able to save many lives

In September, a fundraising campaign was launched to prevent approximately 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from being auctioned to pay off a pottery firm's pension debt. The campaign was successful, and the collection will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund, which led the campaign, will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, where it will be loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The Wedgwood Museum inherited the pension bill from Waterford Wedgwood plc after the firm collapsed in 2009. The collection was at risk of being sold and scattered around the globe had the money not been raised. The collection is considered important for Staffordshire and plays a crucial role in defining Britain's cultural development over centuries.

Dan Groves has stated that the specific details of a potential deal where Wright might acquire 20% of Billericay football club are still undisclosed. In the football match between Blackpool and Colchester United, the score ended 1-1. The first goal was scored by Jamille Matt for Blackpool after 12 minutes, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. The passage discusses the planned redevelopment of the disused Fawley Power Station, which closed in 2013 after more than 40 years of operation. The chimney will be the centerpiece of a "merchant city" development, estimated to cost £1bn, which will include a petal-shaped glass structure, a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The application for outline planning permission is due later this year, and construction could begin in 2018. The power station, commissioned in 1971, was capable of powering one million homes and was fueled by the nearby Esso refinery. The 300-acre site was sold to Fawley Waterside developers in 2016.

The passage describes the results of the Hong Kong championships for cycling. Ethan Hayter earned GB's second medal, a bronze, in the men's scratch race, chasing down Adrian Teklinski of Poland who won gold and Lucass Liss of Germany who got silver. Elinor Barker, an Olympic gold medallist, was part of the team but they were unable to compete for a medal. Joe Truman, the sole British rider in the men's keirin, was outclassed in his semi-final. The passage discusses the return of Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell in the soap opera EastEnders from 1990-1999 and again in 2005 and 2006, for a brief reunion with his character's family. Sadio Mane scored twice for Liverpool in a 2-1 win over second-placed Tottenham Hotspur at Anfield. Spurs' manager, Mauricio Pochettino, expressed concern about his team's lack of desire and ability to cope with pressure, stating that if Chelsea win their upcoming game against Burnley, they could extend their lead at the top of the Premier League to 12 points, which would be a "big problem" for Spurs. Former Liverpool and Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy criticized Spurs' performance, noting their poor play against top-six teams and a lack of pace and a different mindset when playing away from home.

In the provided passage, the All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. However, the PDP managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will offer an augmented reality experience through an app. This feature will allow visitors to access online information from signs and posters on the site, including videos and band interviews. The passage discusses the situation of several schools in Birmingham, England, that have been rated inadequate by Ofsted, the Office for Standards in Education, Children's Services and Skills. The schools in question are Park View, Nansen Primary, Oldknow Academy, and Golden Hillock School. The funding agreements for Park View and Nansen Primary will be terminated, and the Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running the schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School were warned they could lose funding unless concerns, such as less favorable treatment of non-Muslims, segregation of boys and girls, and a narrow curriculum, are addressed. In the provided passage, the core pieces of information are campaign expenditures for several political parties in the UK's May election for the European Parliament. he passage discusses a study that suggests women diagnosed with breast cancer due to carrying the BRCA1 gene, like Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of death by having their ovaries removed. The procedure, known as an oophorectomy, was associated with a 62% reduction in breast cancer death in women with a BRCA1 mutation, but this was not observed in those with a BRCA2 mutation. The study found a 65% reduction in death from all causes associated with oophorectomy. The protective effect of oophorectomy against breast cancer was apparent immediately after diagnosis and lasted for 15 years. The authors of the study suggest that oophorectomy should be considered as part of the treatment discussion for women with early-stage breast cancers who carry the BRCA mutation. The passage also mentions that women who inherit the faulty BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes have a 50 to 80% chance of developing breast cancer during their lifetime, and genetic tests are available for women who are likely to have a mutation. The BRCA gene faults are more common in the Ashkenazi Jewish population

arlos Toro, a 66-year-old former member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s due to a confrontation with his boss.
