The advertisements have been placed on the London Underground and have received significant backlash from feminists, body image campaigners, and social media users who find the campaign offensive, unrealistic, and sexist. The advertisements have been defaced, and a Change.org petition calling for their removal has gathered over 50,000 signatures.

Transport for London (TFL) has confirmed that the posters will be removed because they have come to the end of the three-week advertising period that Protein World paid for. TFL has also received over 200 complaints from people saying that the adverts promote an unhealthy body image. Protein World has defended the campaign, claiming that the image is unphotoshopped and that the campaign is targeted at health-conscious individuals looking to get fit in time for summer.

The controversy has also attracted the attention of TV personalities such as Susanna Reid, who described the campaign as "anxiety-inducing" during

In the provided passage, it is stated that rail firms are planning to increase fares by up to 87% just ten days after the general election, despite promises from main party leaders to freeze prices. The prime minister, David Cameron, has personally intervened and written to First Great Western to request an urgent review of its decision to almost double fares on the route between London and the Cotswolds, which passes through his Witney constituency. Other significant fare hikes are planned by train companies, including a 24.5% increase on the cost of an anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool, and a 22% increase on an anytime first-class day return on Virgin from Manchester to Stoke. However, Virgin defends these increases by stating that the majority of the price hikes affected "Virgin trains-only fares," which are at least 20% cheaper than tickets offered by rival firms.

A former soldier, John Young, aged 66, has been left blind in one eye after being hit with a brick thrown through his front door in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The attack occurred while he was at home with his wife Elaine, 54, who also works for the Alzheimer's Society charity. The couple had been married for just three weeks and were writing thank-you cards for their wedding gifts when their home was targeted by yobs at around 11 pm on April 18. The police have launched an investigation into the attack, but there appears to be no known motive, and it could be a case of yobs "messing around." John and Elaine are moving to a flat in Southport due to feeling unsafe in their Oldham neighborhood. The police are urging anyone with information about the incident to contact them immediately.

om Poynton, a 25-year-old wicketkeeper for Derbyshire, has signed a one-year contract extension after successfully returning from leg injuries sustained in a road accident that claimed the life of his father, Keith, in April 2014. Poynton underwent an ankle operation and made his playing comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Derbyshire's Elite Performance Director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's resilience and hard work, expressing delight at his return to the field. The new contract is expected to boost Poynton's confidence and he will be available for the start of the 2015 season, committing himself to Derbyshire until the end of the 2016 season.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw, from Stretford, battled an aggressive form of cancer (neuroblastoma) for a year and was recently given the all-clear by doctors. The cancer affected his kidney, lungs, bones, and neck. During his treatment, Harley wore a superhero mask, which he helped decorate like a ninja turtle, to help him feel stronger and brave. His story made headlines worldwide, and he received a box of ninja turtle presents from Nickelodeon for Christmas. Harley underwent 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, an operation to remove his kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy at the Christie Clinic in Manchester. He is now cancer-free but will undergo regular check-ups to ensure he stays that way. Harley's family is overjoyed and looking forward to the future. Neuroblastoma is a rare and aggressive childhood cancer that affects fewer than 100 children in the UK each year, most of whom are younger than five years old. The symptoms vary depending on the location of the

The passage discusses the advice given by Aston Villa manager Tim Sherwood to Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old player who starred in Villa's FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool. Sherwood suggests that Grealish should focus on his club career rather than his international future, as he is currently the center of a tug-of-war between the Republic of Ireland and England. Grealish has impressed Sherwood and is expected to choose between the two countries at the end of the season. Grealish's father, Kevin, also agrees that his son should prioritize his club football first. The passage also mentions that Grealish is confident and skilled on the field, and that the more opportunities he gets, the better he will become.

The passage discusses the issue of landing fees at airports for private jet travelers, a concern that is not typically encountered by average travelers. These fees can vary significantly, with some unexpectedly popular transport hubs for the rich and famous charging high fees. Examples include Salzburg in Austria and Darwin in Australia. The luxury of owning a private jet is only affordable by the wealthy, and continuous payment of landing charges, which can reach thousands, is required. The private jet industry is worth $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe. The busiest weekends often occur during major sporting events, such as the Super Bowl in America and the Monaco Grand Prix. Private jet companies like Privatefly estimate costs for a round-trip from New York to Glendale for the Super Bowl this year at around $38,000 on a medium jet and $54,000 on a long-range jet. The passage also provides a list of the most expensive airports for landing fees, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo, Japan being the most expensive at £4,559 ($6,850). Other expensive airports

The passage describes an incident where Katie Gallegos, a dog resort owner from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her dogs Cooper and Daisy to a McDonald's drive-thru for an ice cream treat. While Daisy took a few licks, Cooper quickly devoured the entire ice cream cone in one bite. The video of this incident has been viewed over seven million times. Some viewers criticized Gallegos for feeding her dogs ice cream, but she defended her actions, stating that Cooper is in good health and enjoys these treats as a weekly routine. Daisy, being smaller, only gets a few licks due to her size. Another video shows the dogs visiting a Starbucks for a "pup-uccino," with Cooper again consuming the entire beverage in one gulp. Gallegos clarified that the beverage does not contain coffee and is just a dollop of whipped cream in a cup. It is implied that Cooper and Daisy have a fondness for fast food.

Gary Locke, the former Hearts boss, has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock after a successful interim period. He joined Kilmarnock as assistant boss to Allan Johnson last summer but took over when Johnson resigned in February. Locke has lost only once in seven games since taking charge at Rugby Park, and he will speak at a press conference on Friday morning after signing a three-year deal with the club.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp from Eustis, has accused Seminole County Elementary School of threatening to suspend her autistic five-year-old son, Logan, due to essential oils he uses to manage his illness. The oils, manufactured by Doterra, are applied by Kemp on Logan's head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. Teachers and a teacher's aide complained about the oils' smell and distraction to other students. Kemp received a letter from the school board stating the oils created a problem for staff and students. Despite the threat of punishment, Kemp intends to continue using the oils, claiming they have a positive impact on her son. The Lake County School District has since stated they will not suspend Logan, citing it as a health issue. Doterra, the company that produces the oils, has scents such as lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton, known as the Sandpiper Complex, was destroyed by a severe and intense fire on Wednesday afternoon. The fire spread through 90 condos, causing them to collapse. The cause of the fire is currently unknown, but it was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the fire, but were unable to enter any of the summer homes. The building manager, Rob Taber, who lived and worked in the complex, lost everything. The fire is currently being investigated, with claims that it may have started near a car parked by the complex. The Sandpiper Complex is used as a holiday home by residents between May and November.

The passage describes Queen Elizabeth II, who is 88 years old, enjoying a ride on her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. The queen has been riding horses since she was four and has a long-standing love for equines. She has been encouraged to wear a riding helmet for safety but prefers a silk scarf instead due to her hair. The queen has ridden less in recent years due to a knee injury but remains an enthusiastic equestrienne. The passage also provides information about the history and characteristics of fell ponies, which the queen breeds at Hampton Court. These ponies have been around since the Neolithic period and were used by various invaders, including the Romans and Vikings, as pack ponies. Today, they are a popular choice for riders of all ages, with the queen being one of the breeders.

A neighbor dispute over noise levels in Brisbane escalated into a tragic incident, resulting in the death of a 55-year-old man, Leon Yeaman. The alleged perpetrator, 28-year-old Philip Pama, was charged with manslaughter after he reportedly punched Yeaman during an argument. Pama, a married father of three who works a 3 am shift at a nearby warehouse, was sleeping at the time of the commotion. Yeaman was known for getting drunk, playing loud music, and yelling at people. Pama confronted Yeaman, and during the confrontation, Pama allegedly hit Yeaman, who was later pronounced dead at the scene. Pama was granted conditional bail, with conditions including surrendering his passport, adhering to a curfew, and reporting to the local police station twice a week. Pama's defense lawyer stated that Pama was being pushed at the same time he threw the punch and did not see it connect. The case is due to return to court on May 18. Neighbors described Yeaman as kind and generous, while a friend noted that he was

A jilted 52-year-old music teacher, Yulia Simonova, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder a 15-year-old student, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. Simonova offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the hit and detailed her desire for the boy to be slowly tortured, including breaking his arms and legs, damaging his kidneys, and causing him unbearable pain before being killed. The police set up a sting operation, and an undercover officer posing as a hitman filmed the exchange. Simonova was arrested after handing over some expenses money and is now facing 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Damian Vanya, who ended the relationship with Simonova for a classmate, expressed relief and hoped Simonova would receive a long prison sentence.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, revealed in an interview that he talks to God daily but never about football. He and his family have experienced poverty and have worked as ambassadors against hunger with the World Food Programme. Mourinho tries to separate his professional and family life and has a strong faith in God, praying every day but only going to church regularly in Portugal. He only prays for personal matters and not about Chelsea. Mourinho claimed that despite his intense demeanor on the sideline, he is a good person and a good family man. Chelsea is currently at the top of the league and is playing QPR this weekend. Earlier this season, Mourinho was fined £25,000 for claiming there was a "campaign" against Chelsea after Cesc Fabregas was booked for diving against Southampton. Mourinho's son, Jose Mario, celebrated Chelsea's Capital One Cup victory with some of the players this year.

In the passage, it is stated that after an eight-year absence, Bob Barker, a TV legend known for hosting "The Price is Right" for 35 years, returned to the show. On the April 1 edition, instead of Drew Carey, Barker, now 91, was in charge. He handled the "Lucky Seven" game before passing duties back to Carey. Despite his long absence, Barker appeared to be seamless in his return.

An off-duty Secret Service agent named Arthur Baldwin was arrested in Washington D.C. at 12:30 AM on Friday on charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. The incident occurred on the 3200 block of D Street SE. Baldwin is posted to the foreign missions branch of the Secret Service, which is attached to the State Department and deals with the United States' diplomatic activities. The Secret Service revoked Baldwin's security clearance and put him on leave following the arrest. Court records show Baldwin was to be arraigned Friday afternoon, but no attorney or contact information was listed. This incident comes two days after a high-ranking supervisor was also put on leave due to allegations of misconduct, which is also being investigated by the Homeland Security Department's inspector general. These incidents are the latest in a series of issues for the Secret Service, which is responsible for protecting the President and his family.

he passage describes an incident where a freelance photographer named Atif Saeed, aged 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, took a risk to capture a photograph of a hungry lion in a safari park. He approached the lion, armed only with a camera, and managed to get within 10 feet of the lion before it was alerted by the sound of the camera's shutter. The lion then aggressively approached him, forcing him to retreat quickly. Atif Saeed was able to capture a few frames before the encounter ended. He later expressed that he was laughing about the incident at the time, but now he doubts if he would be able to repeat such a close encounter with the lion.

The passage describes an unidentified woman found unconscious and later pronounced dead on a Brooklyn street on March 22. She was approximately 25 to 45 years old. The New York City Police Department has released an image of a tattoo found on her right leg, which features a heart with the name 'Monique' etched across a ribbon within a heart topped with a rose. The police are awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of her death. Anyone with information about the woman is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers. The woman had no identification on her at the time of discovery.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a two-bedroom, solar-powered home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck due to financial constraints. After a year and a half of labor, they completed the project, which cost approximately $25,000. The home, now located in Nelson, New Zealand, is surrounded by nature and features a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and other creature comforts. The couple is nearly self-sufficient, with a power bill of just $25, and their water comes from a nearby spring. They plan to build another similar home in the future.

The passage discusses a study conducted by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University, which found that kindergarten students who shared iPads in class performed significantly better in early literacy tests compared to those who did not have access to iPads or used the device individually. The shared iPad students scored around 30 points higher in the test. Blackwell attributes this improvement to collaborative learning around the technology, suggesting that schools might reconsider how tablets are used, particularly in earlier grades, to make the technology more effective. The findings will be presented at the 65th annual conference of the International Communication Association in Puerto Rico.

A two-legged pig named "Super Pig" has become an internet sensation due to a heartwarming video showing it learning to walk on its front trotters. Born without back legs, the piglet has mastered the art of balancing and has been observed foraging for food. Despite several close calls, it always manages to regain its balance. The piglet lives with its siblings who were all born with four legs, and one of the siblings has been seen attempting to copy its two-legged counterpart. The piglet belongs to a farmer named Ms. Duan in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China. The piglet has gained attention from villagers and tourists, and it is not the first animal with two legs instead of four to win plaudits in China; a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also became a star attraction for its ability to walk on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, a pit crew member named Todd Phillips was injured when he was hit by the car of Francesco Dracone. Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was struck by Dracone's car on lap 25 while refueling and changing tires. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was taken to the infield care center for treatment and received stitches for a cut on his leg. He has since been released. The race was affected by rain, causing many cars to struggle with traction. Dracone did not finish the race and ended up in 23rd place. Francesco Dracone, a 19-year-old from Italy, spun out on turn one during the race.

In the provided passage, a husband named Milton Vieira Severiano brutally murdered his wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, a dancer who went by the stage name Amanda Bueno. The murder took place in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, and was captured on CCTV. Severiano confessed that he killed his wife due to jealousy over men looking at her. The incident occurred just four days after their marriage. The murder was preceded by a heated argument where Severiano called his wife a slut and a whore. After the murder, Severiano stole a neighbor's car but was later caught by police. Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his car. He now faces life in prison. The crime scene attracted a crowd of people.

Sarah Wilson, a journalist and author, has shared her personal struggle with mental illness, revealing she contemplated suicide due to anxiety. At 41, she felt her life was not worth living, citing mounting stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and a sense of isolation as contributing factors. Wilson believes depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and wants to acknowledge this connection to better address the rising rate of Australian women affected by stress and anxiety. She feels she missed out on a guidebook to life during her younger years, as she watched others cope while struggling with anxiety. Wilson also noted that anxiety is becoming the "new depression." Beyond Blue reports that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime, and while depression and anxiety are separate conditions, one can often lead to the other. If you or someone you know needs help, contact Beyond Blue (1300 224 636) or Lifeline (13 11 14).

An Oregon woman, Elena Curtin, who was seven-months pregnant at the time, was charged with second-degree assault in 2014 for beating her boyfriend's former girlfriend with a crowbar. The incident occurred when Curtin found the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom. However, prosecutors have dropped the charge as Curtin was deemed "completely justified in her outrage" under Oregon law, which allows for the use of physical force against an intruder who refuses to leave a resident's home. The ex-girlfriend and the boyfriend, who is the father of Curtin's child, have a five-year-old child together and have since reconciled. If Curtin had been convicted, she would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

Gemma, a pit bull, was filmed at home in California being fed treats, but when her owner tried to trick her by including broccoli, Gemma showed clear dislike for the vegetable, spitting it out on the floor. The passage also mentions that Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family when she's not eating.

HSBC has apologized for a link on its official website that inadvertently directed visitors to a pornographic site. The error occurred when the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which were scrapped in 2011, were replaced with a registration for retirement on hsbc.com.hk. HSBC has since removed the link and issued an apology, stating that its website remains secure and that it is not associated with the external third-party website. The incident caused embarrassment for the banking giant.

A 13-year-old boy named Marcus from Maryland called 911 after a fire broke out in his home in Clinton. His 9-year-old sister Aaliyah was trapped in a second-floor bedroom with him. Marcus stayed calm during the 11-minute call, giving clear instructions to the dispatcher about their location. He also comforted his sister and guided her to stay low and breathe. Firefighters were able to rescue Marcus and Aaliyah by entering their room through the home and breaking a window. Marcus was handed out of the window to another rescuer, and the firefighter gave his gas mask to Aaliyah. Both siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other family members escaped on their own and were taken to Medstar Hospital. The firefighters' actions were described as heroic.

A blue fluorescent algae, known as Noctiluca scintillans, has been illuminating Australia's east coast, specifically Jervis Bay in New South Wales and previously Manly Beach in Sydney. This phenomenon is a natural occurrence that happens in the spring and autumn. The algae emits light as a defense mechanism and is not harmful. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured these stunning images, describing the sight as a "beautiful supernatural scene."

he passage discusses new genetic tests for breast cancer that can determine the aggressiveness of a tumor and the risk of it returning. These tests, such as Endopredict, are currently available privately for around £2,500 but may become available on the NHS. The results of these tests can help women and their doctors make informed decisions about whether chemotherapy is necessary, as for some women, the risk of recurrence is as low as 5%, which is comparable to or better than the odds for those who undergo chemotherapy. The side effects of chemotherapy, including hair loss, nausea, weight gain or loss, and extreme fatigue, can be difficult to manage. The tests are currently used to spare some women from chemotherapy, which they may find more daunting than the surgery itself. The passage also includes a personal story of a woman named Becca Cornford, who was diagnosed with breast cancer in both breasts and was relieved to learn that she had a low risk of recurrence based on the Endopredict test results, sparing her from chemotherapy.

he passage discusses the issue of pregnancy among women serving in the Royal Navy. More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with HMS Ocean having five pregnant sailors removed in emergency medevacs during the last nine years. HMS Illustrious, which was nicknamed HMS Lusty, also had at least one woman airlifted due to pregnancy. Eighteen other ships, including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, had emergency evacuations.

The passage also mentions Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, who was flown back to the UK following claims of a sexual relationship with a member of her crew. An investigation was launched into her conduct, and she left HMS Portland for personal reasons.

Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990, and in 2014, around 9% of personnel were female. In 2014, three women made history by becoming the first female submariners to serve in the Royal Navy.

Strict military rules ban mothers-to-be from serving in war

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material, believed to be cesium, was found on the rooftop of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence in Tokyo. The discovery occurred on the same day a court approved the restart of two nuclear reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant, four years after the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster. The government suspects the cesium was intentionally placed in the drone, and the discovery has raised concerns about potential terrorism, particularly in relation to upcoming events like the Olympics and G7 summit. There are currently no drone flight restrictions in most of Tokyo, including the Prime Minister's residence and government buildings. The Prime Minister, Shinzo Abe, was not in his office at the time of the discovery as he was attending the Asian-African conference in Indonesia.

he passage describes a man named Lu Xincai, a security guard from China, who takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's, to work with him every day on the back of his motorbike. He does this because he is afraid she will get lost if left at home alone. Lu Xincai ties a sash around both their waists to ensure she doesn't fall off. His mother used to get lost when left alone, especially when she went to collect firewood in the mountains. Lu Xincai started taking his mother to work when his father passed away earlier this year, as there was no one else to look after her. His wife works in a different city, and his son is still in school. Lu Xincai checks on his mother throughout the day, even at work, and his employers have provided her with her own room. Lu Xincai feels a duty to care for his mother, who devoted her life to caring for her children. His mother was vulnerable and used to get lost when left alone. Lu Xincai considers his mother as his apple, and he feels relaxed only when he sees her.

The passage discusses a study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, published in the American Journal of Public Health, which found an increase in heavy drinking and binge-drinking among Americans between 2005 and 2012. Heavy drinking is defined as exceeding an average of one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men, while binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men on a single occasion. The study found that the increase in heavy drinking is largely driven by women's drinking habits as social norms change. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level, and in 2012, 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers. Despite the increases in heavy drinking, the percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained relatively unchanged over time. The study also notes that 88,600 U.S. deaths were attributed to alcohol in 2010, and the cost of excessive drinking has been estimated at more than $220 billion per year. Public health experts

The passage discusses concerns raised by UN officials about the overuse of Caesarean sections in childbirth, particularly in England. The procedure is deemed risky due to potential complications, infections, and even death. The World Health Organization (WHO) suggests that the ideal rate of Caesarean sections should be between 10% and 15%, but in England, over a quarter of women giving birth now undergo the procedure.

Factors contributing to this increase include women opting for planned Caesareans due to anxiety about natural childbirth and women with previous complicated births, being over 40, or having medical conditions such as asthma, diabetes, or depression.

However, the WHO warns that doctors are performing Caesarean sections too frequently and underestimating the risks. A planned Caesarean costs the NHS an average of £2,369, compared to a natural birth at £1,665. The WHO's stance contradicts current NHS guidelines, which offer the procedure to women even without medical justification.

A woman named Michelle Filkins, aged 44, from West Wareham, has been arrested and charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. This occurred on April 17, after she was discovered by the owner, Mark Conklin, sitting in his summer home on Martha's Vineyard, worth approximately $800,000. Filkins claimed to own the house when confronted, but fled when Conklin called the police. A large glass window was broken and covered. Filkins was later arrested after attempting to re-enter the home, thinking Conklin had left. Items missing from the home include furniture, appliances, and a painting by the owner. The police are asking anyone who purchased items or received items from the home to return them to the Edgartown Police Department. The police department also stated that anyone who did purchase something is a victim and will assist in seeking restitution via the court prosecution of this case. Anyone with information can contact the police department at 508-627-4343.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was reunited with its owner after police posted a series of bizarre selfies and puns on Bella's Facebook page. The phone was handed in to Albury police station on the NSW-Victoria border on Sunday morning. Police officers used the unlocked phone to post selfies and humorous comments on Bella's Facebook page, including a photo of the phone in a holding cell and jokes about the phone being charged. Bella lost her phone at a friend's birthday party the night before and was able to reclaim it from the police station without having to give her name, as officers recognized her from her Facebook page. Bella's friends shared the police posts and labeled them as "legends" for their unusual approach to tracking down the phone's owner. Bella has since put a password on her phone.

In this passage, a five-day-old baby hippopotamus was killed during a fight between two adult male hippos in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park, Eastern South Africa. The mother of the calf watched in horror as the baby was caught up in the fight, grabbed by one of the adults, and flung into the air. Despite the mother's attempts to rescue her baby, the calf died hours later from its injuries. The incident was witnessed by Stacey Farrell, a 30-year-old tour operator for Shoreline Hippo and Safari. The exact motive for the attack is unclear, with possibilities including intent to kill, play, or jealousy gone wrong. The mother of the calf had initially stayed with her herd, possibly believing it safer to do so, but this decision proved fatal for the baby.

three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is on the market for £575,000, but it has only three years left on the lease. The property, located in Egerton Place, is described as bright and well-proportioned with 1,990 sq/ft of space, three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking, and a communal garden. The cost of £575,000 on a three-year lease would work out at £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month, which is around the going rate for renting a three-bedroom flat in the area. If a buyer decides to extend the lease, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million. The property needs renovation, and the current freeholder is thought to be the Welcome Trust. Any buyer would have to negotiate a lease extension with them, and for a 90-year lease, it is likely to cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. It is rare for properties with such short leases to come

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting registers at 8,000 stores in the US and Canada on Friday, causing free drinks to be given away. The outage began in the early evening on the east coast and in the late afternoon on the west coast. Starbucks stores were expected to open for business as usual on Saturday. The company did not explain the cause of the outage, but it was a failure during a daily system refresh. Some stores closed to prevent giving away free products during the shutdown. The outage also affected Starbucks' Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. The incident occurred just one day after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings with net revenues of $4.6 billion.

Terrorists are undergoing training and radicalizing Muslims in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, according to the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. These individuals participate in seemingly ordinary activities in the community but have an ulterior motive, as stated by Detective Constable Gareth Jones. Incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales can be traced back to 1998, and the area has historical connections to terrorism, such as the training of extremists by Abu Hamza in the Brecon Beacons in 2005. The rugged terrain of the region is also used for military training, including the British military and elite forces like the SAS. Notably, two of the 7/7 bombers were photographed white water rafting in North Wales in 2005. Additionally, would-be terrorists have been photographed holding secret meetings in a country park in Wales. Community intelligence is essential for authorities in addressing these issues, as emphasized by Detective Constable Jones.

A juvenile female Omura's whale, a rare species believed to be restricted to tropical and subtropical waters, was found washed up on a remote beach in Exmouth, Western Australia. This is the first sighting of the species in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. The discovery was initially challenging for the Department of Parks and Wildlife staff to identify, but DNA profiling confirmed it as an Omura's whale. The find is significant for whale scientists as very little is known about the species, which is usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered in a few years for further scientific investigation and potential public display in museums.

The passage discusses the bias against women in politics and the workplace, using the example of Cheryl Rios, CEO of Go Ape Marketing, who expressed the belief that a woman should not be president due to hormonal differences. Rios's statement received criticism, but her view is not unique. The passage also mentions that Hillary Clinton, a potential presidential candidate, might face a steeper climb to the White House due to her gender. The passage highlights the prevalent bias against women, which limits their potential in leadership roles, and argues for the eradication of gender stereotypes for the benefit of everyone. The passage also mentions that studies show women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than their male counterparts.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, known for roles in All Creatures Great and Small, playing Winston Churchill several times, and more recently in the Harry Potter films, is downsizing his home and selling his extensive collection of antiques in a £100,000 auction. The collection includes over 200 items such as furniture, paintings, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, and books dating back to the 17th century. Notable items include a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow made from yew with a mother-of-pearl handle, a portrait of Hardy holding the bow, and an early 20th-century painting of Alfred the Great rebuilding London. Hardy, who studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien and is an expert on the medieval longbow, has built up his collection due to his interest in classic literature and military history. He has published two books on the history of the longbow and was consulted as an expert during the raising of the Tudor shipwreck the Mary Rose.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man with a history of bipolar mental illness, battery on law enforcement, and involuntary commitment to a psychiatric ward, is on the run after being named a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57. The body was discovered at their shared home in Winter Garden, following a well-being check by an out-of-state family member. Michael failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day, which raised suspicions. Neighbors believe divorce proceedings may have contributed to the murder, as Sandra was preventing Michael from meeting his son and was involved in his divorce. Michael allegedly went into the trailer park's office asking for a glass of water shortly after the murder. His estranged wife is preparing to protect herself, and anyone with information about his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision was made by the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council, who bypassed the usual bidding process due to a strategic opportunity to host the IAAF World Championships for the first time in the USA. Eugene previously failed to host the 2019 event, which was instead awarded to Doha. The IAAF Council's decision was motivated by the collaboration of public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public. The 2007 World Championships held in Osaka, Japan, was also awarded without a bidding process. Mo Farah won gold in the men's 10,000 meters during the 2013 IAAF World Athletics Championships in Moscow.

spiring model Leonie Granger, 25, has been sentenced to 16 years in prison for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56. Granger targeted Hassan after spotting him at a casino in London's West End, befriending him, and accepting gifts, cash, and trips to fancy restaurants. She lured Hassan to his flat, where her boyfriend and an accomplice tied him up, kicked him to death, and ransacked his home to find his hidden winnings. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter by a majority but not guilty of murder. Co-defendants Kyrron Jackson, 28, and Nicholas Chandler, 29, were found guilty of murder and were sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum term of 36 years. The attack was described as "pitiless and wicked" by the judge. Granger, Jackson, and Chandler were also convicted of robbing Hassan and conspiracy to falsely imprison him.

The passage discusses the performance of Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas, who has been struggling during the second half of the season. Despite a promising start to the season, Fabregas' form has dipped significantly, leading to concerns about his durability. His poor form was evident in Spain's 2-0 defeat by Holland, where he was criticized for his performance. Fabregas has been a key player for Chelsea, contributing to their success in the Premier League and the Capital One Cup. However, his contributions have decreased as the season has progressed, with a drop in the number of assists he has provided. This decline in form has raised questions about Fabregas' ability to maintain his performance level throughout a long, intense season. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho will be hoping for a resurgence in Fabregas' form in the remaining games of the season, as Chelsea could need as many as six wins to secure the Premier League title.

West Ham United is in discussions to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a two-week trial with their academy. Beckford, from Montego Bay United, has also received offers from Belgian clubs and is considered one of the hottest prospects to emerge from the Caribbean. Additionally, West Ham has announced that season tickets for their Olympic Stadium will cost as little as £289 for the 2016-17 season, making it the cheapest pricing strategy in the Barclays Premier League.

he passage describes an investigation dropped by Wiltshire police into a vicious assault on Mike Lane, a huntsman, three months after the incident. The attack was carried out by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes, during a hunt where the hounds were chasing an artificial scent, not a fox. Mike Lane was beaten, kicked in the head, and suffered concussion, broken teeth, memory loss, and a swollen face. A video of the incident and a dossier of evidence, including some names of saboteurs and their car registration numbers, were given to Wiltshire police. The main suspect's face was captured on video, but the police have not been able to identify or prosecute anyone involved. Hunt supporters across the country are dismayed by the police's decision to shelve the inquiry due to insufficient evidence. The passage also mentions that Karen Fieldsend, who made the call to police, and James Cameron, vice-chairman of the Tedworth hunt, are angry about the case being dropped. The Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings to help bring crim

Adam Gadahn, a U.S. citizen and a prominent member of Al Qaeda, known as the American mouthpiece of the terrorist organization, was killed in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation in January. He was born in 1978 and converted to Islam in 1995, leaving the United States for Pakistan three years later. Gadahn was indicted for treason and material support to Al Qaeda in 2006. He was among the FBI's most wanted terrorists and appeared in videos commemorating the 9/11 attacks, urging Muslims in the United States to stage their own lone-wolf attacks. Warren Weinstein, another U.S. citizen who was abducted by Al Qaeda in Pakistan in 2011, died along with an Italian hostage, Giovanni Lo Porto, in the operation that killed Gadahn.

he passage describes a five-year-old Chinese boy named Mai Zizhuo who has gained significant attention in China due to a viral video showcasing his exceptional basketball skills. He has been playing basketball since he was two and a half years old. The video shows him scoring multiple hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously without losing rhythm. His skills have garnered him a large fanbase across China. The comparison is made to Yao Ming, the country's biggest basketball star to date. Netizens are stunned by Mai's potential, with some expressing disbelief, questioning his father's identity, and feeling ashamed of their own basketball skills in comparison.

Tom O'Carroll, a former member of the notorious Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which advocated for the legalization of child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, who was previously an information officer at the Open University and a key activist for PIE, attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, established in response to the phone-hacking scandal, is campaigning against the Independent Press Standards Organization, which they view as biased and unfair. They advocate for a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. However, O'Carroll's association with Hacked Off is likely to be an embarrassment to the group due to his past involvement with PIE. PIE, formed in 1974, also sought to lower the age of sexual consent to ten if the child understood the nature of the act and apparently consented, and they advocated for the legalization of incest

On Thursday, Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained to serve as an unusual catwalk setting for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The show featured models parading through the empty pool and along the break wall, with a backdrop of the ocean. Ten Pieces, a lifestyle brand headed by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, presented a monochrome unisex collection of ten pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways, suitable for day to night wear. Guests were treated to nibbles by Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria. Beachgoers at Bondi stopped to watch the show, and the collection was designed to be androgynous, with models wrapping up in scarves and hoodies from the unisex collection. The show took place on an unseasonably warm day, and guests enjoyed the sunny weather poolside before the show commenced.

Amir Khan, a boxer born in Bolton, spent a family day at a safari park in northern California, where he posed with and fed a rare white tiger, as well as giraffes and sea lions. He was accompanied by his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and their daughter Lamysa. Amir Khan has announced his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30. Previously, there was speculation about his next opponent, with pressure to fight British rival Kell Brook in June, but Khan was already in negotiations to fight someone else.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, will have his name removed from an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. Abu Khdeir, 16, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, according to prosecutors. His family and Almagor, an organization that works on behalf of victims of terror in Israel, objected to his inclusion on the memorial, describing his death as a rogue attack and not a terror victim. Almagor wrote a letter to the National Insurance Institute of Israel, demanding that Abu Khdeir's name be removed from the memorial. On Wednesday, it was reported that the National Insurance Institute of Israel will remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial following his father's complaints. The teen's name has already been removed from the organization's website, which lists the names on the memorial wall. A panel of judges began hearing evidence in January against the three suspects in Abu Khdeir's killing.

The passage describes a YouTube video by California-based user Lionel Hutz, featuring his young son attempting to use their family cat as a pillow. The boy chases the cat around the garden, and when he catches up, he places himself on the cat's belly. The cat, after a brief moment of stillness, gets up and moves to another spot. The boy follows the cat and repeats the process. This sequence happens one more time before the cat decides to leave. In a later video, the boy is seen making up with the cat by feeding him treats. The summary is titled "Sleepy head: YouTube user Lionel Hutz filmed his young son chasing the family feline around the garden in a bid to get some rest," with the cat being referred to as a "perfect pillow" and not being "amused" by the situation.

In a Philadelphia police corruption trial, witness Robert Kushner, a former marijuana dealer, lost his coaching job at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past drug dealing activities. Kushner testified that some of the undercover officers on trial had stolen $81,000 in cash and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. He had passed a background check when he was hired to coach basketball in 2010, but he was arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation. Kushner believes he is innocent of the 2011 charges and never meant to deceive the school. He also coaches in a Narberth summer league, where he is described as an excellent coach who is good with kids. The trial involves six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering, and the defense has claimed that the government case is based on 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

In the passage, an explosion at a paraxylene (px) producing chemical plant in Zhangzhou city, Fujian province, China, caused a fire. Six people were injured by broken glass and taken to the hospital. The fire, which occurred at an oil storage facility after an oil leak, is now under control after 600 firefighters were sent to extinguish it. The plant, which is reportedly carcinogenic, has a history of protests due to pollution concerns, and was relocated to a more remote location in 2007 following public backlash. The plant was previously slated for Xiamen, a densely populated city in southeast China. There was no mention of toxic chemical spills in this incident, but the plant has a history of explosions, with the last one occurring in July 2013.

ack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager and Republic of Ireland under-21 international, has a superstition about wearing his socks low on the field. Despite some Premier League referees asking him to pull his socks up, he plans to continue this practice. Grealish made his first Premier League start against QPR in a 3-3 draw, a relegation scrap, and was pleased to have finally made his debut. He expressed gratitude for the faith shown in him by the coach and hopes to secure more starts before the end of the season.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has global and irreversible brain damage, according to her grandmother Cissy Houston. Despite no longer being in a medically induced coma, Bobbi Kristina remains unresponsive. She does not respond to visitors or familiar voices, her eyes do not follow a person around the room, and she has a tracheostomy in her throat. Bobby Brown, her father, previously stated that her condition had improved, but a source with knowledge of her condition and an attorney for the Brown family have since clarified that while her condition has improved, the quality of her life remains uncertain as she is undergoing rehabilitation.

In the Fed Cup tie between Russia and Germany, Russia holds a 2-0 lead, thanks to Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova's victory over Sabine Lisicki. Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point in the second set and won the match 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3. Earlier, Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets. Both players struggled with their serves, but Pavlyuchenkova's 13 double faults were offset by Lisicki's 63 unforced errors. Lisicki acknowledged that Pavlyuchenkova's power caused her problems and that she had a match point but lost it due to a good point from Pavlyuchenkova. Russia now needs one more win from the remaining three matches on Sunday to secure the Fed Cup final and their first title since 2008.

The passage describes an impending storm in New South Wales (NSW), Australia, which is predicted to bring heavy rain and potentially cause more floods and damage. This storm is an East Coast Low, the same weather system that affected the state last week. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned about the impact of the storm, particularly on the hard-hit Hunter region, and is urging residents to prepare themselves and their homes. Meteorologists suggest that the storm will hit the northern parts of the state, with Sydney possibly experiencing less heavy rain compared to last week. The SES is working to complete as many jobs as possible before the next storm hits, with over 1000 personnel in the field across NSW, including from other states. The passage also mentions that the SES was deluged with calls for assistance last week and has more than 4,000 jobs still to be completed.

he passage discusses a model named Nina Moric, who appeared in Ricky Martin's music video for the song "La Vida Loca." Nina was hospitalized after collapsing due to low blood pressure, not as a result of attempting suicide, contrary to initial reports by Italian media. She posted photographs of her injuries on her Instagram account to reassure her followers that she was recovering at home. Nina's boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, was reported to have suggested that she had attempted suicide, but Nina denied these claims. The passage also mentions that Nina was once married to Fabrizio Corona, a famous paparazzi snapper who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photographs.

The passage discusses a poll conducted by YouGov for The Sunday Times, where the British public express their preferences for the names of the second child of Kate and William, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. If the child is a girl, the preferred name is Diana, in honor of William's mother, Princess Diana. Alice and Charlotte are the next most popular choices. If the child is a boy, James and Alexander are the top choices. The poll also shows that a majority of Brits support William taking six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job. Additionally, there is a strong preference for a baby girl among the public, with only three percent hoping for a younger brother for Prince George. Social media users have also expressed their support for the name Diana, with some stating they would be upset if the baby girl is not named Diana.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near a group of protesters in Khost, Eastern Afghanistan, on Thursday, killing 17 people and wounding 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other organization has claimed responsibility. The protesters were on their way to join a larger rally against the provincial governor. The attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time. The report was contributed by CNN's Masoud Popalzai, Jethro Mullen, and Elizabeth Joseph.

Dani Alves, a Brazilian right-back who has spent seven successful years at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice, will be leaving the club this summer. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that Alves rejected a three-year contract extension offer from Barcelona, as the offer was contingent on him participating in 60% of matches for the club. The negotiations are now over, according to Santana.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old footballer currently playing for Argentinian giants Boca Juniors on loan from Southampton, has suggested that Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti should join him at Boca. Osvaldo believes that the fans would adore having these players on the La Bombonera pitch due to their South American style of play and their abilities. Andrea Pirlo is renowned as one of the best midfielders in world football, while Totti is a Roma legend. Osvaldo feels that Totti would be equally loved if he moved to Argentina.

he passage describes an incident involving 18-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson. He fell spectacularly from his horse during a race at Wincanton, performing a double somersault. The fall has been widely viewed online, with hundreds of thousands of views. Despite the fall, Ferguson was back at work the next day, mucking out stables at Paul Nicholls' yard. He only has a cut on his nose as a result of the fall. Ferguson was unaware of what happened during the fall until he watched the replay in the weighing room. The other jockeys expressed concern and watched the replay with him. Ferguson considers the fall to be the most impressive he has seen and jokes about considering a career in gymnastics after his racing career ends.

James Haskell, a London Wasps captain and England flanker, posted a photo of himself dressed as Iron Man on Instagram to express his excitement for the release of the new Avengers: Age of Ultron movie. Haskell returned to Wasps for the 2012 season after playing for Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders in New Zealand. He initially joined Wasps in 2002, played eight seasons for the club, and won his first England cap five years later. However, he moved to Stade Francais in 2009 and spent two seasons in France before moving to Tokyo with the Ricoh Black Rams following the 2011 World Cup. He then moved to New Zealand to join the Highlanders, but made only 12 appearances and returned to England in 2012. Since his return to Wasps, Haskell has surpassed the 100 appearances mark for the club and has become a big part of the England squad with 57 caps to-date.

The passage discusses the resurgence of the wide-leg trouser as a trend for Spring/Summer 2015. This style, which can be denim, cropped, printed, or striped, is considered a refreshing alternative to the long-reigning skinny jeans. The wide-leg trouser can be intimidating, especially for shorter individuals, but pairing it with high-heeled shoes and simple tops can help create a flattering and confident look. Denim is considered the easiest way to achieve this trend, with brands like Gucci and Topshop offering denim versions. Other designers, such as Celine and Stella McCartney, have showcased dressier versions of the wide-leg trouser. For a more affordable option, Topshop's Miller jean is recommended. The wide-leg trouser is a versatile trend that can update one's wardrobe and doesn't require nice weather to wear. For more inspiration and to shop the look, readers are directed to astylealbum.com. Poppy Delevingne also showcased this trend at the AW15 Chloe show in Paris.

The University of Michigan has decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" after initially cancelling it due to student objections. The film, which stars Bradley Cooper as Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL and the most lethal sniper in U.S. military history, was criticized by some students for its depiction of the Iraq War as negatively reflecting on the Middle East and people from that region. The Detroit metropolitan area, where the university is located, has the nation's largest Arab-American population. A counter-petition was signed asking school officials to reconsider the cancellation, and on Wednesday, E. Royster Harper, the university's vice president for student life, stated that the decision to cancel the showing was a mistake and that the film will be screened as part of a student event. UMix, the event organizer, will also offer a screening of the family-friendly "Paddington" for those who prefer not to attend "American Sniper." The announcement received praise from Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

On April 3, two French tourists allegedly set a quokka, a small Australian animal resembling a domestic cat, on fire using an aerosol spray and a lighter on Rottnest Island off Perth in Western Australia. The quokka survived but was singed. Detectives questioned the men, aged 18 and 24, and seized video evidence. They were evicted from the island and charged with animal cruelty. They are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas can be found on several small islands off the west Australian coast, including Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany.

A 102-year-old dancer named Alice Barker, who performed at New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s, was shown early music videos (soundies) of herself dancing for the first time. This was made possible by Mark Cantor of Jazz-on-Film.com and some volunteers. Barker, who had never seen any films of herself or her photographs, was delighted by the experience.

he passage discusses the declining trend of washing one's own car in Britain, as revealed by a study conducted by vehicle leasing firm OSV. The study found that 31% of men have never washed their own car, with only 12% of those who do saying they do it regularly. Women are even less likely to wash their own cars, with 75% admitting they never do. The rise of hand car washes and factors such as shops opening on Sundays and more live football on TV are contributing to this decline. The study also found that Brits are more likely to wash their own car during holidays, with Audi, Toyota, and BMW owners being the most likely to do so. The least likely to wash their own cars are Range Rover, Peugeot, and Mercedes owners. OSV spokesman Andrew Kirkley attributes this decline to lack of time, larger cars, and a lack of interest from children in earning pocket money by washing cars.

Martin Skrtel, a defender for Liverpool, has praised Steven Gerrard's impact on him since joining Liverpool in 2008. Gerrard, Liverpool's captain, is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley on Sunday. If Liverpool wins, Gerrard will play his last match at Anfield in the FA Cup final against Arsenal on his birthday, May 30, before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel considers Gerrard as one of the best players in the world and believes he is synonymous with Liverpool. Gerrard aims to end his Liverpool career by making the FA Cup final and beating Arsenal. Skrtel was signed by Rafael Benitez from Zenit St. Petersburg seven years ago and credits Gerrard for helping him settle at Liverpool. Skrtel believes Liverpool has potential replacements for Gerrard, but they need the right help to fill his void. Both Gerrard and Skrtel could return to the Liverpool line-up after serving three-match bans for violent conduct.

Jack Nicklaus, aged 75, achieved a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole during the Par-3 Contest at Augusta National. This was his first hole-in-one on the hallowed turf of Augusta. However, his achievement was eclipsed by Camilo Villegas, who also made two holes-in-one during the same event. Villegas made one on the fourth hole like Nicklaus and another on the eighth, but he lost out to Kevin Streelman in a play-off. Jack Nicklaus is a renowned golfer, having won the Masters Tournament six times, including being the youngest person to wear a green jacket in 1963. He is one of five men to complete the career Grand Slam. Rory McIlroy, a favorite, can achieve this accolade if he wins his third major in succession.

On Wednesday night, several storms brought reports of tornadoes in Kansas, with one spotted about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, posing potential risks to other communities. Nighttime tornadoes were reported as the most deadly and dangerous by CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers. Other reports of tornadoes came in from Southwestern Kansas. Additionally, a tornado may have touched down in the small town of Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis, causing wind damage, flooding, and fallen trees. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

A Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, pleaded not guilty to a charge of second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting a man he intended to subdue with a taser. The shooting occurred during a weapons sting operation in April. Bates claims the shooting was accidental. The family of the victim, Eric Harris, expressed disappointment that Bates is going on a vacation to the Bahamas during this time, interpreting it as a sign of apathy. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. The family's lawyer claims Bates was not qualified for the force and received preferential treatment due to donations and friendship with the sheriff. Some supervisors in the Tulsa County Sheriff's Office were allegedly told to forge Bates' records, but the office denies these allegations. Over the weekend, some of Bates' training documents were released, showing he had proper law enforcement training. Two deputies involved in Harris' arrest have been reassigned due to threats against them and their families.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas. Prior to this, McGregor has revealed a new tattoo of a tiger's face on his stomach, which he described as a warning that "if you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." McGregor claims Aldo lacks the same motivation as him for the title fight. During a promotional tour in Dublin, McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt and raised it in front of 5,000 home supporters, escalating their already fractious relationship. The title fight will mark the eighth defense of Aldo's belt, but McGregor believes he has greater motivation to win the title.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott was cheered on by a crowd as he quickly drank a schooner of beer at an Australian Rules function. This act has drawn criticism from anti-drinking campaigners who claim it glorifies binge drinking and reinforces the stereotype that being a man involves heavy drinking. Julie Roberts, a cultural studies professor, called it problematic, stating that it sets up a culture where drinking is about speed and quantity rather than socializing. The incident was also criticized for perpetuating the stereotype that heavy drinking makes one a true Australian. Health Minister Susannah Ley defended Abbott, stating that his fitness and work ethic are more important for a healthy country. Abbott gave a speech at the event, joking about being a rugby man but now getting to hang out with footballers, and then quickly drank the schooner, dribbling some on his shirt. This is not the first time an Australian prime minister has shown off his skolling skills, with Bob Hawke being a notable example. However, Roberts believes Abbott should have considered recent shifts in attitudes towards heavy drinking.

The passage discusses a significant increase in HIV cases in Indiana, specifically in Scott County, which is tied to intravenous drug users primarily using the high-powered painkiller Opana. There are now 120 confirmed HIV cases and 10 preliminary positive cases, up from 106 the previous week. The increase in cases could put pressure on Governor Mike Pence to extend the 30-day needle exchange program he approved on March 26. The program, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and received 1,400 used syringes, is intended to curb the state's largest-ever HIV outbreak. However, the future of the program and similar legislation in other counties is uncertain, as Pence opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy. The House has approved a bill that would allow 23 Indiana counties with the highest rate-per-population of hepatitis C to establish their own needle-exchange programs, but its fate is unclear. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that between 50 percent and 90 percent of

he passage describes an incident where a football fan, whose favorite club is Arsenal, made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a test about Arsenal. The test was in the format of a school exam with multiple-choice questions, tables to complete, and an 'in your own words' section. Saskia scored 87% on the test, but her boyfriend criticized her performance, suggesting she could have done better. The FC in Arsenal FC stands for Football Club, and the nickname for Arsenal fans is the Gunners. The current manager of Arsenal is not specified in the passage. The kit in the picture is not identified as either the home or away kit. The passage does not provide the starting 11 squad of this season in their relevant positions. Saskia's creative answers, such as stating that Alexis Sanchez is better than Eden Hazard because he is 'buff' and 'Chilean,' and that Arsenal is the best team because they have won many FA Cups and Thierry Henry is a legend, were appreciated by her boyfriend and fellow football fans. Some found the boyfriend's actions excessive, while others saw it as a fun and creative

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s due to a confrontation with his boss. He provided valuable information about his former bosses and associates, including Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega, and was instrumental in several undercover stings around the world. Toro was promised US citizenship in exchange for his work, but has not received it and is now technically living in the US illegally due to declining health and retirement. The DEA has refused to help Toro with his citizenship after he went public with his plight. Toro fears deportation to Colombia, where he believes he would be in danger. He has aided in the prosecution of several high-profile figures, including Noriega, and has received support from former colleagues. Toro is currently in limbo, trying to secure a green card or a passport, and cannot collect social security benefits until he does so. If necessary, he is prepared to go into hiding.

A 14-year-old girl from India is fighting for her life with 70% burns in Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village in Uttar Pradesh's Mathura district. The incident occurred when she went outside to relieve herself. The girl set herself on fire using kerosene, and her brother attempted to put out the flames. The accused men have been arrested. The issue of sexual assault in India is sensitive at the moment, following the ban of a documentary about the gang rape and murder of an Indian student in Delhi. Recent attacks in India have led to street protests, with many calling for more protection for women. In a separate incident, an 18-year-old girl was brutally beaten to death in Nagaland, eastern India, after being accused of rape and murder. The attention given to the case of the 14-year-old girl and the previous case of Jyoti Singh Pandey, a physiotherapy student who was gang-raped and died from her injuries, has sparked protests in India and internationally about misogyny in the country.

anchester United manager Louis van Gaal will be without Robin van Persie for the derby against Manchester City at Old Trafford on Sunday due to ankle trouble. Van Gaal has ruled out Van Persie, stating he is not yet fit enough to play. The United boss wants his side to take all three points against City to finish as high as second or third in the table, potentially avoiding a Champions League qualifying fixture later in the summer. Van Gaal acknowledges that City will provide a stern challenge and plays down the idea of seeking revenge after losing the away fixture earlier in the campaign. Luke Shaw is also not yet fit enough to feature for United. Van Gaal is looking forward to experiencing the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford for the first time since arriving at the club.

In the Barclays Premier League match between Arsenal and Liverpool at the Emirates Stadium, fans from both teams left their seats empty for the first 10 minutes as a protest against high ticket prices. This protest was sparked by the recent £5.14 billion TV rights deal and the high ticket prices for the match, with the cheapest ticket being £64. Fans displayed banners inside and outside the stadium expressing their dissatisfaction with the rising costs of following their clubs. The protest was organized by Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement, Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups. Protesters hope the empty seats will raise awareness of the struggles fans face to meet the rising costs. Away fans, who have to pay high prices to attend, also participated in the protest. Further protests are expected after the match.

A newborn baby named Star Reader, diagnosed with a life-threatening liver condition called biliary atresia, underwent a successful liver transplant from her mother's twin sister, Shanell Reader. Star's parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, noticed her skin turning a yellowish tinge shortly after birth, which led to tests revealing her bile ducts were blocked. The family was told a liver transplant was necessary for Star's survival, as neither parent was a suitable match. Shanell, Star's maternal aunt, offered part of her liver and was found to be an ideal candidate. Star underwent the transplant in November and has since made a good recovery, requiring regular blood tests and lifelong anti-rejection medication. Shanell, who donated part of her liver, also made a full recovery. Biliary atresia affects about 1 in 16,000 babies at birth and, if untreated, can lead to liver failure and death. The most common treatments for biliary atresia include the Kasai procedure.

In the passage, it is described that Chelsea football players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge. The challenges included shooting balls into the boot of a car from close range, sinking balls into convertible Audis from long range, and playing over a makeshift tennis court with an Audi R8 V10 plus as the net. Hazard and Ake won the majority of the challenges, taking a 6-0 lead after the first two rounds. However, in the final game, Willian and Remy won by smashing the wing mirror of an Audi during the long-range shooting challenge. Remy reacted with disbelief, but it is implied that he will not have to pay for the damage. Willian was allowed to drive one of the Audis that was part of the challenge after the incident.

A former Fortune 500 executive, Robert Dellinger, pleaded guilty to negligent homicide in the deaths of a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy (24) and Jason Timmons (29), and their unborn baby, Reagan Elizabeth, in a highway crash in December 2013. The passage discusses the Firechat app, developed by Open Garden, which allows users to chat with friends without the need for the web or a mobile signal. The passage also introduces Greenstone, a small egg-shaped gadget developed by Open Garden. Greenstone acts as a beacon or booster to help messages move around wireless mesh networks more easily, addressing the limitation of the messages' range in these networks. Greenstone is still under development and currently works with Firechat within a range of around 20ft (6 meters). It is designed to be used in communities, neighborhoods, hospitals, or any other situation where resilient communication is needed, even in the absence of a traditional internet connection. A high-definition map of dark matter, the invisible substance that makes up approximately 80% of the matter in the universe, has been produced by the University of Manchester. This map, the first in a series, covers 0.4% of the night sky and shows clumps of dark matter in red, with less in blue. The goal is to map 12.5% of the sky over five years, which will allow a 3D view of dark matter and help astronomers study how galaxies formed in the universe. The map was created using data captured by the Dark Energy Camera, a 570-megapixel imaging device, and the survey uses the 13ft Victor M. Blanco telescope located at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory in Chile. The survey, part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey, will help scientists better test current cosmological theories by comparing the amounts of dark and visible matter. The map was released at the April meeting of the American Physical Society in Baltimore, Maryland.
